description: Asn rich cytoplasmic protein that contains RGG motifs; high-copy suppressor of group II intron-splicing defects of a mutation in MRS2 and of a conditional mutation in POL1 (DNA polymerase alpha); possible role in mitochondrial mRNA splicing
Asparagine synthetase; catalyzes the synthesis of L-asparagine from L-aspartate in the asparagine biosynthetic pathway; ASN1 has a paralog, ASN2, that arose from the whole genome duplication
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; simultaneous mutations in ASN1 and its paralog ASN2 confer asparagine auxotropy; in systematic studies null mutant shows increased cadmium accumulation

description: Asparagine synthetase; catalyzes the synthesis of L-asparagine from L-aspartate in the asparagine biosynthetic pathway; ASN2 has a paralog, ASN1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; simultaneous mutations in ASN2 and its paralog ASN1 confer asparagine auxotropy; in systematic studies null mutant shows increased sensitivity to starvation

briefDescription: Asparagine tRNA (tRNA-Asn), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Asparagine tRNA (tRNA-Asn), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants have diminished capacity to utilize galactose as a carbon source, but grow faster than wild-type when subjected to reducing agent 1,4-dithiothreitol

phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow slowly when subjected to reducing agent 1,4-dithiothreitol, but grow faster than wild-type in salt

description: Asparagine tRNA (tRNA-Asn), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow slowly under standard conditions, or when subjected to reducing agent 1,4-dithiothreitol

description: Asparagine tRNA (tRNA-Asn), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow faster than wild-type when subjected to reducing agent 1,4-dithiothreitol

description: Aspartate kinase (L-aspartate 4-P-transferase); cytoplasmic enzyme that catalyzes the first step in the common pathway for methionine and threonine biosynthesis; expression regulated by Gcn4p and the general control of amino acid synthesis
functionSummary: Aspartate kinase involved in the biosynthesis of methionine, threonine, and homoserine
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes auxotrophy for methionine, threonine and homoserine; activation leads to excretion of threonine

briefDescription: Aspartate tRNA (tRNA-Asp), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Aspartate tRNA (tRNA-Asp), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis

Aspartic beta semi-aldehyde dehydrogenase; catalyzes the second step in the common pathway for methionine and threonine biosynthesis; expression regulated by Gcn4p and the general control of amino acid synthesis

Aspartic protease; hyperglycosylated member of the yapsin family of proteases, attached to the plasma membrane via a glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor; involved in nutrient limitation-induced cleavage of the extracellular inhibitory domain of signaling mucin Msb2p, resulting in activation of the filamentous growth MAPK pathway; involved with other yapsins in the cell wall integrity response; role in KEX2-independent processing of the alpha factor precursor
functionSummary: Aspartic protease; involved in nutrient limitation-induced cleavage of the signaling mucin Msb2p, resulting in filamentous growth MAPK pathway activation; involved with Kex2p in processing of the alpha factor precursor; role in the cell wall integrity response; GPI-anchored component of the plasma membrane

description: Aspartic protease; member of the yapsin family of proteases involved in cell wall growth and maintenance; attached to the plasma membrane via a glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor
functionSummary: Plasma membrane-anchored aspartic endopeptidase involved in cell wall organization

description: Aspartyl protease; secreted into the periplasmic space of mating type a cell; helps cells find mating partners; cleaves and inactivates alpha factor allowing cells to recover from alpha-factor-induced cell cycle arrest
functionSummary: Aspartyl protease; involved in the catabolism of the alpha factor peptide during adaptation to pheromone during conjugation with cellular fusion; localizes to the extracellular region, the cell wall and to the cell periphery in high-throughput studies
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays a decreased rate of growth on rich media but increased competitive fitness on non-fermentable carbon sources; null mutant has increased pheromone sensitivity, abnormally elongated buds, and has decreased resistance to hyperosmotic stress; overexpression results in a decreased rate of growth and increased pseudohyphal growth

description: Aspartyl-tRNA synthetase, primarily cytoplasmic; homodimeric enzyme that catalyzes the specific aspartylation of tRNA(Asp); class II aminoacyl tRNA synthetase; binding to its own mRNA may confer autoregulation; shares five highly conserved amino acids with human that when mutated cause leukoencephalopathy characterized by hypomyelination with brain stem and spinal cord involvement and leg spasticity (HBSL)
functionSummary: Aspartyl-tRNA synthetase that performs aspartyl-tRNA aminoacylation by coupling aspartate to aspartyl-tRNA; localizes to both the nucleus and cytoplasm
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; repression leads to cell cycle arrest at G1 phase; overexpression causes slow growth

briefDescription: Assembly factor for F1 sector of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase
description: Assembly factor for F1 sector of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; conserved protein; required for assembly of alpha and beta subunits into F1 sector of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; human homolog ATPAF2 can complement yeast atp12 mutant; mutation of human homolog reduces active ATP synthase levels and is associated with the disorder ATPAF2 deficiency
functionSummary: Protein with a role in assembly of the mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase complex; binds to the Atp1p subunit during assembly; localized to mitochondria
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a severe respiratory growth defect, decreased rate of vegetative growth, decreased utilization of various carbon and nitrogen sources; null mutant has a reduced cell size, displays decreased resistance to heat, manganese, freeze-thaw and oxidative stress; null mutant is petite-negative, displays decreased mitophagy, decreased chronological lifespan, decreased glycogen accumulation, abnormal mitochondrial morphology, and elevated rates of mini-chromosome loss

briefDescription: Assembly factor for the eIF2 translation initiation factor complex
description: Assembly factor for the eIF2 translation initiation factor complex; regulates translational initiation; conserved residues of this ATP-Grasp protein that bind to ATP-Mg2+ in the pombe ortholog are required for complex assembly in budding yeast; interaction with eIF2 subunit Gcd11p facilitates complex assembly and activity; required for the START transition and timely progression through G2; regulated by nutrient availability; human ortholog complements the yeast mutant
functionSummary: Cytoplasmic protein required for the assembly of translation initiation factor complex, eIF2; regulates translational initiation; proposed to bind ATP-Mg2+ base on structural similarity with the fission yeast ortholog
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; base-substitution mutants have a G2 delay at permissive temperature, a G1 block at elevated temperatures, and are resistant to cycloheximide; reduced function mutants show decreased competitive fitness; overexpression confers resistance to rapamycin

briefDescription: Assembly factor for the F0 sector of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase
description: Assembly factor for the F0 sector of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; mitochondrial inner membrane protein; interacts genetically with ATP6
functionSummary: Protein with a role in assembly of the mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase complex; binds to the unfolded Atp6p subunit during assembly; integral to the mitochondrial inner membrane
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant is incapable of respiratory growth on non-fermentable carbon sources; null mutant also shows decreased rate of vegetative growth ("petite" phenotype), no sporulation, and reduced autophagy

briefDescription: Assembly factor that couples heme a synthesis to complex IV assembly
description: Assembly factor that couples heme a synthesis to complex IV assembly; regulates the oligomerization state of the Cox15p heme a synthase, and couples this to the assembly of the cytochrome C oxidase complex (complex IV)

briefDescription: ATF/CREB family basic leucine zipper (bZIP) transcription factor
description: ATF/CREB family basic leucine zipper (bZIP) transcription factor; binds as a homodimer to the ATF/CREB consensus sequence TGACGTCA; important for carbon source utilization; target genes include GRE2 and COS8; ACA1 has a paralog, CST6, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Sequence-specific DNA-binding RNA polymerase II transcription factor
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies, null mutant shows decreased competitive fitness

description: ATPase and nucleosome spacing factor; subunit of complex containing actin and actin-related proteins that has chromatin remodeling activity and 3' to 5' DNA helicase activity in vitro; promotes nucleosome shifts in the 3 prime direction; has a role in modulating stress gene transcription
functionSummary: Subunit of Ino80 complex, ATPase that contributes to ATP-dependent 3'-5' DNA helicase involved in chromatin remodeling and silencing at telomeres, has a role in transcription from polymerase II promoters
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows inositol auxotrophy, defects in chromosome segregation, decreased growth rate, and inability to utilize ethanol as a carbon source

briefDescription: ATPase component of heat shock protein Hsp90 chaperone complex
description: ATPase component of heat shock protein Hsp90 chaperone complex; serves as nucleotide exchange factor to load ATP onto the SSA class of cytosolic Hsp70s; plays a role in prion propagation and determining prion variants; binds unfolded proteins; member of Hsp110 subclass of HSP70 proteins; deletion results in spindle elongation in S phase; SSE1 has a paralog, SSE2, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Peptide and ATP-binding adenyl-nucleotide exchange factor involved in protein folding and refolding; associates with polysomes
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutation leads to increased loss of [PSI+], [URE3] and [SWI+] prions, reduced growth rate, and elevated sensitivity to hydroxyurea, cycloheximide and hygromycin B; in systematic studies null mutants show abnormally elongated buds, increased frequency of mitotic chromosome loss and elevated sensitivity to azoles, DMSO, myriocin, spermine; overexpression increases resistance to rapamycin

briefDescription: ATPase component of the RSC chromatin remodeling complex
description: ATPase component of the RSC chromatin remodeling complex; required for expression of early meiotic genes; promotes base excision repair in chromatin; essential helicase-related protein homologous to Snf2p

briefDescription: ATPase dedicated chaperone that adapts proteasome assembly to stress
description: ATPase dedicated chaperone that adapts proteasome assembly to stress; Tma17p is induced upon stress; interacts with Rpt6p to assist its pairing to Rpt3p and early steps in proteasome biogenesis; associates with ribosomes; heterozygous deletion demonstrated increases in chromosome instability in a rad9 deletion background; protein abundance is decreased upon intracellular iron depletion

briefDescription: ATPase involved in protein folding and NLS-directed nuclear transport
description: ATPase involved in protein folding and NLS-directed nuclear transport; member of HSP70 family; required for ubiquitin-dependent degradation of short-lived proteins; forms chaperone complex with Ydj1p; localized to nucleus, cytoplasm, cell wall; 98% identical to paralog Ssa2p with different functional specificity in propagation of yeast [URE3] prions, vacuolar-mediated degradations of gluconeogenesis enzymes; general targeting factor of Hsp104p to prion fibrils
functionSummary: ATPase involved in protein folding, nuclear import, stress granule disassembly, and clathrin coat disassembly; localizes to many places in the cell, including the cell wall, vacuolar and plasma membranes, and the nucleus
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; both null and dominant negative mutants have an increased accumulation of prions; overexpression results in larger aggregates in fewer numbers; heterozygous diploid mutant had decreased fitness

briefDescription: ATPase involved in protein folding and the response to stress
description: ATPase involved in protein folding and the response to stress; plays a role in SRP-dependent cotranslational protein-membrane targeting and translocation; member of the heat shock protein 70 (HSP70) family; localized to the cytoplasm; SSA3 has a paralog, SSA4, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: ATPase involved in protein folding

briefDescription: ATPase involved in protein import into the ER
description: ATPase involved in protein import into the ER; also acts as a chaperone to mediate protein folding in the ER and may play a role in ER export of soluble proteins; regulates the unfolded protein response via interaction with Ire1p
functionSummary: ATPase subunit of the lumial surveillance complex that is involved in a number of processes, including translocation of proteins to membranes, the ubiquitin-dependent ERAD pathway, and beta-glucan biosynthesis; localized to the endoplasmic reticulum
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; reduction of function leads to defects in nuclear fusion during mating; overexpression causes slow growth; in systematic studies reduction-of-function mutations increase sensitivity to hydroxyurea and MMS, and increase resistance to myriocin

briefDescription: ATPase of the 19S regulatory particle of the 26S proteasome
description: ATPase of the 19S regulatory particle of the 26S proteasome; one of ATPases of the regulatory particle; involved in the degradation of ubiquitinated substrates; substrate of N-acetyltransferase B
functionSummary: Putative ATPase involved in proteasome regulatory particle assembly; role in ubiquitin-dependent protein degradation, positive regulation of RNA polymerase II transcriptional preinitiation complex assembly; subunit of proteasome regulatory particle, base subcomplex
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; point mutation confers enhanced vegetative growth; rpt3-K219R mutation causes shorter replicative lifespan; in large-scale studies, repression causes sensitivity to HU and shorter telomere length; diploid heterozygous null mutant exhibits reduced competitive fitness and is sensitive to trapoxin A and 3-nitroso-2-phenylimidazo[1,2-a]pyridine

briefDescription: ATPase of the 19S regulatory particle of the 26S proteasome
description: ATPase of the 19S regulatory particle of the 26S proteasome; one of six ATPases of the regulatory particle; involved in degradation of ubiquitinated substrates; contributes preferentially to ERAD; required for spindle pole body duplication; mainly nuclear localization
functionSummary: Putative ATPase involved in proteasome regulatory particle assembly; role in ubiquitin-dependent ERAD pathway, nucleotide-excision repair, positive regulation of RNA polymerase II elongation and transcriptional preinitiation complex assembly; subunit of proteasome regulatory particle, base subcomplex; localizes to nucleus
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; mutations cause resistance to tunicamycin, sensitivity to heat, cycloheximide, and cadmium ions, slow growth, and accumulation of proteasome substrates; in large-scale studies, repression causes abnormal mitochondrial morphology and an Opi- phenotype (overproduction and excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline); diploid heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient and displays enlarged cell size and sensitivity to trapoxin A and 3-nitroso-2-phenylimidazo[1,2-a]pyridine

briefDescription: ATPase of the 19S regulatory particle of the 26S proteasome
description: ATPase of the 19S regulatory particle of the 26S proteasome; one of six ATPases of the regulatory particle; involved in the degradation of ubiquitinated substrates; bound by ubiquitin-protein ligases Ubr1p and Ufd4p; localized mainly to the nucleus throughout the cell cycle; protein abundance increases in response to DNA replication stress
functionSummary: Putative ATPase involved in proteasome regulatory particle assembly; contributes to proteasome-mediated ubiquitin-dependent protein degradation, nonfunctional ribosomal RNA (rRNA) decay; role in nucleotide-excision repair, chromatin repair; also involved in positive regulation of transcription elongation from RNA polymerase II promoter and negative regulation of DNA binding transcription factor activity; subunit of proteasome regulatory particle, base subcomplex; localizes to proteasome storage granule and nucleus
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; cim3-1 ts allele causes arrest with large buds and accumulation of proteasomal substrates at the restrictive temperature; rpt6-K195R mutation in ATPase active site causes decreased replicative lifespan; in large-scale studies, repression confers reduced competitive fitness and chromosome instability, and altered resistance to various chemicals

briefDescription: ATPase of the 19S regulatory particle of the 26S proteasome
description: ATPase of the 19S regulatory particle of the 26S proteasome; one of six ATPases of the regulatory particle; involved in the degradation of ubiquitinated substrates; recruited to the GAL1-10 promoter region upon induction of transcription; similar to human TBP1
functionSummary: Putative ATPase involved in proteasome regulatory particle assembly, ubiquitin-dependent protein degradation and positive regulation of RNA polymerase II transcriptional preinitiation complex assembly; subunit of base complex of proteasome regulatory particle
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; mutations in the ATPase active site cause sensitivity to heat and canavanine, shorter replicative lifespan, slow growth, and increased budding index; in large-scale studies, repression causes reduced competitive fitness, sensitivity to MMS, resistance to myriocin, and shorter telomere length; diploid heterozygous null mutant exhibits enlarged cell size and haploinsufficiency

briefDescription: ATPase of the 19S regulatory particle of the 26S proteasome
description: ATPase of the 19S regulatory particle of the 26S proteasome; one of six ATPases of the regulatory particle; involved in the degradation of ubiquitinated substrates; required for normal peptide hydrolysis by the core 20S particle; N-myristoylation of Rpt2p at Gly2 is involved in regulating the proper intracellular distribution of proteasome activity by controlling the nuclear localization of the 26S proteasome
functionSummary: Proteasome-activating ATPase involved in ubiquitin-dependent protein degradation; has role in nonfunctional ribosomal RNA (rRNA) decay, proteasome regulatory particle assembly, protein complex localization; subunit of proteasome regulatory particle base subcomplex and localizes to nucleus
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; mutations cause slow growth, shorter replicative lifespan, increased budding index, and sensitivity to canavanine and cadmium dichloride; in large-scale studies, repression causes decreased competitive fitness, abnormal mitochondrial morphology, and an Opi- phenotype (overproduction and excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline); diploid heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient and sensitive to dequalinium, and has enlarged cells

briefDescription: ATPase of the 19S regulatory particle of the 26S proteasome
description: ATPase of the 19S regulatory particle of the 26S proteasome; one of six ATPases of the regulatory particle; involved in the degradation of ubiquitinated substrates; required for optimal CDC20 transcription; interacts with Rpn12p and Ubr1p; mutant has aneuploidy tolerance
functionSummary: Putative ATPase involved in proteasome regulatory particle assembly, ubiquitin-dependent protein degradation and positive regulation of RNA polymerase II transcriptional preinitiation complex assembly; subunit of 19S regulatory particle
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; cim5-1 ts allele causes arrest with large buds at restrictive temperature, accumulation of degradation intermediates, and increased resistance to 4-NQO; rpt1-K256S mutation causes shorter replicative lifespan, sensitivity to canavanine, and decreased budding index; in large-scale studies, repression causes decreased competitive fitness; diploid heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient

briefDescription: ATPase of the ATP-binding cassette (ABC) family
description: ATPase of the ATP-binding cassette (ABC) family; involved in 40S and 60S ribosome biogenesis, has similarity to Gcn20p; shuttles from nucleus to cytoplasm, physically interacts with Tif6p, Lsg1p; human homolog ABCF2 can complement yeast ARB1 mutant
functionSummary: ATPase involved in export of small ribosomal subunits from the nucleus and ribosome biogenesis; localizes in nucleus
phenotypeSummary: Null mutants are inviable under standard aerobic conditions, viable but slow-growing under anaerobic conditions; reduced function mutants show decreased competitive fitness

briefDescription: ATPase of the CDC48/PAS1/SEC18 (AAA) family, forms a hexameric complex
description: ATPase of the CDC48/PAS1/SEC18 (AAA) family, forms a hexameric complex; is essential for pre-60S maturation and release of several preribosome maturation factors; releases Rlp24p from purified pre-60S particles in vitro; target of the ribosomal biosynthesis inhibitor diazaborine; may be involved in degradation of aberrant mRNAs
functionSummary: ATPase component of the 66S preribosome involved in ribosomal large subunit biogenesis and assembly
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; repression leads to defects in nuclear export and accumulation of large ribosomal subunits in the nucleus; repression also results in opi- phenotype (overproduction and excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline)

briefDescription: ATPase, putative RNA helicase of the DEAD-box family
description: ATPase, putative RNA helicase of the DEAD-box family; component of 90S preribosome complex involved in production of 18S rRNA and assembly of 40S small ribosomal subunit; ATPase activity stimulated by association with Esf2p
functionSummary: ATP-dependent RNA helicase required for assembly of small ribosomal subunit, involved in endonucleolytic cleavage in the ITS1 that separates small subunit rRNA from tricistronic rRNA transcript; localizes in 90S preribosome in nucleolus
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; repression leads to depletion of mature 18S rRNA and accumulation of 35S pre-rRNA and aberrant rRNA processing intermediates; both dominant negative mutation and overexpression lead to slow vegetative growth

briefDescription: ATPase required for ubiquinone biosynthesis and respiratory growth
description: ATPase required for ubiquinone biosynthesis and respiratory growth; maintains levels of CoQ biosynthetic proteins; binds to CoQ biosynthesis intermediates; UbiB protein kinase-like family member that lacks canonical protein kinase activity; similar to prokaryotic proteins involved in ubiquinone biosynthesis; human homolog ADCK3 complements a coq8 null, is associated with CoQ and respiratory-chain deficiencies, and is mutated in autosomal-recessive cerebellar ataxia type 2
functionSummary: ATPase and lipid binding protein, capable of autophosphorylation but not phosphorylation in trans; involved in ubiquinone biosynthesis; localizes to the matrix face of the inner mitochondrial membrane
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null and point mutants are unable to respire, fail to accumulate ubiquinones, and exhibit sensitivity to linoleic acid; in large-scale studies, null mutant exhibits decreased biofilm formation, increased sulfur accumulation, increased innate thermotolerance, and altered resistance to various chemicals

briefDescription: ATPase subunit of imitation-switch (ISWI) class chromatin remodelers
description: ATPase subunit of imitation-switch (ISWI) class chromatin remodelers; with Ioc3p forms Isw1a complex involved in repression of transcription initiation; with Ioc2p and Ioc4p forms Isw1b complex involved in regulation of transcription elongation; Isw1b recruited to ORFs by H3K36 methylation and acts with Chd1p to prevent trans-histone exchange over coding regions; Isw1p import into nucleus depends on C-terminal bipartite nuclear targeting signal KRIR X19 KKAK
functionSummary: Subunit of the Isw1a and Isw1b complexes; contributes to the ATPase activity, DNA-binding activity, and nucleosome-binding activity of the complexes; also binds to rDNA and transcription regulatory regions; involved in chromatin remodeling and regulation of chromatin organization, nucleosome density, and histone exchange; involved in transcription elongation, regulation of transcriptional start site selection at RNA pol II promoters, positive regulation of transcription from RNA pol II promoters, and termination of RNA pol I and II transcription

description: ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporter; multidrug transporter involved in multiple drug resistance; mediates sterol uptake when sterol biosynthesis is compromised; regulated by Pdr1p; required for anaerobic growth; PDR11 has a paralog, AUS1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: ATPase-coupled transmembrane transporter involved in sterol uptake; localizes to cell periphery

description: ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporter; multidrug transporter involved in the pleiotropic drug resistance network; regulated by Pdr1p and Pdr3p
functionSummary: Putative ABC transporter involved in double-strand break repair via sister chromatid exchange; localizes to puncta at plasma membrane

description: ATP binding cassette protein; cosediments with polysomes and is required for biogenesis of the small ribosomal subunit; Asn/Gln-rich rich region supports [NU+] prion formation and susceptibility to [PSI+] prion induction
ATP-binding protein of unknown function; crystal structure resembles that of E.coli pantothenate kinase and other small kinases; null mutant is sensitive to expression of the top1-T722A allele

briefDescription: ATP-binding protein required for mismatch repair
description: ATP-binding protein required for mismatch repair; required for both mitosis and meiosis; functions as a heterodimer with Mlh1p; binds double- and single-stranded DNA via its N-terminal domain, similar to E. coli MutL
functionSummary: ATPase subunit of MutLalpha complex involved in meiotic mismatch repair
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays mutator phenotype (increased mutation frequency); in large-scale studies null mutant is also sensitive to multiple chemicals, including amitrole, cicloheximide, neomycin, streptomycin, but shows decreased sensitivity to tunicamycin, fluconazole and edelfosine

briefDescription: ATP-binding protein that is a subunit of the HOPS and CORVET complexes
description: ATP-binding protein that is a subunit of the HOPS and CORVET complexes; essential for protein sorting, vesicle docking, and fusion at the vacuole; binds to SNARE domains

ATP (CTP):tRNA-specific tRNA nucleotidyltransferase; different forms targeted to the nucleus, cytosol, and mitochondrion are generated via the use of multiple transcriptional and translational start sites; human homolog TRNT1 complements yeast null mutant
functionSummary: Nucleotidyltransferase that adds 3'-CCA termini to tRNA molecules; localized in mitochondrial matrix
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; base-substitution mutants grow slowly and are sensitive to heat

briefDescription: ATP-dependent 3'-5' RNA helicase of the DExD/H family
description: ATP-dependent 3'-5' RNA helicase of the DExD/H family; involved in nuclear RNA processing and degradation both as a component of TRAMP complex and in TRAMP-independent processes; TRAMP unwinds RNA duplexes, with Mtr4p unwinding activity stimulated by Pap2p/Air2p but not dependent on ongoing polyadenylation; contains an arch domain, with two coiled-coil arms/stalks and a globular fist/KOW domain, which has RNA binding activity and is required for 5.8S rRNA processing
functionSummary: ATP-dependent 3'-5' RNA helicase involved in exonucleolytic trimming of tricistronic pre-ribosomal RNA (rRNA) (SSU-rRNA, 5.8S rRNA, LSU-rRNA) to generate mature 3'-ends of 5.8S transcripts; role in non-coding RNA (ncRNA) polyadenylation, nuclear poly(A)-dependent RNA degradation; contributes to poly(A)-dependent small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA), U4 small nuclear RNA (snRNA), U5 snRNA 3'-end processing; subunit of TRAMP complex
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; depletion leads to accumulation of unprocessed RNA precursors in the nucleus; reduction-of-function mutations cause increased sensitivity to benomyl and nocodazole

briefDescription: ATP-dependent 5' to 3' RNA/DNA and DNA helicase
description: ATP-dependent 5' to 3' RNA/DNA and DNA helicase; subunit of the exosome-associated Nrd1p complex that mediates 3' end formation of snRNAs, snoRNAs, CUTs and some mRNAs; helicase-independent role in transcription-coupled repair; coordinates replication with transcription, associating with moving forks and preventing errors that occur when forks encounter transcribed regions; homolog of Senataxin, implicated in Ataxia-Oculomotor Apraxia 2 and a dominant form of juvenile ALS
functionSummary: ATP-dependent 5 to 3 DNA and RNA/DNA helicase; subunit of the Nrd1 complex (Nrd1p-Nab3p-Sen1p) that mediates 3' end formation of snRNAs, snoRNAs, CUTs and some mRNAs; involved in the regulation of RNA polII transcription in response to DNA damage, maintaining replication fork integrity across RNAPII transcribed genes, and in transcription-coupled nucleotide-excision repair; localizes to both the nucleus and the cytoplasm
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutations cause transcription termination defects that result in accumulation of longer read-through transcripts; reduction-of-function mutations cause sensitivity to hydroxyurea, MMS and rapamycin

description: ATP-dependent DEAD (Asp-Glu-Ala-Asp)-box RNA helicase; required for translation initiation of all yeast mRNAs; binds to mRNA cap-associated factors, and binding stimulates Ded1p RNA-dependent ATPase activity; mutation in human homolog DBY is associated with male infertility; human homolog DDX3X complements ded1 null mutation; DED1 has a paralog, DBP1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Bifunctional enzyme with both RNA strand-annealing and ATP-dependent RNA helicase activities; involved in translation initiation and spliceosomal complex disassembly; localizes to the nucleus, cytoplasm, and cytoplasmic stress granule
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; conditional alleles confer cold sensitivity and slow growth even at permissive temperature; in a large-scale study, mutant exhibits MMS sensitivity

briefDescription: ATP-dependent DNA helicase, also known as pontin
description: ATP-dependent DNA helicase, also known as pontin; member of the AAA+ and RuvB-like protein families; similar to Rvb2p; conserved component of multiple complexes including the INO80 complex, the Swr1 complex, and the R2TP complex (Rvb1-Rvb2-Tah1-Pih1); involved in multiple processes such as chromatin remodeling, box C/D snoRNP assembly, and RNA polymerase II assembly
functionSummary: ATP dependent DNA helicase subunit of the nuclear Ino80 complex involved in chromatin remodeling, snoRNP assembly and regulation of transcription from RNA Pol II

briefDescription: ATP-dependent DNA helicase, also known as reptin
description: ATP-dependent DNA helicase, also known as reptin; member of the AAA+ and RuvB protein families, similar to Rvb1p; conserved component of multiple complexes including the INO80 complex, the Swr1 complex, and the R2TP complex (Rvb1-Rvb2-Tah1-Pih1); involved in multiple processes such as chromatin remodeling, box C/D snoRNP assembly, and RNA polymerase II assembly
functionSummary: ATP dependent DNA helicase subunit of the nuclear Ino80 complex involved in chromatin remodeling, snoRNP assembly and regulation of transcription from RNA Pol II

briefDescription: ATP-dependent DNA translocase involved in chromatin remodeling
description: ATP-dependent DNA translocase involved in chromatin remodeling; ATPase component that, with Itc1p, forms a complex required for repression of a-specific genes, INO1, and early meiotic genes during mitotic growth; the Isw2 complex exhibits basal levels of chromatin binding throughout the genome as well as target-specific chromatin interactions; targeted by Ume6p- and Sua7p-dependent DNA looping to many loci genome-wide
functionSummary: DNA translocase subunit of the CHRAC chromatin accessibility complex involved in chromatin silencing and chromatin remodeling; binds centromeres and single-stranded DNA; involved in negative regulation of antisense RNA transcription

description: ATP-dependent Lon protease; involved in degradation of misfolded proteins in mitochondria; required for biogenesis and maintenance of mitochondria

ATP-dependent RNA helicase; component of the mitochondrial degradosome along with the RNase Dss1p; the degradosome associates with the ribosome and mediates RNA turnover; also required during splicing of the COX1 AI5_beta intron; expression of a processed form of human homolog SUPV3L1 carrying an N-terminal deletion of 46 amino acids rescues yeast suv3 null mutant
functionSummary: ATP-dependent RNA helicase subunit of the mitochondrial degradosome involved in intron-independent turnover and processing of mitochondrial transcripts; also involved in mitochondrial DNA replication
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant fails to respire, exhibits mitochondrial genome instability, and is sensitive to hygromycin B; suv3-1 point mutant fails to respire but maintains the mitochondrial genome; in large-scale studies, null mutant shows small cell size, sensitivity to desiccation, reduced biofilm formation, shorter chronological lifespan, and resistance to miconazole; null mutation in the Sigma1278b genetic background blocks invasive growth and decreases filamentous growth; diploid homozygous null mutant is sensitive to heat and K. lactis zymocin

description: ATP-dependent RNA helicase; involved in the biogenesis of 40S and 60S ribosome subunits; localizes to both the nuclear periphery and nucleolus; highly enriched in nuclear pore complex fractions; constituent of 66S pre-ribosomal particles
functionSummary: An ATP-dependent RNA helicase involved in the maturation of SSU- and LSU-rRNA; localizes to the large subunit precursor preribosome

briefDescription: ATP-dependent RNA helicase of the DEAD-box protein family
description: ATP-dependent RNA helicase of the DEAD-box protein family; has strong preference for dsRNA; interacts with YRA1; required for assembly of Yra1p, Nab2p and Mex67p onto mRNA and formation of nuclear mRNP; involved in mRNA decay and rRNA processing; may be involved in suppression of transcription from cryptic initiation sites
functionSummary: ATP-dependent RNA helicase involved in messenger ribonucleoprotein (mRNP) complex assembly, rRNA processing, and mRNA decay; localizes to the nucleus
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutation confers slow vegetative growth; in a systematic study, null mutant scored as inviable in strain S288C, possibly due to slow growth

briefDescription: ATP-dependent RNA helicase of the SFI superfamily
description: ATP-dependent RNA helicase of the SFI superfamily; involved in nonsense mediated mRNA decay; required for efficient translation termination at nonsense codons and targeting of NMD substrates to P-bodies; binds to the small ribosomal subunit via an interaction with Rps26; forms cytoplasmic foci upon DNA replication stress
functionSummary: ATP-dependent RNA helicase and ATPase that is involved in non-sense mediated mRNA decay, translation termination, protein ubiquitination; localizes to the polyribosomes
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays abnormal localization of proteins and RNAs to P-bodies, increased resistance to copper, and decreased Ty element transposition; in large-scale studies null mutant shows increased resistance to a variety of chemicals, as well as increased sensitivity to some chemicals

description: ATP-NADH kinase; phosphorylates both NAD and NADH; active as a hexamer; enhances the activity of ferric reductase (Fre1p); UTR1 has a paralog, YEF1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: NAD+ and NADH kinase involved in NADP biosynthesis and iron homeostasis; localizes to nucleus and cytoplasm

description: ATP-NADH kinase; phosphorylates both NAD and NADH; homooctameric structure consisting of 60-kDa subunits; similar to Pos5p; overexpression complements certain pos5 phenotypes; YEF1 has a paralog, UTR1, that arose from the whole genome duplication

ATP phosphoribosyltransferase; a hexameric enzyme, catalyzes the first step in histidine biosynthesis; mutations cause histidine auxotrophy and sensitivity to Cu, Co, and Ni salts; transcription is regulated by general amino acid control

ATP sulfurylase; catalyzes the primary step of intracellular sulfate activation, essential for assimilatory reduction of sulfate to sulfide, involved in methionine metabolism; human homolog PAPSS2 complements yeast null mutant
functionSummary: ATP sulfurylase involved in sulfate assimilation and sulfur amino acid metabolism; localizes to the cytoplasm and mitochondrion in high-throughput studies
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays methionine auxotrophy, increased glycogen accumulation, increased competitive fitness, and is unable to use allantoin as a nitrogen source

briefDescription: Aurora kinase of chromosomal passenger complex
description: Aurora kinase of chromosomal passenger complex; mediates release of mono-oriented kinetochores from microtubules in meiosis I, and kinetochore release from SPB clusters at meiotic exit; helps maintain condensed chromosomes during anaphase; required for SPB cohesion and prevention of multipolar spindle formation; promotes telomerase release at G2/M; Iocalizes to nuclear foci that diffuse upon DNA replication stress; required for inhibition of karyopherin Pse1p upon SAC arrest
functionSummary: Protein kinase of the chromosome passenger complex; involved in attachment of spindle microtubules to kinetochore, chromosome segregation, mitotic spindle disassembly and assembly and mitotic DNA integrity checkpoint; localizes to the kinetochore microtubule, nucleus and cytoplasm
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; conditional mutations under restrictive conditions cause defects in chromosome segregation that lead to increased aneuploidy

briefDescription: Autophagy receptor with a role in degradation of the ER and nucleus
description: Autophagy receptor with a role in degradation of the ER and nucleus; involved specifically in autophagy of perinuclear endoplasmic reticulum in response to nitrogen starvation or rapamycin treatment; localizes to the perinuclear ER
functionSummary: Protein involved in autophagic degradation of the nucleus and endoplasmic reticulum in response to nitrogen starvation; binds to Atg8p during autophagy; localized to the perinuclear ER

briefDescription: Autophagy receptor with a role in endoplasmic reticulum degradation
description: Autophagy receptor with a role in endoplasmic reticulum degradation; involved specifically in autophagy of cortical and cytoplasmic ER in response to nitrogen starvation or rapamycin treatment; localizes to the cortical and cytoplasmic ER; similar to human FAM134B, which is also involved in ER autophagy and is associated with sensory neuropathy
functionSummary: Protein involved in autophagic degradation of the endoplasmic reticulum in response to nitrogen starvation; binds to Atg8p during autophagy; localized to the cortical ER

briefDescription: Autophagy-related protein and dual specificity member of the E1 family
description: Autophagy-related protein and dual specificity member of the E1 family; mediates the attachment of Atg12p to Atg5p and Atg8p to phosphatidylethanolamine which are required steps in autophagosome formation; E1 enzymes are also known as ubiquitin-activating enzymes; involved in methionine restriction extension of chronological lifespan in an autophagy-dependent manner
functionSummary: Atg8 and Atg12 activating enzyme; involved in macroautophagy, cytoplasm-to-vacuole targeting (CVT) pathway, late nucleophagy, piecemeal microautophagy of nucleus, protein lipidation and mitochondrion degradation; localizes to the pre-autophagosomal structure (PAS) and mitochondrion
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; reduction of function mutant is unable to undergo autophagy and the CVT pathway; null mutant is unable to undergo late nucleophagy and pexophagy, and displays reduced mitophagy and micronucleophagy; null mutant has decreased viability during nitrogen starvation and abnormal nuclear morphology; null mutant is unable to localize Atg8p to the PAS; chronological lifespan is decreased in minimal medium but extended during growth in rich conditions; null mutant is defective in starvation-induced protein degradation; null mutant displays decreased glycogen accumulation during stationary phase; null mutant has decreased desiccation resistance, decreased resistance to zinc treatment and increased survival following a ramped heat stimulus; homozygous diploid null mutant is unable to sporulate; overexpression results in decreased filamentous growth

description: Autophagy-specific protein; required for recruiting other ATG proteins to the pre-autophagosomal structure (PAS); interacts with Atg17p and localizas to the PAS in a manner interdependent with Atg17p and Cis1p; not conserved; relocalizes from nucleus to cytoplasmic foci upon DNA replication stress
functionSummary: SNARE-binding subunit of Atg1/ULK1 kinase complex involved in autophagosome formation; also involved in macroautophagy, mitophagy, piecemeal microautophagy of nucleus, and late nucleophagy; localizes to phagophore assembly site, cytoplasm, and nucleus
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant is unable to undergo autophagy, and displays decreased mitophagy, micronucleophagy and late nucleophagy; null mutant displays decreased viability during nitrogen starvation and abnormal nuclear morphology; null mutant displays enhanced competitive fitness on minimal and ethanol-containing media; null mutant displays a reduced growth rate for newly germinated spores; null mutant has decreased resistance to zinc treatment; homozygous diploid null mutant displays decreased sporulation and heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient; overexpression results in decreased filamentous growth

briefDescription: Autophagy-specific protein required for autophagosome formation
description: Autophagy-specific protein required for autophagosome formation; forms a complex with Atg17p and Atg29p that localizes other proteins to the pre-autophagosomal structure; constitutively phosphorylated, and phosphorylation of residue S174 is required for function; high-copy suppressor of CIK1 deletion
functionSummary: Protein involved in autophagy, late nucleophagy, mitochondrion degradation and piecemeal microautophagy of nucleus; localizes to the  pre-autophagosomal structure
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant is unable to undergo autophagy, late nucleophagy, displays reduced mitophagy, and defective micronucleophagy, but has a normal CVT pathway; null mutant displays decreased viability during nitrogen starvation and abnormal nuclear morphology; null mutant has decreased resistance to zinc treatment and reduced desiccation resistance; homozygous diploid null displays a reduction in sporulation efficiency

briefDescription: Autophagy-specific subunit of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase complex I
description: Autophagy-specific subunit of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase complex I; Atg14p targets complex I to the phagophore assembly site (PAS); required for localizing additional ATG proteins to the PAS; required for overflow degradation of misfolded proteins when ERAD is saturated; homolog of human Barkor; other members are Vps34, Vps15, and Vps30p
functionSummary: Subunit of the  phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase complex I involved in macroautophagy, cytoplasm-to-vacuole targeting (CVT) pathway, peroxisome degradation, piecemeal microautophagy of nucleus; also localizes to the pre-autophagosomal structure (PAS)
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows no autophagy, increased sensitivity to nitrogen starvation and is unable to sporulate

description: Autoregulatory, oleate-activated transcription factor; subunit of a heterodimeric complex with Oaf1p, which binds to oleate-response elements (ORE) in the promoter of genes involved in beta-oxidation of fatty acids, peroxisome organization and biogenesis, activating transcription in the presence of oleate; PIP2 has a paralog, OAF1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Subunit of the heterodimeric Pip2-Oaf1 complex, which binds to promoter proximal elements upstream of genes involved in peroxisomal proliferation, functioning as a transcriptional activator in the presence of oleate

briefDescription: Auxilin-like protein involved in vesicular transport
description: Auxilin-like protein involved in vesicular transport; clathrin-binding protein required for uncoating of clathrin-coated vesicles
Bacterially-derived sulfatase; required for use of alkyl- and aryl-sulfates as sulfur sources
functionSummary: Sulfuric ester hydrolase involved in dodecyl sulfate metabolism
phenotypeSummary: Null mutant is unable to grow on media containing alkyl or aryl-sulfates as sulfur source; Null mutant is heat sensitive; null mutant displays increased competitive fitness in conditions that mimic Phase I of a batch fermentation

briefDescription: BAR domain protein that localizes to early and late Golgi vesicles
description: BAR domain protein that localizes to early and late Golgi vesicles; required for adaptation to varying nutrient concentrations, fluid-phase endocytosis, polarization of the actin cytoskeleton, and vacuole biogenesis

Basic helix-loop-helix (bHLH) protein; forms homodimer to bind E-box consensus sequence CACGTG present at MET gene promoters and centromere DNA element I (CDEI); affects nucleosome positioning at this motif; associates with other transcription factors such as Met4p and Isw1p to mediate transcriptional activation or repression; associates with kinetochore proteins, required for chromosome segregation; protein abundance increases in response to DNA replication stress
functionSummary: Sequence specific DNA-binding RNA polymerase II transcription activator and repressor; subunit of the Cbf1-Met4-Met28 complex; activates transcription of genes involved in inositol biosynthetic process and sulfate assimilation and represses transcription of genes involved in ceramide biosynthetic process; localized to the mitochondrion in high-throughput studies
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant grows slowly, has abnormal vacuolar morphology, impaired fitness, cannot utilize allantoin as a nitrogen source, shows decreased Ty1 mobility, is sensitive to various antibiotics, auxotrophic for methionine, heat-resistant, and accumulates glycogen; overexpression causes abnormal nuclear morphology, accumulation of cells with 2C DNA content, increased percentage of large-budded cells, and increases resistance to TOR inhibitor rapamycin

briefDescription: Basic helix-loop-helix (bHLH) transcription factor of the myc-family
description: Basic helix-loop-helix (bHLH) transcription factor of the myc-family; activates transcription cooperatively with Pho2p in response to phosphate limitation; binding to 'CACGTG' motif is regulated by chromatin restriction, competitive binding of Cbf1p to the same DNA binding motif and cooperation with Pho2p; function is regulated by phosphorylation at multiple sites and by phosphate availability
functionSummary: Sequence specific DNA-binding RNA polymerase II transcription factor that activates expression of genes involved in the response to phosphate starvation such as PHO5; relocates to the nucleus during phosphate starvation
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits reduced acid phosphatase activity in low-inorganic phosphate medium and is resistant to quinine but sensitive to disodium selenite; overexpression causes morphological and cell cycle defects; in large-scale studies, null mutant displays a strong growth defect in low-phosphate medium, slow respiratory growth, and sensitivity to alkaline pH and anoxia

briefDescription: Basic leucine zipper (bZIP) iron-sensing transcription factor
description: Basic leucine zipper (bZIP) iron-sensing transcription factor; involved in diauxic shift; YAP5 has a paralog, YAP7, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Sequence-specific DNA binding transcription factor involved in the regulation of transcription by RNA polymerase II in response to iron; also involved in the regulation of telomeric chromatin silencing
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants exhibit increased fitness and resistance to antimalarial quinine, abnormal vacuolar morphology, impaired filamentous growth and use of various nitrogen sources; homozygous diploid nulls are sensitive to preservative sorbate and heat shock; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient; overexpression increases filamentous growth

description: Basic leucine zipper (bZIP) transcription factor
functionSummary: Sequence-specific DNA binding transcription factor involved in the regulation of transcription by RNA polymerase II
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null exhibits abnormal growth and vacuolar morphology, decreased resistance hyperosmotic stress, decreased fitness in alkaline pH; null shows increased resistance to acid and DNA-damaging agents; overexpression confers resistance to TOR inhibitor rapamycin; homozygous diploid null has increased cell size, accumulates glycogen, is sensitive to zinc, caffeine, heat, dessication, rapamycin, and glycosylation inhibitor tunicamycin

description: Basic leucine zipper (bZIP) transcription factor; physically interacts with the Tup1-Cyc8 complex and recruits Tup1p to its targets; overexpression increases sodium and lithium tolerance; computational analysis suggests a role in regulation of expression of genes involved in carbohydrate metabolism; YAP6 has a paralog, CIN5, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Sequence-specific DNA-binding transcription factor that recruits the Cyc1/Tup1 transcriptional repressor complex to RNA polymerase II promoters to downregulate transcription
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; overexpression impairs growth, increases filamentous growth, and decreases sensitivity to DNA-damaging agents; haploid null mutants show decreased competitive fitness and increased respiratory fitness; heterozygous diploid null are haploinsufficient and sensitive to DNA synthesis inhibitor methotrexate

description: Basic leucine zipper (bZIP) transcription factor; required for oxidative stress tolerance; activated by H2O2 through the multistep formation of disulfide bonds and transit from the cytoplasm to the nucleus; Yap1p is degraded in the nucleus after the oxidative stress has passed; mediates resistance to cadmium; relative distribution to the nucleus increases upon DNA replication stress; YAP1 has a paralog, CAD1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Sequence-specific DNA-binding transcription factor involved in the regulation of transcription in response to various stresses and cellular insults; shuttles between nucleus and cytoplasm
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant show increased mutation frequency, decreased lifespan, decreased ethanol tolerance, decreased resistance to dessication, alkaline pH, resveratrol, oxidizing and reducing agents, carcinogens, antifungals, alkylating agents, metals, DNA metabolism inhibitors, protein and sterol synthesis inhibitors, and TOR inhibitor rapamycin; overexpression increases filamentous growth in Sigma1278b, interferes with cell cycle progression in S288C, and confers resistance to many of the aforementioned chemicals

briefDescription: Basic leucine zipper (bZIP) transcription factor (ATF/CREB1 homolog)
description: Basic leucine zipper (bZIP) transcription factor (ATF/CREB1 homolog); regulates the unfolded protein response, via UPRE binding, and membrane biogenesis; ER stress-induced splicing pathway facilitates efficient Hac1p synthesis; two functional forms of Hac1p are produced; translation initiation is repressed under non-stress conditions; protein abundance increases in response to DNA replication stress
functionSummary: Sequence-specific DNA-binding RNA polymerase II transcription factor involved in regulation of the unfolded protein response; also negatively regulates transcription during meiosis
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow slowly, have decreased ethanol tolerance, are extremely sensitive to glycosylation inhibitor tunicamycin, show increased [PSI+] prion formation, are sensitive to Huntingtin, heat, zinc deficiency, and are auxotrophic for inositols; overexpression interferes with cell cycle progression and cytoskeleton morphology; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient

briefDescription: Basic leucine zipper (bZIP) transcription factor from ATF/CREB family
description: Basic leucine zipper (bZIP) transcription factor from ATF/CREB family involved in stress-responsive regulatory network; mediates transcriptional activation of NCE103 in response to low CO2 levels; proposed to be a regulator of oleate responsive genes; involved in utilization of non-optimal carbon sources and chromosome stability; relocalizes to the cytosol in response to hypoxia; CST6 has a paralog, ACA1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Sequence-specific DNA binding RNA polymerase II transcription factor involved in the cellular responses to carbon dioxide and oleic acid
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant is slow-growing and cold-sensitive, also displays increased sensitivity to oxidative stress and ethanol, but increased resistance to benomyl; overexpression results in elevated mitotic recombination; in systematic studies mutants exhibit reduced competitive fitness

briefDescription: Basic leucine zipper (bZIP) transcription factor of the yAP-1 family
description: Basic leucine zipper (bZIP) transcription factor of the yAP-1 family; physically interacts with the Tup1-Cyc8 complex and recruits Tup1p to its targets; mediates pleiotropic drug resistance and salt tolerance; nuclearly localized under oxidative stress and sequestered in the cytoplasm by Lot6p under reducing conditions; CIN5 has a paralog, YAP6, that arose from the whole genome duplication
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; overexpression elevates resistance to MMS, mitomycin C and cisplatin; in systematic studies null mutants show increased competitive fitness and increased accumulation of alpha amino acids

briefDescription: Basic leucine zipper transcription factor of the ATF/CREB family
description: Basic leucine zipper transcription factor of the ATF/CREB family; forms a complex with Tup1p and Cyc8p to both activate and repress transcription; cytosolic and nuclear protein involved in osmotic and oxidative stress responses
Basic zinc-finger protein; similar to human and mouse Kin17 proteins which are chromatin-associated proteins involved in UV response and DNA replication
functionSummary: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the nucleus and cytoplasm in a large-scale study

description: Beta-1,3-glucanosyltransferase; required for cell wall assembly and also has a role in transcriptional silencing; localizes to cell surface via a glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor; also found at nuclear periphery; genetic interactions with histone H3 lysine acetyltransferases GCN5 and SAS3 indicate previously unsuspected functions for Gas1 in DNA damage response and cell cycle regulation
functionSummary: 1,3-beta-glucanosyltransferase, catalyzes splitting and linking of (1->3)-beta-D-glucan molecules that leads to elongation of (1->3)-beta-D-glucan chains; involved in cell wall organization, also has a role in chromatin silencing; localized to cell wall, nuclear periphery and throughout secretory pathway
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutation confers cell wall defects, decreased growth rate, abnormal vacuolar morphology and pheromone sensitivity; null mutatnt is incapable of filamentous growth

description: Beta 1 subunit of the 20S proteasome; responsible for cleavage after acidic residues in peptides

Beta 2 subunit of the 20S proteasome; endopeptidase with trypsin-like activity that cleaves after basic residues; synthesized as a proprotein before being proteolytically processed for assembly into 20S particle; human homolog is subunit Z

briefDescription: Beta3-like subunit of the yeast AP-3 complex
description: Beta3-like subunit of the yeast AP-3 complex; functions in transport of alkaline phosphatase to the vacuole via the alternate pathway; exists in both cytosolic and peripherally associated membrane-bound pools
functionSummary: Subunit of the AP-3 adaptor complex that functions in golgi to vacuole transport
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows defects in vacuolar protein transport, increased accumulation of polyphospahates and increased excretion of inositol; null mutant also shows increased sensitivity to caffeine and caspofungin, but increased resistance to fenpropimorph, mycophenolic acid, rapamycin and tunicamycin

description: Beta 3 subunit of the 20S proteasome; involved in ubiquitin-dependent catabolism; human homolog is subunit C10
functionSummary: Endopeptidase activator involved in ubiquitin-independent and ubiquitin-dependent proteasome-mediated protein degradation; beta-type subunit of 20S proteasome
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; overexpression has negative impact on chromosome stability; in Sigma1278b overexpression enhances pseudohyphal invasive growth

description: Beta 4 subunit of the 20S proteasome; localizes to the nucleus throughout the cell cycle
functionSummary: Endopeptidase activator involved in proteasomal ubiquitin-independent and ubiquitin-dependent protein degradation; localizes to endoplasmic reticulum membrane, nucleus, proteasome storage granules
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutations cause accumulation of ubiquitin conjugates and lead to elevated sensitivity to bleomycin and hydroxyurea, increased resistance to cicloheximide, and inability to sporulate in diploids; in large-scale studies repressible or conditional mutations result in cell cycle arrest at the G2 phase, increased chromosomal instability and defects in cytokinesis

description: Beta 5 subunit of the 20S proteasome; responsible for the chymotryptic activity of the proteasome
Beta 6 subunit of the 20S proteasome
Beta 7 subunit of the 20S proteasome
Beta-adaptin; large subunit of the clathrin associated protein complex (AP-2); involved in vesicle mediated transport; similar to mammalian beta-chain of the clathrin associated protein complex
functionSummary: Subunit of the AP-2 adaptor complex that functions in vesicle mediated transport
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness; in diploid homozygous null mutation increases frequency of mitotic chromosome loss

briefDescription: Beta-adaptin subunit of the clathrin-associated protein (AP-1) complex
description: Beta-adaptin subunit of the clathrin-associated protein (AP-1) complex; binds clathrin; involved in clathrin-dependent Golgi protein sorting; protein abundance increases in response to DNA replication stress
functionSummary: Subunit of the AP-1 adaptor complex that binds clathrin and functions in vesicle  mediated transport
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant is defective in vacuolar protein transport and shows strong vacuolar fragmentation; null mutant is also sensitive to Congo Red, arsenite, mefloquine, monensin A and rapamycin

description: Beta-isopropylmalate dehydrogenase (IMDH); catalyzes the third step in the leucine biosynthesis pathway; can additionally catalyze the conversion of beta-ethylmalate into alpha-ketovalerate
functionSummary: Beta-isopropylmalate dehydrogenase involved in leucine biosynthesis and the glyoxylate cycle; catalyzes the conversion of beta-isopropylmalate to alpha-ketoisocaproate; localizes to the cytosol
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant requires leucine for growth and is sensitive to acetic acid; overexpression confers increased acetic acid resistance

briefDescription: Beta-lyase involved in the production of thiols
description: Beta-lyase involved in the production of thiols; null mutant displays increased levels of spontaneous Rad52p foci; expression induced by nitrogen limitation in a GLN3, GAT1-dependent manner and by copper levels in a Mac1-dependent manner
functionSummary: Cysteine-S-conjugate beta-lyase involved in sulfur metabolism and L-cysteine catabolism

briefDescription: Beta regulatory subunit of casein kinase 2 (CK2)
description: Beta regulatory subunit of casein kinase 2 (CK2); a Ser/Thr protein kinase with roles in cell growth and proliferation; CK2, comprised of CKA1, CKA2, CKB1 and CKB2, has many substrates including transcription factors and all RNA polymerases
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to ionic stress, also shows increased sensitivity to rapamycin and nicotinamide, and accumulates triglycerides; in systematic studies mutants are sensitive to multiple chemicals, including caffeine, MMS, DMSO, doxorubicin, dieldrin, chlorpromazine, fenpropimorph, paromomycin

briefDescription: Beta' regulatory subunit of casein kinase 2 (CK2)
description: Beta' regulatory subunit of casein kinase 2 (CK2); a Ser/Thr protein kinase with roles in cell growth and proliferation; CK2, comprised of CKA1, CKA2, CKB1 and CKB2, has many substrates including transcription factors and all RNA polymerase
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutation confers decreased resistance to ionic stress and rapamycin; in systematic studies mutants show decreased competitive fitness and increased sensitivity to multiple chemicals, including doxorubicin, dieldrin, chlorpromazine, fenpropimorph, and others; mutants also show opi- phenotype (overproduction and excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline) and accumulate altered levels of free amino acids; overproduction in diploid Sigma1278b cells increases invasive growth

briefDescription: Beta subunit of C-terminal domain kinase I (CTDK-I)
description: Beta subunit of C-terminal domain kinase I (CTDK-I); which phosphorylates both RNA pol II subunit Rpo21p to affect transcription and pre-mRNA 3' end processing, and ribosomal protein Rps2p to increase translational fidelity; relocalizes to the cytosol in response to hypoxia
functionSummary: Subunit of the C-terminal Domain Kinase I (CTDK-I) complex that acts as a positive transcription elongation regulator; localized to the nucleus
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays elevated frequency of chromosome loss and abnormally elongated buds; in systematic studies null mutation confers increased sensitivity to oxidative stress and several drugs, including hygromycin B and caspofungin; null mutants also have slow growth rate and increased cell size

briefDescription: Beta subunit of cytoplasmic phenylalanyl-tRNA synthetase
description: Beta subunit of cytoplasmic phenylalanyl-tRNA synthetase; forms a tetramer with Frs2p to generate active enzyme; able to hydrolyze mis-aminoacylated tRNA-Phe, which could contribute to translational quality control

briefDescription: Beta subunit of fatty acid synthetase
description: Beta subunit of fatty acid synthetase; complex catalyzes the synthesis of long-chain saturated fatty acids; contains acetyltransacylase, dehydratase, enoyl reductase, malonyl transacylase, and palmitoyl transacylase activities
functionSummary: Subunit of cytoplasmic fatty acid synthase, contributes acetyltransacylase, dehydratase, enoyl reductase, malonyl transacylase, and palmitoyl transacylase activities; required for long-chain fatty acid biosynthesis
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; null mutant is rescuable by fatty acid supplement; heterozygous diploid accumulates very long-chain fatty acids

briefDescription: Beta subunit of geranylgeranyltransferase type I
description: Beta subunit of geranylgeranyltransferase type I; subunit of the Ram2p-Cdc43p heterodimer that catalyzes the geranylgeranylation of the cysteine residue in proteins containing a C-terminal CaaX sequence ending in Leu or Phe; has substrates important for morphogenesis

Beta subunit of heterooctameric phosphofructokinase; involved in glycolysis; indispensable for anaerobic growth; activated by fructose-2,6-bisphosphate and AMP; mutation inhibits glucose induction of cell cycle-related genes
functionSummary: Subunit of 6-phosphofructokinase complex involved in glycolysis; localizes in mitochondria
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; reduction of function prevents growth under anaerobic conditions; null mutant is blocked in glycolysis and shows decreased rate of both respiratory and fermentative growth, increased heat sensitivity, lower survival in stationary phase and decreased competitive fitness

briefDescription: Beta subunit of Sec61p ER translocation complex (Sec61p-Sss1p-Sbh1p)
description: Beta subunit of Sec61p ER translocation complex (Sec61p-Sss1p-Sbh1p); involved in protein translocation into the endoplasmic reticulum; interacts with the exocyst complex and also with Rtn1p; cotranslationally N-acetylated by NatA; SBH1 has a paralog, SBH2, that arose from the whole genome duplication
Beta subunit of succinyl-CoA ligase; succinyl-CoA ligase is a mitochondrial enzyme of the TCA cycle that catalyzes the nucleotide-dependent conversion of succinyl-CoA to succinate

briefDescription: Beta subunit of the CAAX farnesyltransferase (FTase)
description: Beta subunit of the CAAX farnesyltransferase (FTase); this complex prenylates the a-factor mating pheromone and Ras proteins; required for the membrane localization of Ras proteins and a-factor; homolog of the mammalian FTase beta subunit

briefDescription: Beta subunit of the capping protein heterodimer (Cap1p and Cap2p)
description: Beta subunit of the capping protein heterodimer (Cap1p and Cap2p); capping protein (CP) binds to the barbed ends of actin filaments preventing further polymerization; localized predominantly to cortical actin patches; protein increases in abundance and relocalizes from bud neck to plasma membrane upon DNA replication stress
functionSummary: Actin filament binding protein involved in barbed-end actin filament capping and filamentous growth; localizes to many sites within the cell including incipient bud site, bud tip, mating projection tip, and actin cortical patches; subunit of F-actin capping protein complex
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant is heat sensitive, has a large cell size, and decreased competitive fitness in both rich and minimal media; null mutant has an increased frequency of spontaneous mitochondrial genome loss; null mutant has severe short-chain alcohol and hydroxyurea-induced filamentous growth defects and an inability to undergo pseudohypal growth upon nitrogen starvation; null mutant has an endocytosis defect and decreased hyperosmotic stress resistance; null mutant has a nuclear migration defect; null mutant displays abnormal localization of both actin and chitin

briefDescription: Beta subunit of the F1 sector of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase
description: Beta subunit of the F1 sector of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; which is a large, evolutionarily conserved enzyme complex required for ATP synthesis; F1 translationally regulates ATP6 and ATP8 expression to achieve a balanced output of ATP synthase genes encoded in nucleus and mitochondria; phosphorylated
functionSummary: Subunit of the catalytic core of the F1 sector of mitochondrial F1F0 ATP synthase; ATP synthase complex is localized to the mitochondrial inner membrane
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene, but heterozygous diploid shows haploinsufficiency; null mutant is temperature sensitive, petite-negative, has a decreased rate of survival in stationary phase, a glycogen accumulation defect, decreased starvation resistance, a respiratory growth defect and decreased resistance to desiccation and oxidative stress; null mutant has a competitive fitness defect in various media and abnormal mitochondrial and vacuolar morphologies

briefDescription: Beta subunit of the mitochondrial processing protease (MPP)
description: Beta subunit of the mitochondrial processing protease (MPP); essential processing enzyme that cleaves the N-terminal targeting sequences from mitochondrially imported proteins

briefDescription: Beta subunit of the oligosaccharyl transferase glycoprotein complex
description: Beta subunit of the oligosaccharyl transferase glycoprotein complex; required for N-linked glycosylation of proteins in the endoplasmic reticulum; human homolog DDOST can complement yeast growth defect during down-regulation of yeast gene
functionSummary: Protein subunit of oligosaccharyltransferase complex that transfers lipid-linked oligosaccharide precursor to asparagine residues on nascent proteins; localizes to endoplasmic reticulum membrane and nuclear envelope
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; ts mutant displays under-glycosylation of carboxypeptidase Y at the permissive temperature and increased apoptosis at restrictive temperature; mutant is sensitive to hygromycin B; in large-scale studies, repression confers decreased competitive fitness, increased frequency of chromosomal rearrangements and loss, and sensitivity to MMS

briefDescription: Beta subunit of the translation initiation factor eIF2
description: Beta subunit of the translation initiation factor eIF2; involved in the identification of the start codon; proposed to be involved in mRNA binding

briefDescription: Beta subunit of the translation initiation factor eIF2B
description: Beta subunit of the translation initiation factor eIF2B; the guanine-nucleotide exchange factor for eIF2; activity subsequently regulated by phosphorylated eIF2; first identified as a negative regulator of GCN4 expression; human homolog EIF2B2 can complement yeast mutant, allows growth down-regulation of yeast gene
functionSummary: Enzyme regulator subunit of eukaryotic translation initiation factor 2B complex and guanyl-nucleotide exchange factor complex; involved in regulation of translational initiation; localizes to mitochondrion and cytosol in high-throughput studies
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; conditional mutants are defective in autophagy and in Golgi localization of reporter proteins; haploproficient but sensitive to starvation and oxidative stress

briefDescription: Beta subunit of Type II geranylgeranyltransferase
description: Beta subunit of Type II geranylgeranyltransferase; required for vesicular transport between the endoplasmic reticulum and the Golgi; provides a membrane attachment moiety to Rab-like proteins Ypt1p and Sec4p; human homolog RABGGTB can complement yeast BET2 mutant
functionSummary: Subunit of Rab-protein geranylgeranyltransferase complex which attaches geranylgeranyl moiety to proteins; required for vesicle-mediated transport between ER and Golgi; the complex localizes in cytoplasm
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; conditional mutants are impaired in protein transport; reduced function mutants show decreased competitive fitness, are sensitive to DNA-damaging agent hydroxyurea (HU); heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient

description: Beta-tubulin; associates with alpha-tubulin (Tub1p and Tub3p) to form tubulin dimer, which polymerizes to form microtubules; mutation in human ortholog is associated with congenital fibrosis of the extraocular muscles (CFEOM) with polymicrogyria
functionSummary: Tubulin complex subunit; involved in homologous chromosome segregation, mitotic sister chromatid segregation, and microtubule-mediated transport of the nucleus
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; heterozygous diploid null mutants have unstable chromosomes and are sensitive to cancer drugs; some conditional mutants are resistant to microtubule-destabilizing agent benomyl but senstive to heat, and undergo cell-cycle arrest as large-budded cells; overexpression interferes with mitotis and slows growth in some strain backgrouds, is lethal in others; cells heterozygous for a reduced function allele analogous to human mutation associated with congenital fibrosis of the extraocular muscles (CFEOM) are sensitive to benomyl

briefDescription: bHLH protein with similarity to myc-family transcription factors
description: bHLH protein with similarity to myc-family transcription factors; overexpression confers hyperfilamentous growth and suppresses the pseudohyphal filamentation defect of a diploid mep1 mep2 homozygous null mutant

briefDescription: bHLH/Zip transcription factor for retrograde (RTG) and TOR pathways
description: bHLH/Zip transcription factor for retrograde (RTG) and TOR pathways; forms a complex with another bHLH/Zip protein, Rtg1p, to activate the pathways; target of Hog1p
functionSummary: Sequence-specific DNA-binding RNA polymerase II transcription factor involved in mitophagy and the induction of genes of the retrograde response pathway; localizes to both the nucleus and cytoplasm

briefDescription: Bifunctional alcohol dehydrogenase and formaldehyde dehydrogenase
description: Bifunctional alcohol dehydrogenase and formaldehyde dehydrogenase; formaldehyde dehydrogenase activity is glutathione-dependent; functions in formaldehyde detoxification and formation of long chain and complex alcohols, regulated by Hog1p-Sko1p; protein abundance increases in response to DNA replication stress

Bifunctional carbamoylphosphate synthetase/aspartate transcarbamylase; catalyzes the first two enzymatic steps in the de novo biosynthesis of pyrimidines; both activities are subject to feedback inhibition by UTP

briefDescription: Bifunctional chorismate synthase and flavin reductase
description: Bifunctional chorismate synthase and flavin reductase; catalyzes the conversion of 5-enolpyruvylshikimate 3-phosphate (EPSP) to form chorismate, which is a precursor to aromatic amino acids; protein abundance increases in response to DNA replication stress
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to 2-phenylethanol, shows auxotrophy for phenylalanine, tyrosine and tryptophan and sensitivity to cadmium; null mutant shows no mitophagy; in large-scale studies null mutants show decreased fermentative growth, increased sensitivity to hyperosmotic stress and to multiple chemicals, including MMS, acetic acid, cycloheximide, hydroxyurea, ethanol, bleomycin, azoles, colistin, cordycepin, streptomycin, tunicamycin

description: Bifunctional dehydrogenase and ferrochelatase; involved in the biosynthesis of siroheme, a prosthetic group used by sulfite reductase; required for sulfate assimilation and methionine biosynthesis

Bifunctional DRAP deaminase tRNA:pseudouridine synthase; the deaminase catalyzes the third step in riboflavin biosynthesis and the synthase catalyzes formation of pseudouridine at position 32 in cytoplasmic tRNAs; RIB2 has a paralog, PUS9, that arose from the whole genome duplication

Bifunctional HMG aldolase/oxaloacetate decarboxylase; requires divalent metal ions for activity; competitively inhibited by oxalate; forms a ring-shaped homotrimer; similar to members of the prokaryotic RraA family of class II (divalent metal ion dependent) pyruvate aldolases from the meta cleavage pathways of protocatechuate and gallate

briefDescription: Bifunctional inositol pyrophosphate kinase and phosphatase
description: Bifunctional inositol pyrophosphate kinase and phosphatase; contains an N-terminal PP-InsP kinase domain that phosphorylates inositol hexakisphosphate and heptakisphosphate, and a C-terminal phosphatase domain that hydrolyzes both 1PP-InsP5 and 5PP-InsP5; IP7 levels decrease during starvation, suggesting a role for PP-InsP enzymes in Pi homeostasis; may regulate the dimorphic switch and the function of the cortical actin cytoskeleton
functionSummary: Bifunctional cytosolic inositol hexakisphosphate kinase involved in inositol phosphate biosynthesis and inositol pyrophosphate (PP-IP) dephosphorylation of IP7

briefDescription: Bifunctional triacylglycerol lipase and 1-acyl DHAP reductase
description: Bifunctional triacylglycerol lipase and 1-acyl DHAP reductase; NADPH-dependent 1-acyl dihydroxyacetone phosphate reductase involved in phosphatidic acid biosynthesis; lipid droplet triacylglycerol lipase involved in the mobilization of non-polar lipids; found in lipid particles, the endoplasmic reticulum and the mitochondrial outer membrane; required for spore germination; role in cell wall biosynthesis; capable of metabolizing steroid hormones; oleic acid inducible
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a decrease in both vegetative and respiratory growth rate; null mutant fails to germinate after sporulation; null mutant contains elongated buds; null mutant displays a defect in delivery of the cell surface marker, Fus-Mid-GFP, with late Golgi accumulation; null mutant has decreased resistance to hyperosmotic stress; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient; overexpression results in growth arrest

briefDescription: Bifunctional triacylglycerol lipase and LPA acyltransferase
description: Bifunctional triacylglycerol lipase and LPA acyltransferase; lipid particle-localized triacylglycerol (TAG) lipase involved in triacylglycerol mobilization; catalyzes acylation of lysophosphatidic acid (LPA); potential Cdc28p substrate; TGL5 has a paralog, TGL4, that arose from the whole genome duplication

briefDescription: Bifunctional triacylglycerol lipase and LPE acyltransferase
description: Bifunctional triacylglycerol lipase and LPE acyltransferase; major lipid particle-localized triacylglycerol (TAG) lipase; catalyzes acylation of lysophosphatidylethanolamine (LPE), a function which is essential for sporulation; protein level and stability of Tgl3p are markedly reduced in the absence of lipid droplets; required with Tgl4p for timely bud formation

briefDescription: Bifunctional triacylglycerol lipase and short chain ester hydrolase
