description: Bifunctional triacylglycerol lipase and short chain ester hydrolase; null mutant results in the accumulation of both triacylglycerol and fatty acids derived from neutral lipids and phospholipids as well as an increase in the quantity of lipid droplets; contains an alpha/beta hydrolase domain with a conserved GXSXG lipase motif; localizes to lipid droplets; GFP-fusion protein localizes to the cytoplasm and is induced in response to the DNA-damaging agent MMS
functionSummary: Bifunctional triacylglycerol lipase and short chain ester hydrolase; localizes to the cytoplasm and lipid particles in different large-scale studies

description: Biotin:apoprotein ligase; covalently modifies proteins with the addition of biotin, required for acetyl-CoA carboxylase (Acc1p) holoenzyme formation; comparative analysis suggests that a mitochondrially targeted form may result from translation starting at a non-canonical codon upstream of the annotated start codon; human homolog HLCS can complement yeast BPL1 mutant
functionSummary: Biotin ligase involved in protein biotinylation, covalent attachment of biotin moiety to target proteins; localized to cytoplasm and nucleus
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; conditional mutants are sensitive to heat, and are subject to chromosome instability; base-substitution mutants are potentially viable and may be isolated as long-chain-fatty-acid-requiring auxotrophs; overexpression slows growth

description: Biotin synthase; catalyzes the conversion of dethiobiotin to biotin, which is the last step of the biotin biosynthesis pathway; complements E. coli bioB mutant
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant is auxotrophic for biotin, and has decreased competitive fitness in minimal medium; null mutant accumulates alpha-amino acids; null mutant has elevated metal reductase activity

description: Bisphosphate-3'-nucleotidase; involved in salt tolerance and methionine biogenesis; dephosphorylates 3'-phosphoadenosine-5'-phosphate and 3'-phosphoadenosine-5'-phosphosulfate, intermediates of the sulfate assimilation pathway; human homolog BPNT1 complements yeast null mutant
functionSummary: DPNDase involved in sulfate assimilation; contributes to methionine biosynthesis and salt tolerance; cellular location is unknown
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays methionine auxotrophy and sensitivity to ionic stress; null mutation in homozygous diploid decreases sporulation and increases sensitivity to hygromycin B and Calcofluor White but increases resistance to caffeine, benomyl and oxidative stress

description: Blocked reading frame; may encode a non-functional member of the conserved, often subtelomerically-encoded Cos protein family

briefDescription: Blocked reading frame, contains two in-frame stops in translation
description: Blocked reading frame, contains two in-frame stops in translation; this ORF is conserved, without the stops, in Saccharomyces paradoxus, S. mikatae, and S. bayanus; RNA sequencing data indicate the presence of a transcription unit at this reading frame

briefDescription: Blocked reading frame otherwise encoding L-serine dehydratase
description: Blocked reading frame otherwise encoding L-serine dehydratase

briefDescription: Boron efflux transporter of the plasma membrane
description: Boron efflux transporter of the plasma membrane; binds HCO3-, I-, Br-, NO3- and Cl-; has similarity to the characterized boron efflux transporter A. thaliana BOR1
functionSummary: Transmembrane, plasma membrane localized boron efflux transporter; involved in vacuolar protein trafficking
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased resistance to boric acid, and increased accumulation of boron, while overexpression results in increased boric acid resistance and decreased accumulation of boron; null mutant displays increased vacuolar fragmentation; null mutant displays altered free amino acid profiles including altered levels of alpha amino acids, decreased levels of asparagine and histidine, and increased levels of glutamate; null mutant displays a decreased ability to utilize galactose as carbon source and both arginine and glutamate as nitrogen sources; null mutant displays increased survival following a ramped heat stimulus

briefDescription: Bridging factor involved in ER-associated protein degradation (ERAD)
description: Bridging factor involved in ER-associated protein degradation (ERAD); bridges the cytosolic Cdc48p-Npl1p-Ufd1p ATPase complex and the membrane associated Ssm4p and Hrd1p ubiquitin ligase complexes; contains a UBX (ubiquitin regulatory X) domain and a ubiquitin-associated (UBA) domain; redistributes from the ER to lipid droplets during the diauxic shift and stationary phase; required for the maintenance of lipid homeostasis

Broad-specificity lysophospholipid acyltransferase; part of MBOAT family of membrane-bound O-acyltransferases; key component of Lands cycle; may have role in fatty acid exchange at sn-2 position of mature glycerophospholipids
functionSummary: An 1-acylglycerol-3-phosphate O-acyltransferase involved in glyerophospholipid biosythesis; localized to the endoplasmic reticulum
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant lacks membrane-bound O-acyltransferase activity and shows decreased competitive fitness

briefDescription: B subunit of DNA polymerase alpha-primase complex
description: B subunit of DNA polymerase alpha-primase complex; required for initiation of DNA replication during mitotic and premeiotic DNA synthesis; also functions in telomere capping and length regulation

briefDescription: B-type cyclin involved in cell cycle progression
description: B-type cyclin involved in cell cycle progression; activates Cdc28p to promote the G2/M transition; may be involved in DNA replication and spindle assembly; accumulates during S phase and G2, then targeted for ubiquitin-mediated degradation; CLB4 has a paralog, CLB3, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Cyclin-dependent kinase regulatory subunit involved in the regulation of the G2/M phase transition of the mitotic cell cycle; regulates mitotic spindle assembly and spindle pole body separation; localizes to both the nucleus and cytoplasm
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; overexpression causes slow growth and elevated percentage of cells arrested at G2 phase of the cell cycle; in systematic studies null mutation increases competitive fitness, but also increases sensitivity to cycloheximide, fluconazole, tunicamycin, bleomycin, caffeine

briefDescription: B-type cyclin involved in cell cycle progression
description: B-type cyclin involved in cell cycle progression; activates Cdc28p to promote the G2/M transition; may be involved in DNA replication and spindle assembly; accumulates during S phase and G2, then targeted for ubiquitin-mediated degradation; relative distribution to the nucleus increases upon DNA replication stress; CLB3 has a paralog, CLB4, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Cyclin-dependent kinase regulatory subunit involved in the regulation of the G2/M phase transition of the mitotic cell cycle; regulates mitotic spindle assembly and spindle pole body separation; localizes to both the nucleus and cytoplasm
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; overexpression leads to slow growth and increased percentage of cells arrested at G2 phase of the cell cycle; in systematic studies mutants show increased sensitivity to Calcofluor White, MMS, cycloheximide, fenpropimorph, fluconazole, tunicamycin

briefDescription: B-type cyclin involved in cell cycle progression
description: B-type cyclin involved in cell cycle progression; activates Cdc28p to promote the transition from G2 to M phase; accumulates during G2 and M, then targeted via a destruction box motif for ubiquitin-mediated degradation by the proteasome; CLB1 has a paralog, CLB2, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Cyclin-dependent kinase regulatory subunit involved in the regulation of the G2/M phase transition of both the mitotic cell cycle and first meiotic division; involved in mitotic spindle assembly and spindle pole body separation; localizes to both the nucleus and cytoplasm
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; cells overexpressing an N-terminally truncated allele arrest in M phase of the cell cycle; in systematic studies null mutants show increased sensitivity to cycloheximide, fenpropimorph, fluconazole, caffeine; homozygous diploids reveal inositol auxotrophy and elevated mitotic chromosome loss

briefDescription: B-type cyclin involved in cell cycle progression
description: B-type cyclin involved in cell cycle progression; activates Cdc28p to promote the transition from G2 to M phase; accumulates during G2 and M, then targeted via a destruction box motif for ubiquitin-mediated degradation by the proteasome; CLB2 has a paralog, CLB1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Cyclin-dependent kinase regulatory subunit involved in the regulation of the G2/M phase transition of the mitotic cell cycle; regulates mitotic spindle elongation and spindle pole body separation; localizes to various cellular compartments including the nucleus, the spindle pole bodies, the mitotic spindle, and the bud neck
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows slow growth, abnormal budding pattern, delayed progression through the M phase of the cell cycle and increased cell size; overexpression leads to delayed G2/M transition and abnormal nuclear morphology

briefDescription: B-type cyclin involved in DNA replication during S phase
description: B-type cyclin involved in DNA replication during S phase; activates Cdc28p to promote initiation of DNA synthesis; functions in formation of mitotic spindles along with Clb3p and Clb4p; most abundant during late G1; CLB6 has a paralog, CLB5, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Cyclin-dependent kinase regulatory subunit involved in the regulation of the G1/S phase transition of the mitotic cell cycle; regulates mitotic and premeiotic DNA replication, as well as mitotic spindle assembly
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutation accelerates progression through START and G2/M phase transition, which leads to small cell size; overexpression slows down G2 phase progression and increases chromosome loss; in systematic studies null mutants are sensitive to cycloheximide and mycophenolic acid, but resistant to hydroxyurea, fenpropimorph, camptothecin, tunicamycin, bleomycin

briefDescription: B-type cyclin involved in DNA replication during S phase
description: B-type cyclin involved in DNA replication during S phase; activates Cdc28p to promote initiation of DNA synthesis; functions in formation of mitotic spindles along with Clb3p and Clb4p; most abundant during late G1 phase; CLB5 has a paralog, CLB6, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Cyclin-dependent kinase regulatory subunit involved in the regulation of both G1/S and G2/M phase transitions of the mitotic cell cycle; regulates mitotic and premeiotic DNA replication, as well as mitotic spindle assembly; localizes to the nucleus
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes slow growth, delayed progression through the S and G1 phases of the cell cycle, and increased cell size; overexpression results in delayed S phase, increased cell size and abnormal nuclear morphology

briefDescription: B-type regulatory subunit of protein phosphatase 2A (PP2A)
description: B-type regulatory subunit of protein phosphatase 2A (PP2A); Rts1p and Cdc55p are alternative regulatory subunits for PP2A catalytic subunits, Pph21p and Pph22p; PP2A-Rts1p protects cohesin when recruited by Sgo1p to the pericentromere; highly enriched at centromeres in the absence of Cdc55p; required for maintenance of septin ring organization during cytokinesis, for ring disassembly in G1 and for dephosphorylation of septin, Shs1p; homolog of the mammalian B' subunit of PP2A
functionSummary: Protein phosphatase regulator involved in protein dephosphorylation, mitotic spindle orientation checkpoint, and septin ring organization and disassembly; also involved in sister chromatid biorientation, meiotic sister chromatid cohesion at centromeres, and establishment of protein localization to chromosome; localizes to the nucleus, kinetochore, spindle pole body, bud neck, and centromeric regions of chromosomes
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to elevated temperatures and accumulates glycogen and glutathione; in systematic studies null mutants show slow growth, lower competitive fitness, decreased chronological lifespan and increased sensitivity to hyperosmotic stress, bleomycin, cycloheximide, MMS, hygromycin B, ethanol, fluconazole, but increased resistance to tunicamycin, mycophenolic acid, acetic acid

briefDescription: Bud tip localized protein of unknown function
description: Bud tip localized protein of unknown function; mRNA is targeted to the bud by a She2p dependent transport system; mRNA is cell cycle regulated via Fkh2p, peaking in G2/M phase; null mutant displays increased levels of spontaneous Rad52p foc

briefDescription: bZIP transcriptional activator in the Cbf1p-Met4p-Met28p complex
description: bZIP transcriptional activator in the Cbf1p-Met4p-Met28p complex; participates in the regulation of sulfur metabolism

briefDescription: bZIP transcriptional activator of amino acid biosynthetic genes
description: bZIP transcriptional activator of amino acid biosynthetic genes;  activator responds to amino acid starvation; expression is tightly regulated at both the transcriptional and translational levels
functionSummary: Transcription factor with a role in positive regulation of the assembly of RNA polymerase II transcriptional preinitiation complex and the negative regulation of transcription from RNA polymerase II promoter; localizes to the nucleus
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow slowly, have decreased ethanol tolerance, abnormal vacuolar morphology, and cannot utilize galactose; null also has increased lifespan, decreased competitive fitness and biofilm formation, G1 checkpoint deficiency, and is sensitive to a wide variety of different chemicals; overexpression stunts growth

description: C-14 sterol reductase; acts in ergosterol biosynthesis; mutants accumulate the abnormal sterol ignosterol (ergosta-8,14 dienol), and are viable under anaerobic growth conditions but inviable on rich medium under aerobic conditions
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene under aerobic condition, non-essential gene under anaerobic conditions; mutants are sensitive to multiple chemicals, including 6-azauracil, mycophenolic acid, fenpropimorph, Calcofluor White, hygromycin B, cisplatin, cycloheximide, doxorubicin, rapamycin, miconazole, ethanol, and show decreased respiratory growth

description: C-22 sterol desaturase; a cytochrome P450 enzyme that catalyzes the formation of the C-22(23) double bond in the sterol side chain in ergosterol biosynthesis; may be a target of azole antifungal drugs
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant has abnormal lipid particles and displays decreased replicative lifespan, increased resistance to nystatin and cycloheximide; in systematic studies null mutant is sensitive to multiple chemicals, including benomyl, nocodazole, hydroxyurea, echinocandin, rapamycin, fluconazole, Congo Red

description: C-24(28) sterol reductase; catalyzes the final step in ergosterol biosynthesis; mutants are viable, but lack ergosterol
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant has abnormal lipid particles, decreased shmoo formation and mating efficiency, and shows sensitivity to brefeldin A, Calcofluor White, cycloheximide, echinocandin B, mycophenolic acid and papulacandin B; in systematic studies null mutants display decreased biofilm formation, reduced endocytosis, defective sporulation in diploids, increased sensitivity to multiple chemicals and reduced competitive fitness

briefDescription: C2H2-type zinc finger protein required for ribosome assembly
description: C2H2-type zinc finger protein required for ribosome assembly; shuttling factor which associates with pre-60S particles in the nucleus, accompanying them to the cytoplasm; cytoplasmic dissociation of Bud20p requires Drg1p; N-terminus harbors a nuclear localization signal (NLS) and a nuclear export signal (NES); cytoplasmic Bud20p is reimported by Kap123-dependent pathway; involved in bud-site selection; diploid mutants display a random budding pattern; similar to human ZNF593
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant accumulates ribosomal protein reporters in the nucleus; in large-scale surveys, null mutant diploids display aberrant random budding pattern, delayed G1 phase progression, abnormal cell shape and size; also display inositol auxotrophy, increased innate thermotolerance and decreased growth rate

briefDescription: C3HC4-type RING-finger peroxin and E3 ubiquitin ligase
description: C3HC4-type RING-finger peroxin and E3 ubiquitin ligase; required for peroxisome biogenesis and peroxisomal matrix protein import; forms translocation subcomplex with Pex2p and Pex10p; mutations in human homolog cause peroxisomal disorder
functionSummary: Ubiquitin-protein ligase subunit of the peroxisomal importomer complex involved in the import of proteins into the peroxisomal matrix

description: C-3 sterol dehydrogenase; catalyzes the second of three steps required to remove two C-4 methyl groups from an intermediate in ergosterol biosynthesis; human homolog NSDHL implicated in CK syndrome, and can complement yeast null mutant; molecular target of natural product and antifungal compound FR171456
functionSummary: C-3 sterol dehydrogenase involved in ergosterol biosynthesis; localizes to endoplasmic reticulum membrane
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; in large-scale studies, repression confers S phase cell cycle delay, increased spontaneous DNA damage, and abnormal mitochondrial morphology; heterozygous null mutant is sensitive to ascomycin

description: C-4 methyl sterol oxidase; catalyzes the first of three steps required to remove two C-4 methyl groups from an intermediate in ergosterol biosynthesis; mutants accumulate the sterol intermediate 4,4-dimethylzymosterol; human MSMO1 functionally complements the growth defect caused by repression of ERG25 expression
functionSummary: C-4 methylsterol oxidase involved in ergosterol biosynthesis; localizes to plasma membrane and endoplasmic reticulum membrane
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene under standard conditions; null mutant can grow when supplied with ergosterol, and accumulates C-4,4-dimethylsterol; repression causes vacuolar fragmentation; in large-scale studies, repression causes abnormal mitochondrial morphology; mutant displays decreased competitive fitness; heterozygous null mutant diploid displays chromosome instability and sensitivity to azalomycin B

description: C-5 sterol desaturase; glycoprotein that catalyzes the introduction of a C-5(6) double bond into episterol, a precursor in ergosterol biosynthesis; transcriptionally down-regulated when ergosterol is in excess; mutants are viable, but cannot grow on non-fermentable carbon sources; substrate of HRD ubiquitin ligase; mutation is functionally complemented by human SC5D
functionSummary: C-5 sterol desaturase, catalyzes formation of C-5(6) double bond in episterol that yields 5,7,24(28)-ergostatrienol in third to last step of ergosterol biosynthesis pathway; integral to endoplasmic reticulum membrane
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant fails to synthesize ergosterol and cannot grow on nonfermentable carbon sources; null mutant exhibits increased resistance to azole antifungal drugs and decreased resistance to various other drugs; null mutant has reduced competitive fitness in a large-scale study

description: C6 zinc cluster transcriptional activator; binds to the carbon source-responsive element (CSRE) of gluconeogenic genes; involved in the positive regulation of gluconeogenesis; regulated by Snf1p protein kinase; localized to the nucleus
functionSummary: Sequence-specific DNA-binding transcription factor that positively regulates gluconeogenesis, and negatively regulates invasive growth in response to glucose limitation; localizes to nucleus

description: C-8 sterol isomerase; catalyzes isomerization of delta-8 double bond to delta-7 position at an intermediate step in ergosterol biosynthesis; transcriptionally down-regulated when ergosterol is in excess; mutation is functionally complemented by human EBP
functionSummary: C-8 sterol isomerase involved in ergosterol biosynthesis; localizes to endoplasmic reticulum in high-throughput studies
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays shortened replicative lifespan and sensitivity to metals, benomyl, and tacrolimus; conditional mutant shows reduced endocytosis; in large-scale studies, null mutant displays slower fermentative and respiratory growth, shorter telomeres, auxotrophy for myo-inositol, decreased resistance to osmotic stress, lower competitive fitness, and altered resistance to a variety of chemicals

description: Ca2+-dependent cysteine protease; may cleave specific substrates during the stress response; regulates apoptosis upon H2O2 treatment; required for clearance of insoluble protein aggregates during normal growth; implicated in cell cycle dynamics and lifespan extension; undergoes autocatalytic processing; similar to mammalian metacaspases, but exists as a monomer due to an extra pair of anti-parallel beta-strands that block potential dimerization
functionSummary: Calcium-dependent cysteine-type endopeptidase; involved in apoptosis and the degradation of misfolded or incompletely synthesized proteins; localizes to the nucleus and cytosol

briefDescription: CAAX box containing protein of unknown function
description: CAAX box containing protein of unknown function; proposed to be involved in the RAS/cAMP signaling pathway

Cadmium transporting P-type ATPase; may also have a role in copper and iron homeostasis; stabilized by Cd binding, which prevents ubiquitination; S288C and other lab strains contain a G970R mutation which eliminates Cd transport function

Calcineurin A; one isoform (the other is Cmp2p) of the catalytic subunit of calcineurin, a Ca++/calmodulin-regulated protein phosphatase which regulates Crz1p (a stress-response transcription factor), the other calcineurin subunit is CNB1; regulates the function of Aly1p alpha-arrestin; CNA1 has a paralog, CMP2, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Calcium-dependent protein serine/threonine phosphatase involved in ion homeostasis, cell wall organization, and desensitization to pheromone during conjugation with cellular fusion; subunit of calcineurin complex
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant accumulates increased amounts of calcium and shows increased resistance to cyclosporin A

description: Calcineurin A; one isoform (the other is Cna1p) of the catalytic subunit of calcineurin, a Ca++/calmodulin-regulated protein phosphatase which regulates Crz1p (a stress-response transcription factor), the other calcineurin subunit is CNB1; regulates the function of Aly1p alpha-arrestin; CMP2 has a paralog, CNA1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Calcium-dependent protein serine/threonine phosphatase involved in ion homeostasis and desensitization to pheromone during conjugation with cellular fusion; subunit of calcineurin complex, localizes to cytoplasm
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutation has negative effect on recovery from pheromone-induced cell cycle arrest; overexpression shortens replicative lifespan; in systematic studies null mutants show elevated sensitivity to caffeine, azoles, tunicamycin, hydroxyurea, cycloheximide, camptothecin, bleomycin and rapamycin

description: Calcineurin B; regulatory subunit of calcineurin, a Ca++/calmodulin-regulated type 2B protein phosphatase which regulates Crz1p (stress-response transcription factor); other calcineurin subunit encoded by CNA1 and/or CMP1; regulates function of Aly1p alpha-arrestin; myristoylation by Nmt1p reduces calcineurin activity in response to submaximal Ca signals, is needed to prevent constitutive phosphatase activity; protein abundance increases in response to DNA replication stress
functionSummary: Subunit of calcineurin complex involved in calcium-dependent protein serine/threonine dephosphorylation, ion homeostasis, cell wall organization, and desensitization to pheromone during conjugation with cellular fusion
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant accumulates increased amounts of calcium but shows increased sensitivity to higher concentrations of lithium and calcium; in systematic studies mutants show inositol auxotrophy, increased sensitivity to a variety of chemicals, including DTT, tunicamycin, caffeine, cycloheximide, increased resistance to MMS and mycophenolic acid; null mutant is also sensitive to osmotic and oxidative stress and shows reduced competitive fitness

briefDescription: Calcium and manganese transporter with higher affinity for Ca2+
description: Calcium and manganese transporter with higher affinity for Ca2+; involved in Ca2+ and Mn2+ homeostasis; localizes to the cis- and medial-Golgi apparatus; GFP-fusion localizes to the vacuole; required for the Mn2+-dependent function of glycosylation enzymes; TMEM165, a human ortholog linked to Congenital Disorders of Glycosylation, functionally complements the null allele; expression pattern and physical interactions suggest a possible role in ribosome biogenesis; expression regulated by Gcr1p
functionSummary: Calcium and manganese ion transmembrane transporter involved in calcium and manganese ion transmembrane transport; contributes to cellular calcium and manganese ion homeostasis and Golgi calcium homeostasis; localizes to vacuoles, the cis-Golgi network and Golgi medial cisternae
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows increased sensitivity to calcium and decreased competitive fitness; haploinsufficient; homozygous diploid shows decreased rate of respiratory growth

briefDescription: Calcium-binding component of the spindle pole body (SPB) half-bridge
description: Calcium-binding component of the spindle pole body (SPB) half-bridge; required for SPB duplication in mitosis and meiosis II; homolog of mammalian centrin; binds multiubiquitinated proteins and is involved in proteasomal protein degradation
functionSummary: Subunit of the transcription export complex 2 involved in spindle pole body duplication; localized to the half bridge of the spindle pole body

briefDescription: Calcium/H+ antiporter localized to the endoplasmic reticulum membrane
description: Calcium/H+ antiporter localized to the endoplasmic reticulum membrane; member of the calcium exchanger (CAX) family; potential Cdc28p substrate
Calcium permeable gated cation channel; may be involved in detoxification; similar to Arabidopsis CSC1

Calmodulin; Ca2+ binding protein that regulates Ca2+ independent processes (mitosis, bud growth, actin organization, endocytosis, etc.) and Ca2+ dependent processes (stress-activated pathways), targets include Nuf1p, Myo2p and calcineurin; binds to the Hog1p MAPK in response to hyperosmotic stress; potentiates membrane tubulation and constriction mediated by the Rvs161p-Rvs167p complex; human CALM1 or CALM2 functionally complement repression induced inviability
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; conditional mutations affect processes that depend on actin cytoskeleton, including budding, nuclear position and spindle pole body position; in diploids, conditional (ts) mutations lead to increased chromosome loss under permissive temperature and cell cycle arrest at G2/M phase transition under restrictive temperature; in systematic studies reduction-of-function mutations confer sensitivity to benomyl, myriocin and MMS

description: Calmodulin-binding actin-associated protein; roles in endocytic membrane tabulation and constriction, and exocytosis; N-BAR domain protein that interacts with Rvs161p to regulate actin cytoskeleton, endocytosis, and viability following starvation or osmotic stress; recruited to bud tips by Gyl1p and Gyp5p during polarized growth; homolog of mammalian amphiphysin
functionSummary: Cytoskeletal protein; forms a complex with Rvs161p and is involved in actin cytoskeleton reorganization and endocytosis; localizes to the actin cortical patch

description: Calmodulin-dependent protein kinase; may play a role in stress response, many CA++/calmodulan dependent phosphorylation substrates demonstrated in vitro, amino acid sequence similar to mammalian Cam Kinase II; CMK2 has a paralog, CMK1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Cytoplasmic calmodulin-dependent protein kinase
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; in competitive growth studies null mutant shows decreased fitness and reduced starvation resistance

description: Calmodulin-dependent protein kinase; may play a role in stress response, many Ca++/calmodulin dependent phosphorylation substrates demonstrated in vitro, amino acid sequence similar to mammalian Cam Kinase II; CMK1 has a paralog, CMK2, that arose from the whole genome duplication
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant accumulates increased amounts of free amino acids in a systematic study and shows slightly increased competitive fitness

description: Calnexin; integral membrane ER chaperone involved in folding and quality control of glycoproteins; chaperone activity is inhibited by Mpd1p, with which Cne1p interacts; 24% identical to mammalian calnexin; Ca+ binding not yet shown in yeast
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant has decreased competitive fitness, is auxotrophic for myo-inositol, displays increased chitin deposition and increased activation of the cell wall integrity (CWI) pathway

description: Calpain-like cysteine protease; involved in proteolytic activation of Rim101p in response to alkaline pH; localizes to punctate structures in alkaline conditions and in vps4 mutant; has similarity to A. nidulans palB
functionSummary: Cysteine-type endopeptidase involved in protein processing; localization not yet determined

description: cAMP-dependent protein kinase catalytic subunit; promotes vegetative growth in response to nutrients via the Ras-cAMP signaling pathway; inhibited by regulatory subunit Bcy1p in the absence of cAMP; phosphorylates and inhibits Whi3p to promote G1/S phase passage; partially redundant with Tpk2p and Tpk3p; phosphorylates pre-Tom40p, which impairs its import into mitochondria under non-respiratory conditions; TPK1 has a paralog, TPK3, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: cAMP-dependent protein kinase involved in signaling; localizes to both nucleus and cytoplasm
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutation lowers competitive fitness and increases senitivity to desiccation; overexpression leads to abnormalities in actin cytoskeleton and blocks autophagy

description: cAMP-dependent protein kinase catalytic subunit; promotes vegetative growth in response to nutrients via the Ras-cAMP signaling pathway; partially redundant with Tpk1p and Tpk2p; localizes to P-bodies during stationary phase; TPK3 has a paralog, TPK1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: cAMP-dependent protein kinase involved in signaling and organization of mitochondria; localizes to both nucleus and cytoplasm

description: cAMP-dependent protein kinase catalytic subunit; promotes vegetative growth in response to nutrients via the Ras-cAMP signaling pathway; partially redundant with Tpk1p and Tpk3p; localizes to P-bodies during stationary phase; relocalizes to the cytosol in response to hypoxia
functionSummary: cAMP-dependent protein kinase involved in signaling and invasive growth in response to glucose limitation; localizes to both nucleus and cytosol
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutation decreases filamentous growth and prevents invasive growth in Sigma1278b; overexpression causes slow growth and abnormalities in actin cytoskeleton and nuclear morphology; in systematic studies null mutation results in vacuolar fragmentation

description: CAP (cyclase-associated protein); N-terminus binds adenylate cyclase and facilitates activation by RAS; N-terminus forms novel hexameric star-shaped shuriken structures that directly catalyze cofilin-mediated severing of actin filaments; C-terminus binds and recycles cofilin bound, ADP-actin monomers, facilitating regulation of actin dynamics and cell morphogenesis; N- and C-termini can function as physically separate proteins; mCAP1 is the mouse homolog
functionSummary: Adenylate cyclase-binding protein involved in Ras protein signal transduction and actin filament organization; localizes to actin cortical patches
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits slow growth, an abnormal actin cytoskeleton, and reduced localization of proteins to the bud tip; in large-scale studies, null mutant fails to respire or to mate, has abnormally large cells with elongated buds and abnormal lipid particle morphology, is sensitive to hyperosmotic and oxidative stress, and is resistant to K28 killer toxin and to manganese; conditional mutant exhibits chromosome instability at semi-permissive temperature; overexpression in the Sigma1278b genetic background causes greatly increased filamentous growth; null mutant exhibits filamentous growth in response to HU treatment; diploid heterozygous null mutant is sensitive to starvation and heat; null mutant is sensitive to a variety of chemicals

description: Carbonic anhydrase; metalloenzyme that catalyzes CO2 hydration to bicarbonate, which is an important metabolic substrate, and protons; not expressed under conditions of high CO2, such as inside a growing colony, but transcription is induced in response to low CO2 levels, such as on the colony surface in ambient air; poorly transcribed under aerobic conditions and at an undetectable level under anaerobic conditions; abundance increases in response to DNA replication stress
functionSummary: Carbonate dehydratase involved in responses to oxidative stress and carbon dioxide; localizes to mitochondrial envelope lumen and to nucleus and cytoplasm in high-throughput studies
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant grows slowly under aerobic conditions but shows normal growth rate under elevated CO2 concentration; overexpression in Sigma1278b causes increased filamentous growth

description: Carbon source-responsive zinc-finger transcription factor; required for transcription of the glucose-repressed gene ADH2, of peroxisomal protein genes, and of genes required for ethanol, glycerol, and fatty acid utilization
functionSummary: Sequence specific DNA-binding RNA polymerase II transcription factor that activates expression of genes involved in peroxisome organization, ethanol, glycerol, and fatty acid utilization
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene, but heterozygous diploid shows haploinsufficiency; null mutant displays decreased competitive growth on glycerol but increased competitive growth on ethanol; null mutant has decreased resistance to palmitoleic acid and oleic acid, but increased hibernating lifespan; overexpression results in increased invasive growth

description: Carboxyl methyltransferase; methylates the C terminus of the protein phosphatase 2A catalytic subunit (Pph21p or Pph22p), which is important for complex formation with regulatory subunits; required for methionine to inhibit autophagy and promote growth

Carboxy-terminal domain (CTD) phosphatase; essential for dephosphorylation of the repeated C-terminal domain of the RNA polymerase II large subunit (Rpo21p); relocalizes to the cytosol in response to hypoxia

Cardiolipin synthase; produces cardiolipin, which is a phospholipid of the mitochondrial inner membrane that is required for normal mitochondrial membrane potential and function and for correct integration of membrane-multispanning proteins into the mitochondrial outer membrane; required to maintain tubular mitochondrial morphology and functions in mitochondrial fusion; also required for normal vacuolar ion homeostasis
functionSummary: Cardiolipin synthase; responsible for biosynthesis of cardiolipin, which is required for normal mitochondrial function
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays fragmented mitochondria, increased sensitivity to heat and antifungal drugs (caspofungin, azoles), and shows reduced respiratory growth rate

description: Cargo-binding mu subunit of AP-2; AP-2 is a heterotetrameric endocytic cargo-binding adaptor that facilitates uptake of membrane proteins during clathrin-mediated endocytosis; Apm4p is required for AP-2 function and localization, and binds cell wall stress receptor Mid2p; AP-2 is required for cell polarity responses to pheromone, nutritional status and cell wall damage in S. cerevisiae, and for hyphal growth in C. albicans; AP-2 complex is conserved in mammals
functionSummary: Subunit of the AP-2 adaptor complex that functions in vesicle mediated transport
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays abnormal, random budding pattern and decreased sensitivity to mating pheromone; null mutants are also sensitive to cell wall perturbing drugs, such as Congo Red or caffeine, and to fluconazole, cycloheximide, tunicamycin

description: Cargo-transport protein involved in endocytosis; interacts with phosphatidylinositol-4-kinase Stt4p; is required, along with Efr3p, for the assembly and recruitment of multiple copies of the kinase into phosphoinositide kinase (PIK) patches at the plasma membrane; positively regulates Stt4p; GFP-fusion protein localizes to the cytoplasm; YGR198W is an essential gene
Carnitine acetyl-CoA transferase; present in both mitochondria and peroxisomes; transfers activated acetyl groups to carnitine to form acetylcarnitine which can be shuttled across membranes
functionSummary: Carnitine O-acetyltransferase (CATC) that is involved in carnitine metabollic process; localizes to the peroxisome and the mitochodrion

description: Carnitine acetyltransferase; has similarity to Yat1p, which is a carnitine acetyltransferase associated with the mitochondrial outer membrane
functionSummary: Cytosolic carnitine O-acetyltransferase involved in metabolism of alcohol and carnitine

description: Catabolic L-serine (L-threonine) deaminase; catalyzes the degradation of both L-serine and L-threonine; required to use serine or threonine as the sole nitrogen source, transcriptionally induced by serine and threonine
functionSummary: Serine and threonine deaminase; catalyzes the catabolism of hydroxy amino acids; localizes to the mitochondrial nucleoid
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant is defective in utilization of serine or threonine as nitrogen sources; in competitive growth experiments null mutant shows reduced fitness

description: Catalase A; breaks down hydrogen peroxide in the peroxisomal matrix formed by acyl-CoA oxidase (Pox1p) during fatty acid beta-oxidation
functionSummary: Catalase; involved in hydrogen peroxide catabolism and the response to reactive oxygen species; localizes to the mitochondrial matrix and the peroxisomal matrix
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays elevated sensitivity to oxidative stress and reduced survival rate in stationary phase, but increased chronological lifespan

description: Catalytically inactive alanine transaminase; expression is repressed in the presence of alanine and repression is mediated by Nrg1p; ALT2 has a paralog, ALT1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays increased competitive fitness, shortened chronological lifespan and abnormal accumulation of polyphosphates

briefDescription: Catalytic (alpha) subunit of C-terminal domain kinase I (CTDK-I)
description: Catalytic (alpha) subunit of C-terminal domain kinase I (CTDK-I); phosphorylates both RNA pol II subunit Rpo21p to affect transcription and pre-mRNA 3' end processing, and ribosomal protein Rps2p to increase translational fidelity; required for H3K36 trimethylation but not dimethylation by Set2p; suggested stimulatory role in 80S formation during translation initiation; similar to the Drosophila dCDK12 and human CDK12 and probably CDK13
functionSummary: Cyclin-dependent protein serine/threonine kinase subunit of the CTDK-1 complex; involved in positive regulation of RNA pol I and II and transcription elongation; found in the nucleus
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene in strain S288C, essential in Sigma1278b; null mutant is slow-growing and sensitive to cold, metal ions, and nucleoside analogs such as cordycepin and 6-azauracil; null mutant has abnormal nucleolar morphology and heterogeneous cell size; in large-scale studies, null mutant has reduced competitive fitness in several different media; homozygous null mutant diploid fails to sporulate; null mutant displays altered resistance to a wide variety of chemicals

description: Catalytic component of UDP-GlcNAc transferase; required for the second step of dolichyl-linked oligosaccharide synthesis; anchored to the ER membrane via interaction with Alg14p; similar to bacterial and human glycosyltransferases; protein abundance increases in response to DNA replication stress; both human homologs ALG13 and ALG14 are required to complement yeast alg13 mutant
functionSummary: An N-acetylglucosaminyldiphosphodolichol N-acetylglucosaminyltransferase that is a component of the UDP-N-acetylglucosamine transferase complex; involved in the dolichol-linked oligosaccharide biosynthetic process; localizes to the extrinsic component of endoplasmic reticulum membrane
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; reduced function mutants show decreased competitive fitness, increased sensitivity to rapamycin and to DNA-damaging agents methyl methanesulfonate (MMS) and hydroxyurea (HU); heterozygous diploid nulls have small cells

description: Catalytic core subunit, Anaphase-Promoting Complex/Cyclosome (APC/C); which is a ubiquitin-protein ligase required for degradation of anaphase inhibitors, including mitotic cyclins, during the metaphase/anaphase transition; contains a RING-H2 domain that is required for activity
functionSummary: Ubiquitin transferase that is a component of the anaphase-promoting complex involved in degradation of mitotic cyclins and transition from metaphase to anaphase during mitotic cell cycle
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutants show cell cycle arrest at G2/M phase transition, abnormal spindle morphology, chromosome instability and sensitivity to hydroxyurea

briefDescription: Catalytic epsilon subunit of the translation initiation factor eIF2B
description: Catalytic epsilon subunit of the translation initiation factor eIF2B; eIF2B is the guanine-nucleotide exchange factor for eIF2; activity subsequently regulated by phosphorylated eIF2; first identified as a negative regulator of GCN4 expression; forms cytoplasmic foci upon DNA replication stress

Catalytic subunit of 1,3-beta-D-glucan synthase; functionally redundant with alternate catalytic subunit Gsc2p; binds to regulatory subunit Rho1p; involved in cell wall synthesis and maintenance; localizes to sites of cell wall remodeling; FKS1 has a paralog, GSC2, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Catalytic subunit of the 1,3-beta-D-glucan synthase complex; involved in beta-glucan biosynthesis, regulation of cell size, and positive regulation of endocytosis; localizes to the plasma membrane, cellular bud tip and neck, and actin cortical patch
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes abnormal cell wall morphology and confers sensitivity to cell-wall affecting drugs and FK506

description: Catalytic subunit of 1,3-beta-glucan synthase; involved in formation of the inner layer of the spore wall; activity positively regulated by Rho1p and negatively by Smk1p; GSC2 has a paralog, FKS1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Catalytic subunit of 1,3-beta-D-glucan synthase complex involved in beta-glucan biosynthesis and spore wall assembly; localizes to prospore membranes
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants have abnormal vacuolar morphology, defects in sporulation, and decreased fitness, ethanol tolerance, and thermotolerance; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient; overexpression slows growth

briefDescription: Catalytic subunit of ADA and SAGA histone acetyltransferase complexes
description: Catalytic subunit of ADA and SAGA histone acetyltransferase complexes; modifies N-terminal lysines on histones H2B and H3; acetylates Rsc4p, a subunit of the RSC chromatin-remodeling complex, altering replication stress tolerance; relocalizes to the cytosol in response to hypoxia; mutant displays reduced transcription elongation in the G-less-based run-on (GLRO) assay; greater involvement in repression of RNAPII-dependent transcription than in activation
functionSummary: Subunit of SAGA, ADA, and SLIK histone acetyltransferase complexes involved ih chromatin modification and transcription regulation
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow slowly, have increased lifespan, flocculate more readily, cannot utilize glutamine or maltose, have abnormal spindles and buds, decreased ethanol tolerance, are defective in endocytosis, are sensitive to heat, metals, nucleotide analogs, TOR inhibitor rapamycin and various antibiotics, and are auxotrophic for myo-inositol; overexpression slows vegetative growth, increases lifespan, enhances invasive growth

briefDescription: Catalytic subunit of adoMet-dependent tRNA methyltransferase complex
description: Catalytic subunit of adoMet-dependent tRNA methyltransferase complex; required for the methylation of the guanosine nucleotide at position 10 (m2G10) in tRNAs; contains a THUMP domain and a methyltransferase domain; another complex member is Trm112p
functionSummary: tRNA (guanine-N2-)-methyltransferase subunit of cytoplasmic tRNA (m2G10) methyltransferase complex required for methylation of the guanosine nucleotide at position 10 (m2G10)

briefDescription: Catalytic subunit of a tRNA methyltransferase complex
description: Catalytic subunit of a tRNA methyltransferase complex; Trm8p and Trm82p comprise an enzyme that catalyzes a methyl-transfer from S-adenosyl-l-methionine to the N(7) atom of guanine at position 46 in tRNA; Trm8 lacks catalytic activity if not bound to Trm82p

briefDescription: Catalytic subunit of Dcp1p-Dcp2p decapping enzyme complex
description: Catalytic subunit of Dcp1p-Dcp2p decapping enzyme complex; removes 5' cap structure from mRNAs prior to their degradation; also enters nucleus and positively regulates transcription initiation; nudix hydrolase family member; forms cytoplasmic foci upon DNA replication stress; human homolog DCP2 complements yeast dcp2 thermosensitive mutant
functionSummary: m7G(5')pppN diphosphatase that binds chromatin and mRNA; involved in deadenylation-dependent and deadenylation-independent decapping of nuclear-transcribed mRNA; also involved in stress granule assembly and positive regulation of transcription initiation from RNA polymerase II promoters; colocalizes with cytoplasmic mRNA processing bodies during the response to stress and localizes to the nucleus, cytoplasm, and cytoplasmic side of membranes
phenotypeSummary: Gene reported to be essential in some strain backgrounds and non-essential in others; null mutant displays increased apoptosis; point mutation confers stabilization of mRNAs encoding ribosomal proteins; in large-scale studies, conditional mutant shows chromosome instability at the semi-permissive temperature; heterozygous null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness and starvation resistance

briefDescription: Catalytic subunit of DNA polymerase delta
description: Catalytic subunit of DNA polymerase delta; required for chromosomal DNA replication during mitosis and meiosis, intragenic recombination, repair of double strand DNA breaks, and DNA replication during nucleotide excision repair (NER)
functionSummary: Subunit of the delta DNA polymerase complex; has DNA polymerase and 3'-5'-exodeoxyribonuclease activities; involved in DNA replication, Okazaki initiator RNA removal, RNA-dependent DNA biosynthesis, and maintenance of fidelity during DNA replication

briefDescription: Catalytic subunit of DNA polymerase (II) epsilon
description: Catalytic subunit of DNA polymerase (II) epsilon; a chromosomal DNA replication polymerase that exhibits processivity and proofreading exonuclease activity; participates in leading-strand synthesis during DNA replication; also involved in DNA synthesis during DNA repair; interacts extensively with Mrc1p
functionSummary: DNA-directed DNA polymerase and single-stranded DNA 3'-5' exodeoxyribonuclease; subunit of the epsilon DNA polymerase complex; involved in DNA-dependent DNA replication, leading strand elongation, DNA replication proofreading, and DNA repair; also involved in mitotic sister chromatid cohesion, heterochromatin organization involved in chromatin silencing, the mitotic DNA replication checkpoint, and the intra-S DNA damage checkpoint
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; heat-sensitive mutant arrests as large-budded cells with nuclei at the mother-bud neck; point mutations affect chromosome stability and mutation frequency, and confer sensitivity to HU, MMS, and camptothecin; in large-scale studies, mutants display reduced competitive fitness and an Opi- phenotype (overproduction and excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline)

briefDescription: Catalytic subunit of DNA polymerase zeta
description: Catalytic subunit of DNA polymerase zeta; involved in translesion synthesis during post-replication repair; required for mutagenesis induced by DNA damage; involved in double-strand break repair; forms a complex with Rev7p, Pol31p and Pol32p

briefDescription: Catalytic subunit of i-AAA protease complex
description: Catalytic subunit of i-AAA protease complex; complex is located in mitochondrial inner membrane; responsible for degradation of unfolded or misfolded mitochondrial gene products; serves as nonconventional translocation motor to pull PNPase into intermembrane space; also has role in intermembrane space protein folding; mutation causes elevated rate of mitochondrial turnover; human homolog YME1L1 can complement yeast null mutant
functionSummary: ATP-dependent peptidase of the inner mitochondrial membrane; subunit of the i-AAA complex involved in mitochondrial protein turnover; also involved in protein import, folding and maturation
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant is unable to respire and has abnormal globular mitochondria; null mutant becomes inviable upon loss of the mitochondrial genome; null mutant displays slow growth at reduced temperatures, decreased chronological lifespan, and resistance to bortezomib; in large-scale studies, the null mutant displays reduced competitive fitness in a variety of media, sensitivity to desiccation and heat, and altered resistance to a variety of chemicals

briefDescription: Catalytic subunit of mitochondrial inner membrane peptidase complex
description: Catalytic subunit of mitochondrial inner membrane peptidase complex; required for maturation of mitochondrial proteins of the intermembrane space; complex contains two catalytic subunits (Imp1p and Imp2p that differ in substrate specificity), and Som1p

briefDescription: Catalytic subunit of mitochondrial inner membrane peptidase complex
description: Catalytic subunit of mitochondrial inner membrane peptidase complex; required for maturation of mitochondrial proteins of the intermembrane space; complex contains two catalytic subunits (Imp1p and Imp2p that differ in substrate specificty) and Som1p

briefDescription: Catalytic subunit of protein phosphatase 2A, PP2A
description: Catalytic subunit of protein phosphatase 2A, PP2A; functionally redundant with Pph21p; C-terminally methylated; forms alternate complexes with several regulatory subunits; involved in signal transduction and regulation of mitosis; protein abundance increases in response to DNA replication stress; dephosphorylates Tel1p/Mec1p-phosphorylated Cdc13p to promote telomerase release from telomeres at G2/M; PPH22 has a paralog, PPH21, that arose from the whole genome duplication

briefDescription: Catalytic subunit of protein phosphatase 2A, PP2A
description: Catalytic subunit of protein phosphatase 2A, PP2A; functionally redundant with Pph22p; C-terminally methylated; forms alternate complexes with several regulatory subunits; involved in signal transduction and regulation of mitosis; forms nuclear foci upon DNA replication stress; PPH21 has a paralog, PPH22, that arose from the whole genome duplication

briefDescription: Catalytic subunit of protein phosphatase PP4 complex
description: Catalytic subunit of protein phosphatase PP4 complex; Pph3p and Psy2p form active complex, Psy4p may provide substrate specificity; regulates recovery from the DNA damage checkpoint, the gene conversion- and single-strand annealing-mediated pathways of meiotic double-strand break repair and efficient Non-Homologous End-Joining (NHEJ) pathway; involved in activation of Gln3p to alleviate nitrogen catabolite repression; Pph3p and Psy2p localize to foci on meiotic chromosomes

briefDescription: Catalytic subunit of the COP9 signalosome (CSN) complex
description: Catalytic subunit of the COP9 signalosome (CSN) complex; acts as an isopeptidase in cleaving the ubiquitin-like protein Nedd8 from SCF ubiquitin ligases; metalloendopeptidase involved in the adaptation to pheromone signaling; involved in modulation of genes controlling amino acid and lipid metabolism, and ergosterol biosynthesis

briefDescription: Catalytic subunit of the DNA polymerase I alpha-primase complex
description: Catalytic subunit of the DNA polymerase I alpha-primase complex; required for the initiation of DNA replication during mitotic DNA synthesis and premeiotic DNA synthesis
functionSummary: DNA polymerase of the alpha DNA polymerase:primase complex; involved in DNA replication initiation and lagging strand elongation; also involved in double-strand break repair, premeiotic DNA replication, and RNA-dependent DNA biosynthesis
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; heat-sensitive mutant arrests as large-budded cells with nuclei at the mother-bud neck; point mutations affect minichromosome maintenance, chromosome stability, lifespan, mutation frequency, and telomere length; repression in a diploid causes increases in mitotic and meiotic recombination

briefDescription: Catalytic subunit of the Hat1p-Hat2p histone acetyltransferase complex
description: Catalytic subunit of the Hat1p-Hat2p histone acetyltransferase complex; uses the cofactor acetyl coenzyme A to acetylate free nuclear and cytoplasmic histone H4; involved in telomeric silencing and DNA double-strand break repair
functionSummary: A H4 histone acetyltransferase; silences chromatin at telomeres with Hht1p and Hht2p; subunit of histone acetyltransferase complex

briefDescription: Catalytic subunit of the histone acetyltransferase complex (NuA4)
description: Catalytic subunit of the histone acetyltransferase complex (NuA4); acetylates four conserved internal lysines of histone H4 N-terminal tail and can acetylate histone H2A; master regulator of cellular acetylation balance; required for cell cycle progression and transcriptional silencing at the rDNA locus and regulation of autophagy; human ortholog TIP60/KAT5 is implicated in cancer and other diseases, functionally complements lethality of the esa1 null mutation
functionSummary: Acetyltransferase involved in acetylation of histone H4, chromatin silencing, regulation of transcription, macroautophagy, DNA repair and other cellular processes; subunit of the Piccolo NuA4 histone acetyltransferase complex
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; conditional mutants exhibit heat sensitivity; in a large-scale study, depletion confers an Opi- phenotype, overproduction and excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline

briefDescription: Catalytic subunit of the NatB N-terminal acetyltransferase
description: Catalytic subunit of the NatB N-terminal acetyltransferase; NatB catalyzes acetylation of the amino-terminal methionine residues of all proteins beginning with Met-Asp or Met-Glu and of some proteins beginning with Met-Asn or Met-Met

briefDescription: Catalytic subunit of the NatC type N-terminal acetyltransferase (NAT)
description: Catalytic subunit of the NatC type N-terminal acetyltransferase (NAT); involved in subcellular targeting of select N-terminally acetylated substrates to the Golgi apparatus (Arl3p and Grh1p) and the inner nuclear membrane (Trm1p); required for replication of dsRNA virus; human NatC ortholog, Naa60, functionally complements the null, requiring either auxiliary subunit Mak10p or co-expression of human ortholog, Naa35; Naa60, the human NatF gene, also complements the null allele

briefDescription: Catalytic subunit of the Pan2p-Pan3p poly(A)-ribonuclease complex
description: Catalytic subunit of the Pan2p-Pan3p poly(A)-ribonuclease complex; complex acts to control poly(A) tail length and regulate the stoichiometry and activity of postreplication repair complexes

briefDescription: Catalytic subunit of the SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling complex
description: Catalytic subunit of the SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling complex; involved in transcriptional regulation; contains DNA-stimulated ATPase activity; functions interdependently in transcriptional activation with Snf5p and Snf6p
functionSummary: Subunit of the SWI/SNF complex with DNA-dependent ATPase and histone-binding activities; involved in chromatin remodeling and positive regulation of transcription from polymerase II promoters; localized in nucleus
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; mutants show defects in chromatin remodeling and transcriptional regulation, leading to inability to switch mating type, abnormal utilization of carbon sources, increased sensitivity to DNA-affecting factors (UV, gamma rays, camptothecin, cisplatin, hydroxyurea) and cell wall-affecting drugs (Congo Red); null mutation in homozygous diploid decreases respiratory growth, prevents sporulation, and increases innate thermotolerance

description: C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); commonly referred to as U18; guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at positions A649 and C650
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); commonly referred to as U24; guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at positions C1437, C1449, and C1450
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at position A1133
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at position A2220 and small subunit (SSU) rRNA at position A619
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at position A2256
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at position A2640
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at position A2946
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at position A807
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at position A807
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at position A876
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at position C2197
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at position C2337
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at position C2948
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at position C2959
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at position C663
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at position G2288
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at position G2815
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at position G805
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at position G867
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at positions A2280 and A2281
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at positions A817 and G908
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at positions G2619 and U2724
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at positions G2791 and G2793
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at position U1888
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at position U2347
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at position U2417
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at position U2421
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at position U2729 and small subunit (SSU) rRNA at position A100
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at position U2921 and small subunit (SSU) rRNA at position A420
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at position U898 and small subunit (SSU) rRNA at position G1271
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of small subunit (SSU) rRNA at position A28
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of small subunit (SSU) rRNA at position A436
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of small subunit (SSU) rRNA at position A796
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of small subunit (SSU) rRNA at position A974
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of small subunit (SSU) rRNA at position C1007
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of small subunit (SSU) rRNA at position G1428
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of small subunit (SSU) rRNA at position G1572
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of small subunit (SSU) rRNA at positions A541 and G1126
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); guides 2'-O-methylation of small subunit (SSU) rRNA at position U578
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); predicted to guide 2'-O-methylation of large subunit (LSU) rRNA at position G2395; not shown to be active
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); predicted to guide 2'-O-methylation of small subunit (SSU) rRNA at position C1639
C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); predicted to guide 2'-O-methylation of small subunit (SSU) rRNA at position U1269

C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA); referred to as U14; essential gene required for cleavage of 35S primary rRNA transcript to release the precursor to the 18S rRNA; guides 2'-O-methylation of small subunit (SSU) rRNA at position C414

briefDescription: C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA) but not shown to be active
description: C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA) but not shown to be active; no target site is predicted within the ribosomal RNAs

briefDescription: C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA) but not shown to be active
description: C/D box small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA) but not shown to be active; no target site is predicted within the ribosomal RNAs

Cdc42p-activated signal transducing kinase; involved in pheromone response, pseudohyphal/invasive growth, vacuole inheritance, down-regulation of sterol uptake; GBB motif binds Ste4p; member of the PAK (p21-activated kinase) family
functionSummary: MAP kinase kinase kinase kinase involved in vacuole inheritance, pheromone signaling, osmosensory signaling, filamentous and psudohyphal growth, bud site selection, stress granule assembly, regulation of mitotic exit, and regulation of apoptosis; localizes to the nucleus, incipient bud sites, and shmoo tip
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant confers sterility, and an inability to undergo cell cycle arrest, and form shmoos in the presence of pheromone; null mutant has a reduced growth rate, and temperature sensitivity; homozygous diploid null mutant buds in a unipolar rather than bipolar pattern and are rounder than wild-type, indicative of bud site selection and apical growth defects; null mutant is sensitive to hyperosmotic stress, metal and desiccation stress

description: Cdc42p-activated signal transducing kinase; member of the PAK (p21-activated kinase) family, along with Ste20p and Skm1p; involved in septin ring assembly, vacuole inheritance, cytokinesis, sterol uptake regulation; phosphorylates Cdc3p and Cdc10p; CLA4 has a paralog, SKM1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Serine/Threonine kinase; involved in septin ring organization, vacuole inheritance, regulation of exit from mitosis, positive regulation of protein import into nucleus; negative regulation of sterol import by negative regulation of transcription from RNA Pol II promoter; localizes to the vacuole, nucleus and bud
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant is hypersensitive to zymolyase treatment and displays lowered sensitivity to mating pheromones; null mutant accumulates elevated levels of sterol esters under anaerobic conditions; in large-scale studies the null mutant displays slow growth, haploinsufficiency, large cell size, decreased filamentous growth, and sensitivity to various chemicals

description: CDK inhibitor and nuclear anchor; during the cell cycle Far1p sequesters the GEF Cdc24p in the nucleus; phosphorylation by Cdc28p-Cln results in SCFCdc4 complex-mediated ubiquitin-dependent degradation, releasing Cdc24p for export and activation of GTPase Cdc42p; in response to pheromone, phosphorylation of Far1p by MAPK Fus3p results in association with, and inhibition of Cdc28p-Cln, as well as Msn5p mediated nuclear export of Far1p-Cdc24p, targeting Cdc24p to polarity sites
functionSummary: Serine/threonine cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor; required for G1 arrest in response to treatment with pheromone and for pheromone dependent signal transduction during conjugation; sequesters the guanine-nucleotide exchange factor Cdc24p in the nucleus; localizes to the nucleus, the cytosol, and the mating projection or shmoo tip
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant fails to arrest the cell cycle upon mating pheromone exposure; reduced expression causes smaller cell size while overexpression causes increased cell size; null mutant is defective for shmoo formation and mating; in large-scale studies the null mutant has altered resistance to a variety of chemicals, and overexpression is lethal

description: Cell-cycle checkpoint S/T protein kinase; required for transient G2/M arrest after DNA damage, damage-induced transcription, and nuclear-to-cytoplasmic redistribution of Rnr2p-Rnr4p after genotoxic stress and iron deprivation; phosphorylates repair protein Rad55p, transcriptional repressor Sml1p, superoxide dismutase, and ribonucleotide reductase inhibitors Crt1p and Dif1p; functions in the Mec1p pathway to regulate dNTP pools and telomere length; postreplicative repair role
functionSummary: Protein serine/threonine kinase involved in replication fork protection and the DNA damage checkpoint; localized to the nucleus in high-throughput studies
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays elevated chromosomal instability, gross chromosomal rearrangements, increased loss of heterozygosity and decreased telomere length; null mutant is also sensitive to agents that damage DNA and/or invoke replication stress such as: hydroxyurea, MMS, UV, idarubicin and aminopterin; null mutant has decreased competitive fitness during growth in various media; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient

briefDescription: Cell cycle-regulated gene of unknown function
description: Cell cycle-regulated gene of unknown function; promoter bound by Fkh2p; null mutant is sensitive to expression of the top1-T722A allele; TDA7 has a paralog, YDL211C, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the vacuole

briefDescription: Cell death protease essential for hypochlorite-induced apoptosis
description: Cell death protease essential for hypochlorite-induced apoptosis; involved in the processing of killer toxin and alpha factor precursor; cleaves Lys and Arg residues from the C-terminus of peptides and proteins

Cell fusion regulator; cytoplasmic protein localized to shmoo tip; required for alignment of parental nuclei before nuclear fusion during mating; contains a Dbl-homology domain; binds specifically with activated Cdc42p
functionSummary: Protein involved in regulating the termination of mating projection growth as well as karyogamy during mating; localizes to nucleus and mating projection tip

briefDescription: Cell wall adhesin, expressed specifically during mating
description: Cell wall adhesin, expressed specifically during mating; may be involved in maintenance of cell wall integrity during mating; FIG2 has a paralog, AGA1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
Cell wall and vacuolar protein; required for wild-type resistance to vanadate; SVS1 has a paralog, SRL1, that arose from the whole genome duplication

briefDescription: Cell wall-associated protein involved in export of acetylated sterols
description: Cell wall-associated protein involved in export of acetylated sterols; member of the CAP protein superfamily (cysteine-rich secretory proteins (CRISP), antigen 5, and pathogenesis related 1 proteins); role in mating efficiency; expression of full-length transcript is daughter cell-specific; in response to alpha factor, a short transcript starting at +452 is expressed and the long form is repressed by Ste12p

briefDescription: Cell wall glycoprotein involved in beta-glucan assembly
description: Cell wall glycoprotein involved in beta-glucan assembly; serves as a K1 killer toxin membrane receptor

briefDescription: Cell-wall L-asparaginase II involved in asparagine catabolism
description: Cell-wall L-asparaginase II involved in asparagine catabolism; expression induced during nitrogen starvation; ORF contains a short non-coding RNA that enhances expression of full-length gene; likely arose in via horizontal gene transfer from the wine yeast Wickerhamomyces anomalus or a close relative; reference strain S288C has four copies of ASP3; ASP3-1 has a paralog, ASP3-3, that arose from a segmental duplication
functionSummary: Asparaginase involved in asparagine catabolism and the cellular response to nitrogen starvation; localized to the cell wall-bounded periplasmic space

briefDescription: Cell-wall L-asparaginase II involved in asparagine catabolism
description: Cell-wall L-asparaginase II involved in asparagine catabolism; expression induced during nitrogen starvation; ORF contains a short non-coding RNA that enhances expression of full-length gene; likely arose in via horizontal gene transfer from the wine yeast Wickerhamomyces anomalus or a close relative; reference strain S288C has four copies of ASP3; ASP3-2 has a paralog, ASP3-4, that arose from a segmental duplication
functionSummary: Asparaginase involved in asparagine catabolism and the cellular response to nitrogen starvation; localized to the cell wall-bounded periplasmic space
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; overexpression causes slow growth

briefDescription: Cell-wall L-asparaginase II involved in asparagine catabolism
description: Cell-wall L-asparaginase II involved in asparagine catabolism; expression induced during nitrogen starvation; ORF contains a short non-coding RNA that enhances expression of full-length gene; likely arose in via horizontal gene transfer from the wine yeast Wickerhamomyces anomalus or a close relative; reference strain S288C has four copies of ASP3; ASP3-3 has a paralog, ASP3-1, that arose from a segmental duplication
functionSummary: Asparaginase involved in asparagine catabolism and the cellular response to nitrogen starvation; localized to the cell wall-bounded periplasmic space
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; overexpression causes slow growth and increased resistance to rapamycin

briefDescription: Cell-wall L-asparaginase II involved in asparagine catabolism
description: Cell-wall L-asparaginase II involved in asparagine catabolism; expression induced during nitrogen starvation; ORF contains a short non-coding RNA that enhances expression of full-length gene; likely arose in via horizontal gene transfer from the wine yeast Wickerhamomyces anomalus or a close relative; reference strain S288C has four copies of ASP3; ASP3-4 has a paralog, ASP3-2, that arose from a segmental duplication
functionSummary: Asparaginase involved in asparagine catabolism and the cellular response to nitrogen starvation; localized to the cell wall-bounded periplasmic space
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; overexpression in Sigma1278b causes greatly increased filamentous growth

description: Cell wall mannoprotein; expressed under anaerobic conditions and required for anaerobic growth; transcription is also induced by cold shock; member of the Srp1p/Tip1p family of serine-alanine-rich proteins
functionSummary: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cell wall

description: Cell wall mannoprotein; expression is downregulated at acidic pH and induced by cold shock and anaerobiosis; abundance is increased in cells cultured without shaking; member of the Srp1p/Tip1p family of serine-alanine-rich proteins
Cell wall mannoprotein; has similarity to Tir1p, Tir2p, Tir3p, and Tir4p; expressed under anaerobic conditions, completely repressed during aerobic growth
functionSummary: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cell wall

description: Cell wall mannoprotein; has similarity to Tir1p, Tir2p, Tir3p, and Tir4p; expressed under anaerobic conditions, completely repressed during aerobic growth
functionSummary: Structural protein of the cell wall; contributes to cell wall organization, also implicated in sterol transport; localizes to the cell wall
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutation lowers resistance to streptomycin and slightly increases competitive fitness in systematic studies; overexpression reduces growth rate

description: Cell wall mannoprotein; has similarity to Tir1p, Tir2p, Tir3p, and Tir4p; member of the seripauperin multigene family encoded mainly in subtelomeric regions; expressed under anaerobic conditions, completely repressed during aerobic growth
functionSummary: Predicted cell wall protein whose biological role is unknown

description: Cell wall mannoprotein; has similarity to Tir1p, Tir2p, Tir3p, and Tir4p; member of the seripauperin multigene family encoded mainly in subtelomeric regions; expressed under anaerobic conditions, completely repressed during aerobic growth
functionSummary: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cell wall

description: Cell wall mannoprotein; member of Srp1p/Tip1p family of serine-alanine-rich proteins; expressed under anaerobic conditions and required for anaerobic growth; TIR3 has a paralog, TIR2, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cell wall

description: Cell wall mannoprotein; plays a role in maintenance of newly synthesized areas of cell wall; localizes to periphery of small buds, septum region of larger buds, and shmoo tip; CCW12 has a paralog, YDR134C, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Structural constituent of cell wall; involved in agglutination during conjugation and fungal cell wall organization; localizes to the bud tip and mating projection tip
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes abnormalities in bud and mating projection (shmoo) morphology, increased chitin deposition in cell wall, higher sensitivity to hypoosmotic stress and to cell wall-affecting chemicals (Congo Red, Calcofluor White); both null mutation and overexpression result in slow growth

briefDescription: Cell wall mannoprotein that localizes to birth scars of daughter cells
description: Cell wall mannoprotein that localizes to birth scars of daughter cells; linked to a beta-1,3- and beta-1,6-glucan heteropolymer through a phosphodiester bond; required for propionic acid resistance
functionSummary: A structural constituent of the cell wall involved in both fungal-type cell wall organization and ascospore-type prospore membrane assembly; localized in the cell wall, cellular birth scar, and prospore membrane
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant has thinner cell wall and shows increased sensitivity to acidic conditions; in systematic studies mutants exhibit elevated sensitivity to copper ions and quinine, and increased ability to form biofilms

description: Cell wall protein; YDR134C has a paralog, CCW12, that arose from the whole genome duplication; S. cerevisiae genome reference strain S288C contains an internal in-frame stop at codon 67, which in other strains encodes glutamine

briefDescription: Cell wall protein of unknown function
description: Cell wall protein of unknown function; localizes to the cytoplasm; deletion improves xylose fermentation in industrially engineered strains; YLR042C is not an essential gene
functionSummary: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cell wall

briefDescription: Cell wall protein related to glucanases
description: Cell wall protein related to glucanases; possibly involved in cell wall septation; member of the SUN family; SUN4 has a paralog, SIM1, that arose from the whole genome duplication

briefDescription: Cell wall protein that contains a putative GPI-attachment site
description: Cell wall protein that contains a putative GPI-attachment site; secreted by regenerating protoplasts; up-regulated by activation of the cell integrity pathway, as mediated by Rlm1p; upregulated by cell wall damage via disruption of FKS1; PST1 has a paralog, ECM33, that arose from the whole genome duplication

briefDescription: Cell wall protein with similarity to glucanases
description: Cell wall protein with similarity to glucanases; may play a role in conjugation during mating based on its regulation by Ste12p

briefDescription: Cell wall protein with similarity to glucanases
description: Cell wall protein with similarity to glucanases; may play a role in conjugation during mating based on mutant phenotype and its regulation by Ste12p; SWC10 has a paralog, SCW4, that arose from the whole genome duplication

briefDescription: Cell wall protein with similarity to glucanases
description: Cell wall protein with similarity to glucanases; scw4 scw10 double mutants exhibit defects in mating; SCW4 has a paralog, SCW10, that arose from the whole genome duplication
