description: Isoleucine tRNA (tRNA-Ile), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis

briefDescription: Isoleucine tRNA (tRNA-Ile), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Isoleucine tRNA (tRNA-Ile), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis

briefDescription: Isoleucine tRNA (tRNA-Ile), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Isoleucine tRNA (tRNA-Ile), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis

briefDescription: Isoleucine tRNA (tRNA-Ile), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Isoleucine tRNA (tRNA-Ile), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis

briefDescription: Isoleucine tRNA (tRNA-Ile), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Isoleucine tRNA (tRNA-Ile), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis

briefDescription: Isoleucine tRNA (tRNA-Ile), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Isoleucine tRNA (tRNA-Ile), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis

Isomaltase (alpha-1,6-glucosidase/alpha-methylglucosidase); preferred specificity for isomaltose, alpha-methylglucoside, and palatinose, but also exhibits alpha-1,2 glucosidase activity on sucrose and kojibiose, and can cleave the 1,3-alpha linkage of nigerose and turanose and the alpha-1,5 linkage of leucrose in vitro; not required for isomaltose utilization, but Ima2p overexpression allows the ima1 null mutant to grow on isomaltose

Isopentenyl diphosphate:dimethylallyl diphosphate isomerase; catalyzes an essential activation step in the isoprenoid biosynthetic pathway; required for viability; isopentenyl diphosphate:dimethylallyl diphosphate isomerase is also known as IPP isomerase
Isopropylmalate isomerase; catalyzes the second step in the leucine biosynthesis pathway
functionSummary: Isopropylmalate isomerase involved in leucine biosynthesis; catalyzes the conversion of 2-isopropylmalate to 3-isopropylmalate; localizes to the cytosol

description: JmjC domain-containing histone demethylase; targets tri- and dimethylated H3K36; associates with actively transcribed regions and promotes elongation; repressor of autophagy-related genes in nutrient-replete conditions; damage-responsive repressor of PHR1; phosphorylated by the Rad53p-dependent DNA damage checkpoint pathway and by a Rim1p-mediated event during starvation; target of stress-induced hormesis; RPH1 has a paralog, GIS1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Histone demethylase specific for K36 tri- and dimethylated histone H3; independently functions as a transcription factor that represses the expression of genes involved in autophagy and DNA repair; involved in transcriptional elongation

description: JmjC domain family histone demethylase; promotes global demethylation of H3K4 and repression of noncoding intergenic transcription during sporulation; removes methyl groups added by Set1p methyltransferase; negatively regulated by H3K14 acetylation; protein levels regulated by Not4p polyubiquitin-mediated degradation; regulates sporulation timing by extending period of active transcription in opposition to programmed global transcriptional quiescence; regulates rDNA silencing

briefDescription: JmjC domain family histone demethylase specific for H3-K36
description: JmjC domain family histone demethylase specific for H3-K36; similar to proteins found in human, mouse, drosophila, X. laevis, C. elegans, and S. pombe

K48-specific deubiquitinating (DUB) enzyme; MINDY family endo-type deubiquitinase that preferentially cleaves long K48-linked polyubiquitin chains between moieties; diploid deletion strain exhibits high budding index; GFP-fusion protein localizes to the cytoplasm endoplasmic reticulum and cell periphery in high-throughput studies; YPL191C has a paralog, YGL082W, that arose from the whole genome duplication; ortholog of human MINDY2/FAM63B
functionSummary: Evolutionarily-conserved K48-specific deubiquitinase involved in recycling ubiquitin from Ub-conjugated proteins destined for proteolysis; localizes to the cytoplasm

description: Karyopherin; a carrier protein involved in nuclear import of proteins; importin beta homolog
functionSummary: Nuclear import signal receptor that localizes to cytoplasm and nuclear periphery

description: Karyopherin; involved in nuclear import and export of proteins, including import of replication protein A and export of Far1p and transcription factors Swi5p, Swi6p, Msn2p, and Pho4p; required for re-export of mature tRNAs after their retrograde import from the cytoplasm; exportin-5 homolog

Karyopherin alpha homolog; forms a dimer with karyopherin beta Kap95p to mediate import of nuclear proteins, binds the nuclear localization signal of the substrate during import; involved in cotranslational protein degradation; binds ribosome-bound nascent polypeptides; Srp1p and Sts1p couple proteasomes to nascent polypeptides emerging from the ribosome for cotranslational degradation
functionSummary: Nuclear import signal receptor involved in NLS-bearing protein import into nucleus, protein targeting to membrane, and proteasome localization; subunit of NLS-dependent protein nuclear import complex; localizes to cytoplasm and nucleus

description: Karyopherin beta; forms a complex with Srp1p/Kap60p; interacts with nucleoporins to mediate nuclear import of NLS-containing cargo proteins via the nuclear pore complex; regulates PC biosynthesis; GDP-to-GTP exchange factor for Gsp1p

Karyopherin beta; mediates nuclear import of ribosomal proteins prior to assembly into ribosomes and import of histones H3 and H4; localizes to the nuclear pore, nucleus, and cytoplasm; exhibits genetic interactions with RAI1
functionSummary: Nuclear localization sequence-binding protein transporter that imports proteins to the nucleus; localizes to cytoplasmic stress granules and nuclear pores

description: Karyopherin beta; responsible for import of the Toa1p-Toa2p complex into the nucleus; binds to nucleoporins Nup1p and Nup2p; may play a role in regulation of pleiotropic drug resistance
functionSummary: Nuclear import signal receptor involved in protein import into nucleus and regulation of cell size; localizes to cytoplasm

briefDescription: Karyopherin/importin that interacts with the nuclear pore complex
description: Karyopherin/importin that interacts with the nuclear pore complex; acts as the nuclear import receptor for specific proteins, including Pdr1p, Yap1p, Ste12p, and Aft1p
functionSummary: Nuclear localization sequence-binding nuclear import signal receptor involved in protein import into nucleus, mRNA export from nucleus, regulation of protein desumoylation, and regulation of mitosis; localizes to cytoplasm and nucleus

briefDescription: Karyopherin, responsible for nuclear import of specific proteins
description: Karyopherin, responsible for nuclear import of specific proteins; cargoes include Spt15p, Sua7p, histones H2A and H2B, and Nap1p; amino terminus shows similarity to those of other importins, particularly Cse1p; localization is primarily nuclear; function is regulated by sumoylation; protein abundance increases in response to DNA replication stress
functionSummary: Nuclear protein importer that directs the movement of various protein cargoes from the cytoplasm to the nucleus

briefDescription: Karyopherin responsible for the nuclear import of Rpf1p
description: Karyopherin responsible for the nuclear import of Rpf1p; Rpf1p is a ribosome maturation factor
functionSummary: Nuclear localization sequence-binding nuclear import signal receptor that directs the movement of proteins from the cytoplasm to the nucleus

description: Ketopantoate hydroxymethyltransferase; required for pantothenic acid biosynthesis, converts 2-oxoisovalerate into 2-dehydropantoate
functionSummary: Mitochondrial 3-methyl-2-oxobutanoate hydroxymethyltransferase involved in biosynthesis of pantothenate

description: Kexin, a subtilisin-like protease (proprotein convertase); a calcium-dependent serine protease involved in the activation of proproteins of the secretory pathway
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to tacrolimus and zinc; in systematic studies null mutant shows defective endocytosis, reduced growth rate, greatly increased cell size, and increased sensitivity to multiple chemicals, including DTT, bleomycin, caffeine, tunicamycin, camptothecin, cyclosporin A, fluconazole hydroxyurea, MMS, rapamycin; overexpression in Sigma1278b increases invasive growth

briefDescription: Key component of the RAM signaling network
description: Key component of the RAM signaling network; required for proper cell morphogenesis and cell separation after mitosis

Kinesin-associated protein; required for both karyogamy and mitotic spindle organization, interacts stably and specifically with Kar3p and may function to target this kinesin to a specific cellular role; locus encodes a long and short transcript with differing functions; CIK1 has a paralog, VIK1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: ATP-dependent minus-end-directed microtubule motor subunit of kinesin complex; involved in meiosis, nuclear migration and karyogamy during mating, and regulation of mitotic spindle organization; localizes to nucleus and spindle pole body
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant produces abnormally large-budded cells and shows defective nuclear migration during pheromone-induced shmoo formation; null mutant is also sensitive to several chemicals, including hydroxyurea, staurosporin, Calcofluor White, tunicamycin; overexpression is lethal

description: Kinesin-like myosin passenger-protein; interacts with Myo2p and enhances its interaction with Sec4p during transport of secretory vesicles; controls actin cable structure and dynamics
Kinesin motor protein; involved in mitotic spindle assembly and chromosome segregation
functionSummary: ATP-dependent microtubule motor involved in microtubule depolymerization, mitotic spindle assembly and elongation, spindle pole body separation, and sister chromatid segregation; localizes to astral microtubules and condensed nuclear chromosome kinetochores
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays phenotypes associated with chromosome instability, such as abnormal chromosome segregation and cell cycle progression, and colony sectoring in a chromosome transmission fidelity (CTF) assay; in large-scale studies, null mutant cells are abnormally large, grow poorly, have increased mitophagy, and are sensitive to heat and various chemicals; heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient

description: Kinesin-related antiparallel sliding motor protein; involved in mitotic spindle positioning; sliding activity promotes bipolar spindle assembly and maintenance of genome stability; inhibits spindle elongation, destabilizing late anaphase spindle microtubules that polymerize beyond the midzone

Kinesin-related motor protein; required for mitotic spindle assembly, chromosome segregation, and 2 micron plasmid partitioning; functionally redundant with Cin8p for chromosomal but not plasmid functions
functionSummary: Subunit of the kinesin complex with microtubule motor activity; localized to the spindle and spindle pole body (SPB); involved in spindle related procecces, including spindle assembly/disassembly, SPB and sister chromatid separation

briefDescription: Kinesin-related motor protein involved in mitotic spindle positioning
description: Kinesin-related motor protein involved in mitotic spindle positioning; stabilizes microtubules by targeting Bik1p to the plus end; functions as a microtubule polymerase and catastrophe inhibitor in vitro; Kip2p levels are controlled during the cell cycle

Kinetochore-associated protein; required for chromosome segregation and kinetochore clustering; required for normal segregation of chromosomes in meiosis and mitosis; component of the FEAR regulatory network, which promotes Cdc14p release from the nucleolus during anaphase; potential Cdc28p substrate
functionSummary: Protein involved in centromere clustering, mitotic spindle organization, nuclear migration, chromosome segregation, activation of mitotic exit, and meiosis; localizes to kinetochore and spindle midzone

description: Kinetochore checkpoint WD40 repeat protein; localizes to kinetochores during prophase and metaphase, delays anaphase in the presence of unattached kinetochores; forms complexes with Mad1p-Bub1p and with Cdc20p, binds Mad2p and Mad3p; functions at kinetochore to activate APC/C-Cdc20p for normal mitotic progression
functionSummary: Ubiquitin-binding subunit of mitotic checkpoint complex; involved in mitotic DNA integrity checkpoint; localizes to condensed nuclear chromosome kinetochore
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays eleveated chromosome instability; in systematic studies null mutants show reduced growth rate, increased cell size, and sensitivity to multiple chemicals, including benomyl, bleomycin, caffeine, caspofungin, flucytosine, myriocin, but increased resistance to camptothecin, fluconazole, MMS, rapamycin

briefDescription: Kinetochore localized protein of unknown function
description: Kinetochore localized protein of unknown function; interacts with Cnn1p (CENP-T); orthologous to human centromere constitutive-associated network (CCAN) subunit CENP-W and fission yeast new1

Kinetochore protein; associated with the essential kinetochore proteins Nnf1p and Spc24p; phosphorylated by Clb5-Cdk1, Mps1p, Ipl1p and to a lesser extent by Clb2-Cdk1; localizes to the lower region of the Ndc80 complex during anaphase and regulates KMN activity by inhibiting the Mtw1 and Spc105 complexes from binding to the Ndc80 complex; similar to metazoan CENP-T
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes chromosome instability and significant defects in meiotic recombination; in systematic studies null mutants show reduced competitive fitness

description: Kynureninase; required for the de novo biosynthesis of NAD from tryptophan via kynurenine; expression regulated by Hst1p
functionSummary: Kynureninase involved in de novo NAD biosynthesis from tryptophan; localizes to both the cytoplasm and nucleus
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant is auxotrophic for nicotinic acid; in systematic studies null mutants show increased sensitivity to His3p inhibitor amitrole, increased resistance to antifungal drug miconazole, and increased accumulation of free amino acids

description: Kynurenine 3-monooxygenase; required for the de novo biosynthesis of NAD from tryptophan via kynurenine; expression regulated by Hst1p; putative therapeutic target for Huntington disease
functionSummary: Kynurenine 3-monooxygenase involved in de novo NAD biosynthesis from tryptophan; localizes to the mitochondrial outer membrane
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant is auxotrophic for nicotinic acid; systematic studies null mutant accumulates elevated amounts of free amino acids and shows reduced [GAR+] prion formation

description: Kynurenine aminotransferase; catalyzes formation of kynurenic acid from kynurenine; potential Cdc28p substrate
functionSummary: L-kynurenine and 2-aminoadipate transaminase; involved in the biosynthesis of kynurenic acid from kynurenine; localizes to both the cytoplasm and mitochondria
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant releases reduced amounts of volatile thiol 4-mercapto-4-methylpentan-2-one (4MMP), during wine fermentation; in systematic studies null mutant shows decreased endocytosis

description: Lanosterol 14-alpha-demethylase; catalyzes C-14 demethylation of lanosterol to form 4,4''-dimethyl cholesta-8,14,24-triene-3-beta-ol in ergosterol biosynthesis pathway; transcriptionally down-regulated when ergosterol is in excess; member of cytochrome P450 family; associated and coordinately regulated with the P450 reductase Ncp1p; human CYP51A1 functionally complements the lethality of the erg11 null mutation
functionSummary: Lanosterol 14-alpha-demethylase; catalyzes the demethylation of lanosterol during the biosynthesis of ergosterol; localizes to the endoplasmic reticulum
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene under standard growth conditions; null mutant is viable under anaerobic conditions and requires ergosterol for growth; down-regulation causes sensitivity to azole drugs and overexpression confers resistance; in large-scale studies, heterozygous null diploid is sensitive to heat and to toxic antimicrobial peptides

description: Lanosterol synthase; an essential enzyme that catalyzes the cyclization of squalene 2,3-epoxide, a step in ergosterol biosynthesis; human LSS functionally complements the lethality of the erg7 null mutation
functionSummary: Lanosterol synthase involved in ergosterol biosynthesis; localizes to lipid bodies
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; mutants require ergosterol, accumulate squalene and 2,3-epoxysqualene, and display abnormal lipid particle morphology; in large-scale studies, repressible mutant exhibits an Opi- phenotype (overproduction and excretion of inositol in the absence of inositol and choline) and displays abnormal mitochondrial morphology

briefDescription: Largest subunit of the Anaphase-Promoting Complex/Cyclosome
description: Largest subunit of the Anaphase-Promoting Complex/Cyclosome; APC/C is a ubiquitin-protein ligase required for degradation of anaphase inhibitors, including mitotic cyclins, during the metaphase/anaphase transition; component of the platform domain of the APC/C, based on structural analysis; localizes to nuclear foci that become diffuse upon DNA replication stress
functionSummary: Ubiquitin transferase that is a component of the anaphase-promoting complex involved in degradation of mitotic cyclins and transition from metaphase to anaphase during mitotic cell cycle
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; reduction of function increases competitive fitness

briefDescription: Largest subunit of the origin recognition complex
description: Largest subunit of the origin recognition complex; involved in directing DNA replication by binding to replication origins; also involved in transcriptional silencing; exhibits ATPase activity; ORC1 has a paralog, SIR3, that arose from the whole genome duplication

briefDescription: Largest subunit (p90) of the Chromatin Assembly Complex (CAF-1)
description: Largest subunit (p90) of the Chromatin Assembly Complex (CAF-1); chromatin assembly by CAF-1 is important for multiple processes including silencing at telomeres, mating type loci, and rDNA; maintenance of kinetochore structure; deactivation of the DNA damage checkpoint after DNA repair; chromatin dynamics during transcription; and repression of divergent noncoding transcription
functionSummary: Subunit of the chromatin assembly factor 1 (CAF-1) complex, which promotes histone H3 and H4 deposition onto newly synthesized DNA during replication or DNA repair; localizes to the centromeric region of chromosomes

briefDescription: Large subunit of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase
description: Large subunit of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase; carbamoyl phosphate synthetase catalyzes a step in the synthesis of citrulline, an arginine precursor
functionSummary: Subunit of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase that catalyzes the synthesis of carbamoyl phosphate from bicarbonate in the arginine biosynthesis pathway; localizes to the cytoplasm
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutation results in arginine auxotrophy and increased sensitivity to fluorouracil; overexpression increases resistance to fluorouracil and flucytosine; in systematic studies mutants show decreased competitive fitness

briefDescription: Large subunit of the dynactin complex
description: Large subunit of the dynactin complex; dynactin is involved in partitioning the mitotic spindle between mother and daughter cells; putative ortholog of mammalian p150(glued)

briefDescription: Large subunit of the nuclear mRNA cap-binding protein complex
description: Large subunit of the nuclear mRNA cap-binding protein complex; interacts with Npl3p to carry nuclear poly(A)+ mRNA to cytoplasm; also involved in nuclear mRNA degradation and telomere maintenance; orthologous to mammalian CBP80
functionSummary: mRNA-binding protein involved in splicing, nonsense-mediated decay, and response to osmotic stress; subunit of nuclear cap binding complex and also of spliceosomal commitment complex

briefDescription: Large subunit of trehalose 6-phosphate synthase/phosphatase complex
description: Large subunit of trehalose 6-phosphate synthase/phosphatase complex; Tps1p-Tps2p complex converts uridine-5'-diphosphoglucose and glucose 6-phosphate to trehalose; contributes to survival to acute lethal heat stress; mutant has aneuploidy tolerance; protein abundance increases in response to DNA replication stress; TSL1 has a paralog, TPS3, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Subunit of alpha,alpha-trehalose phosphate synthase complex that contributes to trehalose-phosphate synthase activity; involved in trehalose biosynthesis

briefDescription: Late endosomal protein involved in late endosome to vacuole transport
description: Late endosomal protein involved in late endosome to vacuole transport; functional homolog of human obesity receptor gene-related protein (OB-RGRP)

briefDescription: Lectin-like cell wall protein (flocculin) involved in flocculation
description: Lectin-like cell wall protein (flocculin) involved in flocculation; binds mannose chains on the surface of other cells, confers floc-forming ability that is chymotrypsin resistant but heat labile; important for co-flocculation with other yeasts, mediating interaction with specific species; FLO5 has a paralog, FLO1, that arose from a segmental duplication
functionSummary: Mannose-binding protein involved in flocculation and substrate adhesion; localizes to cell wall and cell periphery

description: Lectin-like protein involved in flocculation; cell wall protein that binds mannose chains on the surface of other cells, confers floc-forming ability that is chymotrypsin sensitive and heat resistant; important for co-flocculation with other yeasts, mediating interaction with specific species; FLO1 has a paralog, FLO5, that arose from a segmental duplication
functionSummary: Mannose-binding protein involved in flocculation via cell wall protein-carbohydrate interaction and co-flocculation with other yeasts; also involved in the cellular response to heat, hydrogen peroxide, and ethanol; localizes to the cell wall
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutation blocks flocculation while overexpression increases it; null mutant is sensitive to ethanol and oxidative stress, and shows reduced competitive fitness in minimal medium

briefDescription: Lectin-like protein with similarity to Flo1p
description: Lectin-like protein with similarity to Flo1p; thought to be expressed and involved in flocculation
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant has filamentous and invasive growth defects; overexpression results in increased in flocculation and adherence

briefDescription: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis

briefDescription: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow faster than wild-type when subjected to reducing agent 1,4-dithiothreitol

briefDescription: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow faster than wild-type when subjected to reducing agent 1,4-dithiothreitol

briefDescription: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow slowly under standard conditions, but grow faster than wild-type when subjected to reducing agent 1,4-dithiothreitol

briefDescription: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants have diminished capacity to utilize galactose as a carbon source, but grow faster than wild-type when subjected to reducing agent 1,4-dithiothreitol

briefDescription: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow faster than wild-type when subjected to reducing agent 1,4-dithiothreitol

briefDescription: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis

briefDescription: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants have diminished capacity to utilize galactose as a carbon source, but grow faster than wild-type when subjected to reducing agent 1,4-dithiothreitol

briefDescription: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow faster than wild-type when subjected to reducing agent 1,4-dithiothreitol

briefDescription: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow faster than wild-type when subjected to reducing agent 1,4-dithiothreitol

briefDescription: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants have diminished capacity to utilize galactose as a carbon source, and grow slowly in salt, but grow faster than wild-type when subjected to reducing agent 1,4-dithiothreitol

briefDescription: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow faster than wild-type when subjected to reducing agent 1,4-dithiothreitol

briefDescription: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis

briefDescription: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis

briefDescription: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants have diminished capacity to utilize galactose as a carbon source

briefDescription: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants have diminished capacity to utilize galactose as a carbon source, but grow faster than wild-type in other conditions

briefDescription: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis; can mutate to suppress amber nonsense mutations

briefDescription: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis; can mutate to suppress amber nonsense mutations

briefDescription: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis; can mutate to suppress amber nonsense mutations

briefDescription: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis; can mutate to suppress amber nonsense mutations
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants have diminished capacity to utilize galactose as a carbon source, and grow slowly in standard conditions or under glucose limitation, but grow faster than wild-type when subjected to reducing agent 1,4-dithiothreitol

briefDescription: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Leucine tRNA (tRNA-Leu), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis; not essential for viability even though this is the only tRNA that decodes GAG codons
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants have diminished capacity to utilize galactose as a carbon source, and grow slowly in salt, but grow faster than wild-type when subjected to reducing agent 1,4-dithiothreitol

description: Leucine-zipper transcriptional activator; responsible for regulation of sulfur amino acid pathway; requires different combinations of auxiliary factors Cbf1p, Met28p, Met31p and Met32p; feedforward loop exists in the regulation of genes controlled by Met4p and Met32p; can be ubiquitinated by ubiquitin ligase SCF-Met30p, is either degraded or maintained in an inactive state; regulates degradation of its own DNA-binding cofactors by targeting them to SCF-Met30p
functionSummary: Transcription coactivator and subunit of the Cbf1-Met4-Met28 complex, which activates the transcription of genes involved in sulfur amino acid metabolism; involved in the response to arsenic and cadmium

briefDescription: Leucyl aminopeptidase yscIV with epoxide hydrolase activity
description: Leucyl aminopeptidase yscIV with epoxide hydrolase activity; metalloenzyme containing one zinc atom; green fluorescent protein (GFP)-fusion protein localizes to the cytoplasm and nucleus; also known as leukotriene A4 hydrolase
L-homoserine-O-acetyltransferase; catalyzes the conversion of homoserine to O-acetyl homoserine which is the first step of the methionine biosynthetic pathway
functionSummary: L-homoserine-O-acetyltransferase; catalyzes the conversion of L-homoserine to O-acetyl L-homoserine; involved in methionine biosynthesis and homoserine metabolism; localizes to the cytoplasm in high-throughput studies

briefDescription: Linker nucleoporin component of the nuclear pore complex (NPC)
description: Linker nucleoporin component of the nuclear pore complex (NPC); also part of the NPC cytoplasmic filaments; contributes to nucleocytoplasmic transport and NPC biogenesis; forms stable associations with three FG-nucleoporins (Nsp1p, Nup159p, and Nup116p); relocalizes to the cytosol in response to hypoxia

briefDescription: Linker nucleoporin component of the nuclear pore complex (NPC)
description: Linker nucleoporin component of the nuclear pore complex (NPC); also part of the NPC nuclear basket; contributes to nucleocytoplasmic transport and NPC biogenesis; forms stable associations with three FG-nucleoporins (Nsp1p, Nup57p, and Nup49p)

briefDescription: Linker protein responsible for recruitment of myosin to the bud neck
description: Linker protein responsible for recruitment of myosin to the bud neck; interacts with the C-terminal extensions of septins Cdc11p and Shs1p and binds Myo1p to promote cytokinesis
functionSummary: Protein that binds to the septin ring at the bud neck; recruits myosin to the bud neck
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased competitive fitness on minimal medium; null mutant displays increased accumulation of serine; homozygous diploid null mutant is sensitive to treatment with various antimicrobial peptides; heterozygous diploid null is haploproficient in conditions that mimic Phase I of a batch fermentation

description: Lipase with specificity for monoacylglycerol; preferred substrate is 1-oleoylglycerol; null mutation affects lipid droplet morphology and overexpression causes increased accumulation of reactive oxygen species
functionSummary: Acylglycerol lipase with a role in lipid metabolism; localized to the cytoplasm and nucleus

briefDescription: Lipid-binding ER protein, enriched at nucleus-vacuolar junctions (NVJ)
description: Lipid-binding ER protein, enriched at nucleus-vacuolar junctions (NVJ); may be involved in sterol metabolism or signaling at the NVJ; contains a synaptotagmin-like-mitochondrial-lipid binding protein (SMP) domain; binds phosphatidylinositols and other lipids in a large-scale study; may interact with ribosomes, based on co-purification experiments
functionSummary: Lipid binding protein; localizes to nucleusvacuole junction and the endoplasmic reticulum

briefDescription: Lipid-binding ER protein involved in ER-plasma membrane tethering
description: Lipid-binding ER protein involved in ER-plasma membrane tethering; one of 6 proteins (Ist2p, Scs2p, Scs22p, Tcb1p, Tcb2p, Tcb3p) that connect ER to plasma membrane and regulate PI4P levels by controlling access of Sac1p phosphatase to its substrate PI4P in PM; contains 3 calcium and lipid binding domains; non-tagged protein also localizes to mitochondria; C-termini of Tcb1p, Tcb2p and Tcb3p interact; TCB1 has a paralog, TCB2, that arose from the whole genome duplication

briefDescription: Lipid-interacting protein in SNARE complex assembly machinery
description: Lipid-interacting protein in SNARE complex assembly machinery; acts at late step in secretion; interacts with membranes through two distinct binding sites; shows genetic and physical interactions with Sec1p; required for prospore membrane formation during sporulation; N-terminus closely associates with plasma membrane, C-terminus colocalizes with Sec4p on intracellular membranes; relocalizes from bud neck to nucleus upon DNA replication stress

Lipid phosphate phosphatase; catalyzes Mg(2+)-independent dephosphorylation of phosphatidic acid (PA), lysophosphatidic acid, and diacylglycerol pyrophosphate; involved in control of the cellular levels of phosphatidylinositol and PA

Lipid raft associated protein; interacts with the plasma membrane ATPase Pma1p and has a role in its targeting to the plasma membrane by influencing its incorporation into lipid rafts; sometimes classified in the medium-chain dehydrogenase/reductases (MDRs) superfamily; AST1 has a paralog, AST2, that arose from the whole genome duplication
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies null mutant shows increased sensitivity to oxidative stress and reduced competitive fitness

description: Lipid raft associated protein; overexpression restores Pma1p localization to lipid rafts which is required for targeting of Pma1p to the plasma membrane; sometimes classified in the medium-chain dehydrogenase/reductases (MDRs) superfamily; AST2 has a paralog, AST1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies homozygous null mutant diploid shows inositol auxotrophy and increased sensitivity to insecticide dieldrin; null mutant in Sigma1278b is incapable of invasive growth

description: Lipoyl ligase; involved in the modification of mitochondrial enzymes by the attachment of lipoic acid groups

Long-chain base-1-phosphate phosphatase; specific for dihydrosphingosine-1-phosphate, regulates ceramide and long-chain base phosphates levels, involved in incorporation of exogenous long chain bases in sphingolipids; LCB3 has a paralog, YSR3, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Dihydrosphingosine-1-phosphate phosphatase involved in sphingolipid metabolism; localized to endoplasmic reticulum

description: Long chain fatty acyl-CoA synthetase; activates fatty acids with a preference for C12:0-C16:0 chain lengths; role in the competitive import of long-chain fatty acids and sphingoid long-chain bases; accounts for most acyl-CoA synthetase activity; localizes to lipid particles and the plasma membrane; role in sphingolipid-to-glycerolipid metabolism; forms ER foci upon replication stress; faa1 faa4 double null complemented by any of human ACSBG1, ACSL1, 3, 4, 5, 6, SLC27A2, or 4
functionSummary: Fatty acid-CoA ligase involved in long-chain fatty acid metabolism and import; contributes to sphingoid transport; localizes to lipid bodies and plasma membrane and to mitochondrion and endoplasmic reticulum in high-throughput studies
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows reduced incorporation of myristate into phospholipids at elevated temperatures and reduced accumulation of long-chain fatty acids; null mutant is sensitive to cerulenin and displays decreased survival in stationary phase; in large-scale studies, homozygous null mutant displays increased competitive fitness; overproduction confers enhanced invasive growth

description: Long chain fatty acyl-CoA synthetase; activates fatty acids with a preference for C12:0-C16:0 chain lengths; role in the competitive import of long-chain fatty acids and sphingoid long-chain bases; role in stationary phase survival; localizes to lipid particles and the plasma membrane; role in sphingolipid-to-glycerolipid metabolism; forms cytoplasmic foci upon replication stress; faa1 faa4 double null complemented by any of human ACSBG1, ACSL1, 3, 4, 5, 6, SLC27A2, or 4
functionSummary: Long-chain fatty acid-CoA ligase involved in long-chain fatty acyl-CoA metabolism and long-chain fatty acid import; contributes to sphingoid transport; localizes to lipid bodies, plasma membrane, cytoplasmic stress granules and to cytoplasm in high-throughput studies
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant contains lower levels of long-chain acyl-CoA and shows decreased anaerobic growth and sensitivity to cicloheximide, neomycin and streptomycin

description: Long chain fatty acyl-CoA synthetase; activates imported fatty acids with a preference for C16:0-C18:0 chain lengths; green fluorescent protein (GFP)-fusion protein localizes to the cell periphery

Long intergenic regulatory ncRNA; has a key role in regulating transcription of the nearby protein-coding ORF FLO11; initiated far upstream from FLO11 and transcribed across much of the large promoter of FLO11, repressing FLO11 transcription in cis

briefDescription: Long noncoding RNA that governs mating-type control of gametogenesis
description: Long noncoding RNA that governs mating-type control of gametogenesis; located in the IME1 promoter; in haploids, expression of IME1, the central inducer of gametogenesis, is inhibited in cis by transcription of IRT1, which recruits the Set2p histone methyltransferase and the Set3p histone deacetylase complex to establish repressive chromatin at the IME1 promoter

L-ornithine transaminase (OTAse); catalyzes the second step of arginine degradation, expression is dually-regulated by allophanate induction and a specific arginine induction process; not nitrogen catabolite repression sensitive; protein abundance increases in response to DNA replication stress; human homolog OAT complements yeast null mutant
functionSummary: L-ornithine-oxo-acid transaminase, involved in arginine catabolism; localized to cytosol
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes slow growth and decreased innate thermotolerance; overexpression increases filamentous growth

description: Low-affinity amino acid permease; may act to supply the cell with amino acids as nitrogen source in nitrogen-poor conditions; transcription is induced under conditions of sulfur limitation; plays a role in regulating Ty1 transposition
functionSummary: Amino acid transmembrane transporter that localizes to the endoplasmic reticulum
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays increased competitive fitness in minimal medium; null mutant has increased resistance to DNA damaging agent, tirapazamine and lysophosphatidylcholine analogue, edelfosine; overexpression results in increased invasive growth

briefDescription: Low-affinity amino acid permease with broad substrate range
description: Low-affinity amino acid permease with broad substrate range; involved in uptake of asparagine, glutamine, and other amino acids; expression regulated by SPS plasma membrane amino acid sensor system (Ssy1p-Ptr3p-Ssy5p); AGP1 has a paralog, GNP1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Transmembrane transporter of L-proline; localizes to plasma membrane
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant has increased competitive fitness in minimal medium; homozygous diploid null mutant has an elevated chronological lifespan and accumulated glycogen; null mutant displays reduced apoptosis after a ramped heat stimulus, and has increased resistance to quinine, camptothecin and hydroxyurea; heterozygous null mutant is haploproficient; overexpression results in a decreased growth rate and increased invasive growth

briefDescription: Low-affinity copper transporter of the vacuolar membrane
description: Low-affinity copper transporter of the vacuolar membrane; mutation confers resistance to toxic copper concentrations, while overexpression confers resistance to copper starvation; regulated by nonsense-mediated mRNA decay pathway
functionSummary: Transmembrane transporter of copper ions, involved in intracellular copper homeostasis; localized to vacuolar membrane
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant is resistant to high copper levels and accumulates excess copper in vacuoles; overexpression prevents sensitivity to copper starvation

description: Low-affinity cyclic AMP phosphodiesterase; controls glucose and intracellular acidification-induced cAMP signaling, target of the cAMP-protein kinase A (PKA) pathway; glucose induces transcription and inhibits translation
functionSummary: 3',5'-cyclic-AMP phosphodiesterase involved in cAMP-mediated signaling; cellular location unknown
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant accumulates cAMP; overexpression causes decreased levels of cAMP and sensitivity to rapamycin

briefDescription: Low-affinity Fe(II) transporter of the plasma membrane
description: Low-affinity Fe(II) transporter of the plasma membrane

briefDescription: Low affinity glucose transporter of the major facilitator superfamily
description: Low affinity glucose transporter of the major facilitator superfamily; expression is induced in low or high glucose conditions; HXT3 has a paralog, HXT5, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Glucose transporter; involved in glucose uptake; localized to plasma membrane

briefDescription: Low-affinity glucose transporter of the major facilitator superfamily
description: Low-affinity glucose transporter of the major facilitator superfamily; expression is induced by Hxk2p in the presence of glucose and repressed by Rgt1p when glucose is limiting; HXT1 has a paralog, HXT6, what arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Hexose and pentose transmembrane transporter of the plasma membrane
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes decreased transport of glucose and mannose across the plasma membrane, and increased resistance to quinine; in systematic studies null mutant shows increased lifespan; overexpression results in decreased growth rate

description: Low-affinity inorganic phosphate (Pi) transporter; acts upstream of Pho81p in regulation of the PHO pathway; expression is independent of Pi concentration and Pho4p activity; contains 12 membrane-spanning segments; PHO87 has a paralog, PHO90, that arose from the whole genome duplication
Low affinity methionine permease; similar to Mup1p
Low affinity NH4+ transporter; member of the DHA2 family of drug:H+ anti porters; putative paralog of ATR1; but not required for boron tolerance; non-essential gene
functionSummary: Ammonium transmembrane transporter; localizes to plasma membrane and cell periphery
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased competitive fitness in minimal medium

description: Low-affinity phosphate transporter; acts upstream of Pho81p in regulation of the PHO pathway; deletion of pho84, pho87, pho89, pho90, and pho91 causes synthetic lethality; transcription independent of Pi and Pho4p activity; overexpression results in vigorous growth; PHO90 has a paralog, PHO87, that arose from the whole genome duplication

Low-affinity vacuolar phosphate transporter; exports phosphate from the vacuolar lumen to the cytosol; regulates phosphate and polyphosphate metabolism; acts upstream of Pho81p in regulation of the PHO pathway; localizes to sites of contact between the vacuole and mitochondria (vCLAMPs); deletion of pho84, pho87, pho89, pho90, and pho91 causes synthetic lethality; transcription independent of Pi and Pho4p activity; overexpression results in vigorous growth

briefDescription: Low-affinity zinc transporter of the plasma membrane
description: Low-affinity zinc transporter of the plasma membrane; transcription is induced under low-zinc conditions by the Zap1p transcription factor
functionSummary: Low-affinity zinc transmembrane transporter of the plasma membrane involved in zinc ion transport
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants have low intracellular zinc levels, have abnormal vacuolar morphology, are resistant to heat, carcinogen toxaphene, serine C-palmitoyltransferase inhibitor myriocin, tin dichloride, and show increased competitive fitness as haploids in rich medium but decreased competive fitness as haploids in minimal medium and as diploids under batch fermentation conditions; null mutants are sensitive to tellurite, cadmium; heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient

description: Low complexity protein; mediates inhibition of Mep1p and Mep3p activity; hyperphosphorylated upon rapamycin treatment in a Tap42p-dependent manner; green fluorescent protein (GFP)-fusion protein localizes to the cytoplasm; phosphorylation and localization regulated by TORC1-effector kinase, Npr1p
functionSummary: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cytoplasm in a large-scale study

description: Lsm (Like Sm) protein; forms heteroheptameric complex (with Lsm2p, Lsm3p, Lsm4p, Lsm5p, Lsm6p, and Lsm7p) involved in degradation of cytoplasmic mRNAs; also enters the nucleus and positively regulates transcription initiation; unlike most Sm-like proteins, Lsm1p requires both its SM-domain and C-terminal domain for RNA-binding; binds to mRNAs under glucose starvation, most often in the 3' UTR; forms cytoplasmic foci upon DNA replication stress

Lsm (Like Sm) protein; forms heteroheptameric complex (with Lsm2p, Lsm3p, Lsm4p, Lsm5p, Lsm6p, and Lsm7p) that is part of spliceosomal U6 snRNP and is also implicated in processing of pre-tRNA, pre-snoRNA, and pre-rRNA

Lsm (Like Sm) protein; part of heteroheptameric complexes (Lsm2p-7p and either Lsm1p or 8p): cytoplasmic Lsm1p complex involved in mRNA decay; nuclear Lsm8p complex part of U6 snRNP and possibly involved in processing tRNA, snoRNA, and rRNA
functionSummary: U4/U6 x U5 tri-small nucleolar RNP (snRNP) complex and Lsm1-7-Pat1 complex subunit; involved in messenger RNA (mRNA) splicing and nuclear-transcribed mRNA degradation; localizes to U6 small nucleolar RNP (snRNP)
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene under aerobic condition; null mutant is viable but slow-growing under anaerobic conditions

description: Lsm (Like Sm) protein; part of heteroheptameric complexes (Lsm2p-7p and either Lsm1p or 8p): cytoplasmic Lsm1p complex involved in mRNA decay; nuclear Lsm8p complex part of U6 snRNP and possibly involved in processing tRNA, snoRNA, and rRNA

Lsm (Like Sm) protein; part of heteroheptameric complexes (Lsm2p-7p and either Lsm1p or 8p): cytoplasmic Lsm1p complex involved in mRNA decay; nuclear Lsm8p complex part of U6 snRNP and possibly involved in processing tRNA, snoRNA, and rRNA; forms cytoplasmic foci upon DNA replication stress
functionSummary: U6 small nuclear RNA (snRNA) binding protein involved in messenger RNA (mRNA) splicing and cytoplasmic mRNA processing body assembly; localizes to P-body, U6 small nucleolar RNP (snRNP), U4/U6 x U5 tri-snRNP complex and Lsm1-7-Pat1 complex
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; repression leads to sensitivity to acetate and caffeine; haploinsufficient

description: Lsm (Like Sm) protein; part of heteroheptameric complexes (Lsm2p-7p and either Lsm1p or 8p): cytoplasmic Lsm1p complex involved in mRNA decay; nuclear Lsm8p complex part of U6 snRNP and possibly involved in processing tRNA, snoRNA, and rRNA; protein abundance increases and forms cytoplasmic foci in response to DNA replication stress

Lsm (Like Sm) protein; part of heteroheptameric complexes (Lsm2p-7p and either Lsm1p or 8p): cytoplasmic Lsm1p complex involved in mRNA decay; nuclear Lsm8p complex part of U6 snRNP and possibly involved in processing tRNA, snoRNA, and rRNA; protein increases in abundance and relocalizes from nucleus to cytoplasmic foci upon DNA replication stress

Lsm (Like Sm) protein; part of heteroheptameric complexes (Lsm2p-7p and either Lsm1p or 8p): cytoplasmic Lsm1p complex involved in mRNA decay; nuclear Lsm8p complex part of U6 snRNP and possibly involved in processing tRNA, snoRNA, and rRNA; relocalizes from nucleus to cytoplasmic foci upon DNA replication stress
Lumazine synthase (DMRL synthase); catalyzes synthesis of immediate precursor to riboflavin; DMRL synthase stands for 6,7-dimethyl-8-ribityllumazine synthase

briefDescription: Lunapark family member involved in ER network formation
description: Lunapark family member involved in ER network formation; regulates the ER asymmetry-induced inheritance block during ER stress; localizes to ER junctions and this localization is regulated by the yeast atlastin ortholog Sey1p; required for reticulophagy where it is proposed to stabilize the actin-dependent remodeling of the ER; interacts with the reticulon protein Rtn1p; induced in response to the DNA-damaging agent MMS

Lysine methyltransferase; involved in the dimethylation of eEF1A (Tef1p/Tef2p) at lysine 316; sequence similarity to S-adenosylmethionine-dependent methyltransferases of the seven beta-strand family; role in vesicular transport
functionSummary: S-adenosylmethionine-dependent lysine methyltransferase; catalyzes the dimethylation of translational elongation factor EF-1 alpha (Tef1p/Tef2p); role in vesicle-mediated transport; localizes to the cytoplasm

description: Lysine methyltransferase; involved in the monomethylation of eEF1A (Tef1p/Tef2p); SET-domain family member; predicted involvement in ribosome biogenesis; green fluorescent protein (GFP)-fusion protein localizes to the cytoplasm
functionSummary: S-adenosylmethionine-dependent lysine methyltransferase; catalyzes the monomethylation of translational elongation factor EF-1 alpha (Tef1p/Tef2p); localizes to the cytoplasm

description: Lysine permease; one of three amino acid permeases (Alp1p, Can1p, Lyp1p) responsible for uptake of cationic amino acids
functionSummary: Basic amino acid permease; localizes to mitochondria and eisosomes

briefDescription: Lysine-specific metalloprotease of the pitrilysin family
description: Lysine-specific metalloprotease of the pitrilysin family; metalloprotease of the intermembrane space; degrades proteins and presequence peptides cleaved from imported proteins; required for normal mitochondrial morphology
functionSummary: Metalloendopeptidase that hydrolyzes internal alpha-peptide bonds in presequence peptides cleaved from proteins imported into mitochondria; localizes in mitochondrial intermembrane space
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant has abnormal mitochondrial morphology and respiratory growth defects; in systematic studies mutants exhibit reduced competitive fitness and elevated sensitivity to neomycin, hydroxyurea, bleomycin and myriocin; overexpression causes increased frequency of chromosome loss

briefDescription: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis; a small portion is imported into mitochondria via interaction with mt lysyl-tRNA synthetase Msk1p and is necessary to decode AAG codons at high temperature, when base modification of mt-encoded tRNA-Lys is reduced

briefDescription: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis; a small portion is imported into mitochondria via interaction with mt lysyl-tRNA synthetase Msk1p and is necessary to decode AAG codons at high temperature, when base modification of mt-encoded tRNA-Lys is reduced

briefDescription: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis; a small portion is imported into mitochondria via interaction with mt lysyl-tRNA synthetase Msk1p and is necessary to decode AAG codons at high temperature, when base modification of mt-encoded tRNA-Lys is reduced
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants have diminished capacity to utilize galactose as a carbon source, and grow slowly when subjected to reducing agent 1,4-dithiothreitol

briefDescription: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis; a small portion is imported into mitochondria via interaction with mt lysyl-tRNA synthetase Msk1p and is necessary to decode AAG codons at high temperature, when base modification of mt-encoded tRNA-Lys is reduced
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow faster than wild-type when subjected to reducing agent 1,4-dithiothreitol

briefDescription: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis; a small portion is imported into mitochondria via interaction with mt lysyl-tRNA synthetase Msk1p and is necessary to decode AAG codons at high temperature, when base modification of mt-encoded tRNA-Lys is reduced

description: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis; a small portion is imported into mitochondria via interaction with mt lysyl-tRNA synthetase Msk1p and is necessary to decode AAG codons at high temperature, when base modification of mt-encoded tRNA-Lys is reduced

description: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis; a small portion is imported into mitochondria via interaction with mt lysyl-tRNA synthetase Msk1p and is necessary to decode AAG codons at high temperature, when base modification of mt-encoded tRNA-Lys is reduced

description: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis; a small portion is imported into mitochondria via interaction with mt lysyl-tRNA synthetase Msk1p and is necessary to decode AAG codons at high temperature, when base modification of mt-encoded tRNA-Lys is reduced

description: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis; a small portion is imported into mitochondria via interaction with mt lysyl-tRNA synthetase Msk1p and is necessary to decode AAG codons at high temperature, when base modification of mt-encoded tRNA-Lys is reduced

description: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis; a small portion is imported into mitochondria via interaction with mt lysyl-tRNA synthetase Msk1p and is necessary to decode AAG codons at high temperature, when base modification of mt-encoded tRNA-Lys is reduced

description: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis; a small portion is imported into mitochondria via interaction with mt lysyl-tRNA synthetase Msk1p and is necessary to decode AAG codons at high temperature, when base modification of mt-encoded tRNA-Lys is reduced

briefDescription: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis; a small portion is imported into mitochondria via interaction with mt lysyl-tRNA synthetase Msk1p and is necessary to decode AAG codons at high temperature, when base modification of mt-encoded tRNA-Lys is reduced

briefDescription: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis; thiolation of uridine at wobble position (34) requires Ncs6p
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow slowly under various conditions, but grow faster than wild-type when subjected to reducing agent 1,4-dithiothreitol

briefDescription: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis; thiolation of uridine at wobble position (34) requires Ncs6p
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow slowly, but grow faster than wild-type when subjected to reducing agent 1,4-dithiothreitol

briefDescription: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis; thiolation of uridine at wobble position (34) requires Ncs6p
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants have diminished capacity to utilize galactose as a carbon source

briefDescription: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis; thiolation of uridine at wobble position (34) requires Ncs6p
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow slowly under glucose limitation, but grow faster than wild-type when subjected to reducing agent 1,4-dithiothreitol

briefDescription: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis; thiolation of uridine at wobble position (34) requires Ncs6p
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow faster than wild-type when subjected to reducing agent 1,4-dithiothreitol

briefDescription: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis; thiolation of uridine at wobble position (34) requires Ncs6p

briefDescription: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis
description: Lysine tRNA (tRNA-Lys), predicted by tRNAscan-SE analysis; thiolation of uridine at wobble position (34) requires Ncs6p
Lysophosphatidic acid acyltransferase; involved in triacelglyceride homeostasis and lipid droplet formation; localized to lipid droplets and the ER; specificity for oleoyl-CoA

Lysophosphatidic acid acyltransferase; responsible for enhanced phospholipid synthesis during organic solvent stress; null displays increased sensitivity to Calcofluor white; highly expressed during organic solvent stress; ICT1 has a paralog, ECM18, that arose from the whole genome duplication; human ABHD5 can complement ict1 null mutant
functionSummary: Lysophosphatidic acid acyltransferase involved in the biosynthesis of phosphatidic acid
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to azole drugs; overexpression increases resistance to azoles and benomyl

description: Lysophosphatidic acid (LPA) phosphatase, nucleotidase; principle and physiological nucleotidase working on GMP, UMP and CMP; involved in LPA hydrolysis in response to phosphate starvation and ribose salvage pathway; phosphatase activity is soluble and Mg2+ dependent; expression is induced by low phosphate levels and by inactivation of Pho85p; repressed by Gcn4p under normal conditions; PHM8 has a paralog, SDT1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Lysophosphatidic acid phosphatase with nucleotidase activity; involved in a cell's response to phosphate or carbon starvation as well as nucleotide catabolism

description: Lyso-phosphatidylcholine acyltransferase; required for normal phospholipid content of mitochondrial membranes; major determinant of the final acyl chain composition of the mitochondrial-specific phospholipid cardiolipin; mutations in human ortholog tafazzin (TAZ) cause Barth syndrome, a rare X-linked disease characterized by skeletal and cardiomyopathy and bouts of cyclic neutropenia; a specific splice variant of human TAZ can complement yeast null mutant
functionSummary: Lysolecithin acyltransferase involved in phospholipid biosynthesis and cardiolipin acyl-chain remodeling; role in organization of inner mitochondrial membrane, mitochondrial ATP synthesis coupled electron transport, mitochondrial respiratory chain supercomplex assembly; integral to outer mitochondrial membrane
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants are subject to chromosome instability, sensitive to osmotic stress and starvation, have abnormal mitochondria and are impaired in respiration; overexpression enhances pseudohyphal growth in strain Sigma1278b

description: Lysyl-tRNA synthetase
functionSummary: Cytoplasmic lysyl-tRNA synthetase that catalyzes lysyl-tRNA aminoacylation through the coupling of lysine to lysyl-tRNA
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; in large-scale studies, repression causes telomere shortening, reduced competitive fitness, and MMS sensitivity; uncharacterized mutation confers cycloheximide resistance; diploid heterozygous null mutant is haploinsufficient

description: m(7)GpppX pyrophosphatase regulator; non-essential, stress induced regulatory protein; modulates m7G-oligoribonucleotide metabolism; inhibits Dcs1p; regulated by Msn2p, Msn4p, and the Ras-cAMP-cAPK signaling pathway; mutant has increased aneuploidy tolerance; DCS2 has a paralog, DCS1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: A m7G(5')pppN diphosphatase involved in deadenylation-dependent decapping of nuclear-transcribed mRNA and cellular response to starvation; found in cytoplasmic mRNA processing body
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows slow growth and increased survival in stationary phase; in systematic studies mutants display increased competitive fitness

description: MADS-box transcription factor; component of the protein kinase C-mediated MAP kinase pathway involved in the maintenance of cell integrity; phosphorylated and activated by the MAP-kinase Slt2p; RLM1 has a paralog, SMP1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Sequence-specific DNA-binding RNA polymerase II transcription factor involved in signal transduction; activates gene expression in response to cell wall stress and heat; localizes to the nucleus

briefDescription: MADS-box transcription factor involved in osmotic stress response
description: MADS-box transcription factor involved in osmotic stress response; SMP1 has a paralog, RLM1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
Magnesium-dependent acid phosphatase; member of the haloacid dehalogenase superfamily; non-essential gene
functionSummary: Protein tyrosine phosphatase involved in peptidyl-tyrosine dephosphorylation

briefDescription: Major ADP/ATP carrier of the mitochondrial inner membrane
description: Major ADP/ATP carrier of the mitochondrial inner membrane; exchanges cytosolic ADP for mitochondrially synthesized ATP; also imports heme and ATP; required for viability in many lab strains that carry a sal1 mutation; PET9 has a paralog, AAC3, that arose from the whole genome duplication; human homolog SLC25A4 implicated in progressive external ophthalmoplegia can complement yeast null mutant
functionSummary: ATP/ADP exchanger of the mitochondrial inner membrane involved in respiration and apoptosis
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene in W303, essential gene in other strain backgrounds; null mutants grow slowly, cannot respire, are sensitive to heat and cold; missense mutants that correspond to human disease mutations display electron transport chain damage, hypersensitivity to the chemical uncoupler CCCP, mtDNA instability, and intolerance to mtDNA loss; overexpression slows growth

description: Major apurinic/apyrimidinic endonuclease; 3'-repair diesterase; involved in repair of DNA damage by oxidation and alkylating agents; also functions as a 3'-5' exonuclease to repair 7,8-dihydro-8-oxodeoxyguanosine; genetically interacts with NTG1 to maintain mitochondrial genome integrity
functionSummary: Multifunctional 3'-5' exodeoxyribonuclease, phosphoric diester hydrolase, and AP lyase involved in base-excision repair; localizes to nucleus and mitochondria
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant is sensitive to DNA-damaging factors, including UV, gamma rays, 5-fluorouracil, MMS; also shows increased mutation frequency and loss of mitochondrial genome

briefDescription: Major cell wall mannoprotein with possible lipase activity
description: Major cell wall mannoprotein with possible lipase activity; transcription is induced by heat- and cold-shock; member of the Srp1p/Tip1p family of serine-alanine-rich proteins

briefDescription: Major CTP synthase isozyme (see also URA8)
description: Major CTP synthase isozyme (see also URA8); catalyzes the ATP-dependent transfer of the amide nitrogen from glutamine to UTP, forming CTP, the final step in de novo biosynthesis of pyrimidines; involved in phospholipid biosynthesis; capable of forming cytoplasmic filaments termed cytoophidium, especially during conditions of glucose depletion; URA7 has a paralog, URA8, that arose from the whole genome duplication

briefDescription: Major exo-1,3-beta-glucanase of the cell wall
description: Major exo-1,3-beta-glucanase of the cell wall; involved in cell wall beta-glucan assembly; exists as three differentially glycosylated isoenzymes; EXG1 has a paralog, SPR1, that arose from the whole genome duplication

briefDescription: Major isoform of large subunit of ribonucleotide-diphosphate reductase
description: Major isoform of large subunit of ribonucleotide-diphosphate reductase; the RNR complex catalyzes rate-limiting step in dNTP synthesis, regulated by DNA replication and DNA damage checkpoint pathways via localization of small subunits; relative distribution to the nucleus increases upon DNA replication stress; RNR1 has a paralog, RNR3, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Subunit of the ribonucleoside-diphosphate reductase complex; nucleotide-binding protein that contributes to the ribonucleoside-diphosphate reductase activity of the complex; involved in deoxyribonucleotide biosynthesis and localizes to the cytoplasm
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene in S288C; in some strains null mutation results in terminal cell cycle arrest at S phase after spore germination; mutations in W303 affect telomere length; in systematic studies in S288C null mutants grow slowly, have enlarged cells and abnormally elongated buds and show elevated sensitivity to heat, various metals, oxidative stress, and multiple drugs, including azoles, cyclosporin A, hygromycin B

description: Major isoform of tropomyosin; binds to and stabilizes actin cables and filaments, which direct polarized cell growth and the distribution of several organelles; acetylated by the NatB complex and acetylated form binds actin most efficiently; TPM1 has a paralog, TPM2, that arose from the whole genome duplication

Major isomaltase (alpha-1,6-glucosidase/alpha-methylglucosidase); required for isomaltose utilization; preferred specificity for isomaltose, alpha-methylglucoside, and palatinose, but also exhibits alpha-1,2 glucosidase activity on sucrose and kojibiose, and can cleave the 1,3-alpha linkage of nigerose and turanose and the alpha-1,5 linkage of leucrose in vitro; member of the IMA isomaltase family
Major isozyme of methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase; catalyzes the reduction of 5,10-methylenetetrahydrofolate to 5-methyltetrahydrofolate in the methionine biosynthesis pathway
functionSummary: Methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (NAD(P)H) involved in methionine biosynthesis; localizes to mitochondrion in high-throughput studies
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant requires methionine; homozygous null mutant diploid accumulates elevated levels of tellurium and displays resistance to tellurite; in large-scale studies, null mutant exhibits either increased or decreased competitive fitness in different media, increased glycogen accumulation, increased filamentous growth, and decreased sporulation with altered spore wall composition

description: Major karyopherin; involved in export of proteins, RNAs, and ribosomal subunits from the nucleus; exportin
functionSummary: Nuclear import signal receptor involved in export of mRNA, proteins, and large ribosomal subunits from the nucleus; also involved in protein localization to the kinetochore; localizes to the nucleus, spindle pole body, and kinetochore
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; conditional (ts) mutations cause defects in actin cytoskeleton and endocytosis at both permissive and restrictive temperatures, and lead to reduced nuclear export of poly(A)+ RNA and abnormal distribution of reporter proteins; overexpression results in slow growth and increased frequency of chromosome loss and rearrangements

description: Major mitochondrial D-lactate dehydrogenase; oxidizes D-lactate to pyruvate, transcription is heme-dependent, repressed by glucose, and derepressed in ethanol or lactate; located in the mitochondrial inner membrane
functionSummary: Major D-lactate dehydrogenase oxidizing D-lactate to pyruvate; role in lactate catabolism; localizes to the mitochondrial inner membrane
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutation accumulates lactate; in competitive growth studies null mutation increases competitive fitness

description: Major mitochondrial nuclease; has RNAse and DNA endo- and exonucleolytic activities; roles in mitochondrial recombination, apoptosis and maintenance of polyploidy; involved in fragmentation of genomic DNA during PND (programmed nuclear destruction); encodes ortholog of mammalian endoG

briefDescription: Major of three pyruvate decarboxylase isozymes
description: Major of three pyruvate decarboxylase isozymes; key enzyme in alcoholic fermentation; decarboxylates pyruvate to acetaldehyde; involved in amino acid catabolism; subject to glucose-, ethanol-, and autoregulation; activated by phosphorylation in response to glucose levels; N-terminally propionylated in vivo
functionSummary: Pyruvate decarboxylase involved in amino acid catabolism and the fermentation of glucose to ethanol; localizes to both the nucleus and the cytosol
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows slow growth rate; in large-scale studies, null mutant exhibits decreased competitive fitness, heat sensitivity, and altered resistance to various chemicals

description: Major orotate phosphoribosyltransferase (OPRTase) isozyme; catalyzes the fifth enzymatic step in de novo biosynthesis of pyrimidines, converting orotate into orotidine-5'-phosphate; URA5 has a paralog, URA10, that arose from the whole genome duplication

briefDescription: Major stress-induced structural GPI-cell wall glycoprotein
description: Major stress-induced structural GPI-cell wall glycoprotein; associates with translating ribosomes, possible role in mitochondrial genome maintenance; ORF contains two distinct variable minisatellites; SED1 has a paralog, SPI1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Structural constituent of the cell wall; involved in cell wall organization and mitochondrial genome maintenance; localizes to the cell wall, ribosome, and mitochondrion

briefDescription: Major transcriptional repressor of DNA-damage-regulated genes
description: Major transcriptional repressor of DNA-damage-regulated genes; recruits repressors Tup1p and Cyc8p to their promoters; involved in DNA damage and replication checkpoint pathway; similar to a family of mammalian DNA binding RFX1-4 proteins
MAL-activator protein; part of complex locus MAL1; nonfunctional in genomic reference strain S288C
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant cannot utilize maltose; in large-scale studies, null mutant shows reduced competitive fitness and starvation resistance, and is sensitive to various chemicals

description: MAL-activator protein; part of complex locus MAL3; nonfunctional in genomic reference strain S288C

Malate synthase; can accept butyryl-CoA as acyl-CoA donor in addition to traditional substrate acetyl-CoA; recycles glyoxylate generated during allantoin degradation; SWAT-GFP and mCherry fusion proteins localize to the cytosol; expression sensitive to nitrogen catabolite repression and induced by allophanate, an intermediate in allantoin degradation
functionSummary: A malate synthase involved in the breakdown of allantoin; localizes to the cytosol
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows increased sensitivity to paromomycin and increased competitive fitness in systematic studies

briefDescription: Malate synthase, enzyme of the glyoxylate cycle
description: Malate synthase, enzyme of the glyoxylate cycle; involved in utilization of non-fermentable carbon sources; expression is subject to carbon catabolite repression; localizes in peroxisomes during growth on oleic acid, otherwise cytosolic; can accept butyryl-CoA as acyl-CoA donor in addition to traditional substrate acetyl-CoA
functionSummary: Malate synthase involved in the glyoxylate cycle; localizes to the cytosol and the peroxisomal matrix

description: Maltase (alpha-D-glucosidase); inducible protein involved in maltose catabolism; encoded in the MAL1 complex locus; hydrolyzes the disaccharides maltose, turanose, maltotriose, and sucrose

Maltase (alpha-D-glucosidase); inducible protein involved in maltose catabolism; encoded in the MAL3 complex locus; functional in genomic reference strain S288C; hydrolyzes the disaccharides maltose, turanose, maltotriose, and sucrose

Maltose permease; high-affinity maltose transporter (alpha-glucoside transporter); encoded in the MAL3 complex locus; member of the 12 transmembrane domain superfamily of sugar transporters; functional in genomic reference strain S288C
Mannitol dehydrogenase; deletion suppresses mutation of mpt5; DSF1 has a paralog, MAN2, that arose from a segmental duplication
functionSummary: Mannitol dehydrogenase  whose biological role and cellular location are unknown
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; overexpression increases resistance to rapamycin

description: Mannitol dehydrogenase; MAN2 has a paralog, DSF1, that arose from a segmental duplication

briefDescription: Mannoprotein that exhibits a tight association with the cell wall
description: Mannoprotein that exhibits a tight association with the cell wall; required for cell wall stability in the absence of GPI-anchored mannoproteins; has a high serine-threonine content; expression is induced in cell wall mutants; SRL1 has a paralog, SVS1, that arose from the whole genome duplication

briefDescription: Mannoprotein that is incorporated into the cell wall
description: Mannoprotein that is incorporated into the cell wall; incorporated via a glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor; involved in the retention of siderophore-iron in the cell wall

briefDescription: Mannoprotein that is incorporated into the cell wall
description: Mannoprotein that is incorporated into the cell wall; incorporated via a glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor; involved in the retention of siderophore-iron in the cell wall

briefDescription: Mannoprotein that is incorporated into the cell wall
description: Mannoprotein that is incorporated into the cell wall; incorporated via a glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchor; involved in the retention of siderophore-iron in the cell wall
Mannose-6-phosphate isomerase; catalyzes the interconversion of fructose-6-P and mannose-6-P; required for early steps in protein mannosylation

briefDescription: Mannose-containing glycoprotein constituent of the cell wall
description: Mannose-containing glycoprotein constituent of the cell wall; member of the PIR (proteins with internal repeats) family
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutation causes defects indicative of weakened cell walls, such as reduced resistance to low pH,  SDS, Calcofluor White and caffeine; null mutant is also sensitive to amphotericin B but resistant to cystamine; null mutant has lower survival rate in stationary phase; in systematic studies null mutant is auxotrophic for inositol and has higher competitive fitness

description: Mannosylinositol phosphorylceramide (MIPC) synthase catalytic subunit; forms a complex with regulatory subunit Csg2p; function in sphingolipid biosynthesis is overlapping with that of Csh1p; SUR1 has a paralog, CSH1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Catalytic subunit of mannosylinositol phosphorylceramide (MIPC) synthase; required for biosynthesis of mature sphingolipids; predicted to be integral to membranes

description: Mannosylinositol phosphorylceramide (MIPC) synthase catalytic subunit; forms a complex with regulatory subunit Csg2p; function in sphingolipid biosynthesis is overlapping with that of Sur1p; CSH1 has a paralog, SUR1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Catalytic subunit of mannosylinositol phosphorylceramide (MIPC) synthase; required for biosynthesis of mature sphingolipids; predicted to be integral to membranes
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant has abnormal distribution of a reporter protein between Golgi and vacuole; in systematic studies null mutant shows increased competitive fitness

description: Mannosyltransferase; involved in adding the 4th and 5th mannose residues of O-linked glycans
Mannosyltransferase; involved in asparagine-linked glycosylation in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER); essential for viability; human homolog ALG1 complements yeast null mutant
functionSummary: Beta-1,4-mannosyltransferase that transfers a mannose residue to an oligosaccharide; involved in protein glycosylation and the assembly of oligosaccharide-lipid intermediates; localizes to the endoplasmic reticulum
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; conditional mutants are senstive to heat and impaired in invertase glycosylation; reduced function mutants show increased competitive fitness, increased sensitivity to DNA-damaging agent methyl methanesulfonate (MMS); heterozygous diploid nulls are sensitive to starvation

briefDescription: Mannosyltransferase in the N-linked glycosylation pathway
description: Mannosyltransferase in the N-linked glycosylation pathway; catalyzes two consecutive steps in the N-linked glycosylation pathway; alg2 mutants exhibit temperature-sensitive growth and abnormal accumulation of the lipid-linked oligosaccharide Man2GlcNAc2-PP-Dol; human ALG2 complements the temperature sensitivity and dolichol-linked oligosaccharide biosynthesis defect of the alg2-1 mutant, but mutant form from a patient with CDG-Ii fails to complement
functionSummary: Glycolipid mannosyltransferase involved in oligosaccharide-lipid intermediate biosynthesis; localizes to endoplasmic reticulum
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; mutations cause sensitivity to gentamycin, hygromycin B, kanamycin and neomycin B; repression leads to increased sensitivity to MMS and myriocin; overexpression results in slow growth

description: Mannosyltransferase, involved in N-linked glycosylation; catalyzes the transfer of both the seventh mannose residue on B-arm and ninth mannose residue on the C-arm from Dol-P-Man to lipid-linked oligosaccharides; human homolog ALG9 can complement yeast null mutant; mutation of human homolog causes type 1 congenital disorders of glycosylation
functionSummary: Dol-P-Man-dependent alpha-1,2 mannosyltransferase that catalyzes addition of seventh and ninth mannose to lipid-linked oligosaccharides; involved in synthesis of oligosaccharide precursor for N-linked protein glycosylation; localizes in endoplasmic reticulum
