description: Putative serine hydrolase; localizes to both the nucleus and cytoplasm; sequence is similar to S. cerevisiae Fsh2p and Fsh3p and the human candidate tumor suppressor OVCA2

briefDescription: Putative serine hydrolase that localizes to the cytoplasm
description: Putative serine hydrolase that localizes to the cytoplasm; sequence is similar to S. cerevisiae Fsh1p and Fsh3p and the human candidate tumor suppressor OVCA2
functionSummary: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cytoplasm in a large-scale study

description: Putative serine/threonine protein kinase; implicated in the regulation of phospholipid asymmetry through the activation of phospholipid translocases (flippases); involved in the phosphorylation of upstream inhibitory kinase Ypk1p along with Fpk1p; has a redundant role in the cellular response to mating pheromone; KIN82 has a paralog, FPK1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Putative protein kinase; involved in the regulation of phospholipid translocation; phosphoryates upstream inhibitory kinase Ypk1p; has a role in the cellular response to mating pheromone

description: Putative serine/threonine protein kinase; involved in the adaptation to low concentrations of glucose independent of the SNF3 regulated pathway; SKS1 has a paralog, VHS1, that arose from the whole genome duplication

Putative serine/threonine protein kinase; regulates spermine uptake; involved in polyamine transport; possible mitochondrial protein; PTK1 has a paralog, PTK2, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Putative protein kinase involved in polyamine transport

briefDescription: Putative serine/threonine protein kinase with unknown cellular role
description: Putative serine/threonine protein kinase with unknown cellular role; KKQ8 has a paralog, HAL5, that arose from the whole genome duplication

Putative serine/threonine protein phosphatase; putative phosphatase of the type 2A-like phosphatase family, required for glycogen accumulation; interacts with Tap42p, which binds to and regulates other protein phosphatases
Putative short-chain dehydrogenase/reductase; proposed to be a palmitoylated membrane protein
functionSummary: Protein whose biological role and cellular location are unknown

description: Putative short-chain dehydrogenase/reductase; YDL114W is not an essential gene
functionSummary: Predicted integral membrane protein whose biological role is unknown

briefDescription: Putative sphingoid long-chain base (LCB) efflux transporter
description: Putative sphingoid long-chain base (LCB) efflux transporter; integral membrane transporter that localizes to the plasma membrane and may transport long chain bases (LCBs) from the cytoplasmic side toward the extracytoplasmic side of the membrane; role in glycerophospholipid translocation; suppressor of the sphingoid LCB sensitivity of an LCB-lyase mutation
functionSummary: Phospholipid-translocating ATPase involved in sphingoid long-chain base transport; integral membrane protein that localizes to plasma membrane, vacuole, and endoplasmic reticulum

description: Putative spore wall protein; expression increases during sporulation; not an essential gene; YOR214C has a paralog, SPO19, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cell wall

description: Putative sterol transfer protein; has a probable role in retrograde transport of sterols from the plasma membrane to the ER; co-localizes to puncta in the cortical ER with Ysp2p; contains GRAM, StART-like (VASt) and two PH-like domains; one of 6 StART-like domain-containing proteins in yeast that may be involved in sterol transfer between intracellular membranes; conserved across eukaryotes; previously identified as a transcription cofactor that interacts with DNA-bound Snf1p
functionSummary: Protein identified as having a role both in transcription and in intracellular sterol transport; localizes to the cortical ER

description: Putative sterol transfer protein; localizes to puncta in the cortical ER; probable role in retrograde transport of sterols from the plasma membrane to the ER; one of six StART-like domain-containing proteins in yeast that may be involved in sterol transfer between intracellular membranes; conserved across eukaryotes; contains GRAM, StART-like (VASt) and two PH-like domains
functionSummary: Putative sterol transfer protein with a role in intracellular sterol transport; localizes to mitochondria and cortical ER

description: Putative sterol transfer protein; one of six StART-like domain-containing proteins in yeast that may be involved in sterol transfer between intracellular membranes; conserved across eukaryotes; has both GRAM and StART-like (VASt) domains; localizes to membrane contact sites throughout the cell, including nucleus-vacuole junctions and ER-mitochondrial contact sites
functionSummary: Putative sterol transfer protein with a role in intracellular sterol transport, by similarity with Lam6p; localizes to intracellular membrane contact sites between ER and other organelles

briefDescription: Putative subunit of the 90S preribosome processome complex
description: Putative subunit of the 90S preribosome processome complex; overexpression rescues supressor mutant of mcm10; null mutant is viable; relocalizes from nucleus to cytoplasm upon DNA replication stress
functionSummary: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cytoplasm, 90S preribosome, and nucleus in different large-scale studies
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies null mutation causes increased biofilm formation, increased chronological lifespan, but decreased competitive fitness; overexpression confers slow growth

briefDescription: Putative subunit of U3-containing 90S preribosome complex
description: Putative subunit of U3-containing 90S preribosome complex; complex is involved in production of 18S rRNA and assembly of small ribosomal subunit
Putative sulfate permease; physically interacts with Hsp82p; green fluorescent protein (GFP)-fusion protein localizes to the ER; YPR003C is not an essential gene
functionSummary: Predicted integral membrane protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the endoplasmic reticulum in a large-scale study

briefDescription: Putative targeting subunit for type-1 protein phosphatase Glc7p
description: Putative targeting subunit for type-1 protein phosphatase Glc7p; tethers Glc7p to Gsy2p glycogen synthase; PIG1 has a paralog, GAC1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
Putative transcriptional activator; interacts with G1-specific transcription factor MBF and G1-specific promoters; MSA2 has a paralog, MSA1, that arose from the whole genome duplication

briefDescription: Putative transcriptional repressor with Zn(2)-Cys(6) finger
description: Putative transcriptional repressor with Zn(2)-Cys(6) finger; negatively regulates transcription in response to oleate levels, based on mutant phenotype and localization to oleate-responsive promoters; the authentic, non-tagged protein is detected in highly purified mitochondria in high-throughput studies; forms nuclear foci upon DNA replication stress
functionSummary: RNA polymerase II-specific DNA-binding transcription factor that represses transcription during cellular response to oleic acid; localizes to nucleus, mitrochondria, and cytoplasm

description: Putative transcription factor; contains a Zn(II)2Cys6 zinc finger domain characteristic of DNA-binding proteins; computational analysis suggests a role in regulation of expression of genes encoding transporters; binds Sin3p in a two-hybrid assay;
Putative transcription factor; has homolog in Kluyveromyces lactis
functionSummary: Protein whose biological role and cellular location are unknown

briefDescription: Putative transcription factor, as suggested by computational analysis
description: Putative transcription factor, as suggested by computational analysis; green fluorescent protein (GFP)-fusion protein localizes to both the cytoplasm and the nucleus and is induced in response to the DNA-damaging agent MMS; overproduction of a truncation allele suppresses lethality due to expression of the dominant PET9 allele AAC2-A128P

briefDescription: Putative transcription factor containing a C2H2 zinc finger
description: Putative transcription factor containing a C2H2 zinc finger; mutation affects transcriptional regulation of genes involved in growth on non-fermentable carbon sources, response to salt stress and cell wall biosynthesis; USV1 has a paralog, RGM1, that arose from the whole genome duplication

briefDescription: Putative transcription factor containing a WOPR domain
description: Putative transcription factor containing a WOPR domain; binds DNA in vitro; similar to C. albicans Wor1p transcription factor that regulates white-opaque switching; overexpression causes a cell cycle delay or arrest

briefDescription: Putative transcription factor containing a zinc finger
description: Putative transcription factor containing a zinc finger; overexpression increases salt tolerance through increased expression of the ENA1 (Na+/Li+ extrusion pump) gene while gene disruption decreases both salt tolerance and ENA1 expression; HAL9 has a paralog, TBS1, that arose from the whole genome duplication

briefDescription: Putative transcription factor, contains Forkhead Associated domain
description: Putative transcription factor, contains Forkhead Associated domain; binds chromatin; involved in expression homeostasis, buffering of mRNA synthesis rate against gene dosage changes during S phase; target of SBF transcription factor; expression is periodic and peaks in G1; involved in DNA replication checkpoint response; interacts with Rpd3 and Set3 histone deacetylase complexes; APCC(Cdh1) substrate; relative distribution to nucleus increases upon DNA replication stress

briefDescription: Putative transcription factor, contains Forkhead Associated domain
description: Putative transcription factor, contains Forkhead Associated domain; found associated with chromatin; target of SBF transcription factor; induced in response to DNA damaging agents and deletion of telomerase; PLM2 has a paralog, TOS4, that arose from the whole genome duplication

Putative transmembrane polyol transporter; supports growth on and uptake of mannitol and sorbitol with moderate affinity when overexpressed in a strain deleted for hexose family members; minor hexose transport activity when overexpressed in a similar strain; induced by non-fermentable carbon sources; induced in low glucose, repressed in high glucose; HXT13 has a paralog, HXT17, that arose from a segmental duplication

Putative transmembrane polyol transporter; supports growth on and uptake of mannitol and sorbitol with moderate affinity when overexpressed in a strain deleted for hexose family members; minor hexose transport activity when overexpressed in a similar strain; induced by raffinose and galactose at pH 7.7 versus pH 4.7, repressed by high levels of glucose; HXT17 has a paralog, HXT13, that arose from a segmental duplication

Putative transmembrane polyol transporter; supports growth on and uptake of mannitol, sorbitol and xylitol with moderate affinity when overexpressed in a strain deleted for hexose family members; minor hexose transport activity when overexpressed in a similar strain; similarity to hexose transporters; expression is induced by low levels of glucose and repressed by high levels of glucose

Putative transmembrane polyol transporter; supports growth on and uptake of sorbitol with moderate affinity and mannitol with lower affinity when overexpressed in a strain deleted for hexose family members; minor hexose transport activity when overexpressed in a similar strain; similarity to hexose transporters; expression is repressed by high levels of glucose

briefDescription: Putative transmembrane protein involved in export of ammonia
description: Putative transmembrane protein involved in export of ammonia; ammonia is a starvation signal that promotes cell death in aging colonies; phosphorylated in mitochondria; member of the TC 9.B.33 YaaH family; homolog of Y. lipolytica Gpr1p; ATO2 has a paralog, ADY2, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Plasma membrane ammonium transporter involved in nitrogen utilization
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; dominant negative mutation results in acetic acid sensitivity; null mutant has decreased competitive fitness in minimal medium and heterozygous null has decreased resistance to starvation; null mutant has an increased replicative lifespan; overexpression results in increased colony sectoring, indicative of chromosomal instability

briefDescription: Putative transmembrane protein involved in the biotin biosynthesis
description: Putative transmembrane protein involved in the biotin biosynthesis; responsible for uptake of 7-keto 8-aminopelargonic acid; BIO5 is in a cluster of 3 genes (BIO3, BIO4, and BIO5) that mediate biotin synthesis
functionSummary: Endoplasmic reticulum transmembrane transporter involved in biotin biosynthesis and vitamin transport
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays decreased competitive fitness in minimal medium; null mutant has reduced starvation resistance; null mutant displays increased sensitivity to the biotin vitamers 7,8-diaminopelargonic acid and 7-keto-8-aminopelargonic; heterozygous null mutant is haploproficient

description: Putative transporter; member of a family of seven S. cerevisiae genes (AVT1-7) related to vesicular GABA-glycine transporters
functionSummary: Protein of unknown biological role; localizes to the endoplasmic reticulum
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies null mutants are defective in biofilm formation and show increased sensitivity to caffeine, camptothecin, cycloheximide, tunicamycin, but increased resistance to bleomycin, and miconazole

description: Putative transporter; member of a family of seven S. cerevisiae genes (AVT1-7) related to vesicular GABA-glycine transporters
functionSummary: Protein of unknown biological role; predicted to be an amino acid transporter; localizes to the vacuole
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows decreased proline levels in vacuole; in systematic studies null mutant is sensitive to neomycin and oxidative stress; overexpression causes slow growth

description: Putative transporter; member of a family of seven S. cerevisiae genes (AVT1-7) related to vesicular GABA-glycine transporters; AVT5 has a paralog, AVT6, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Putative transmembrane transporter
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; in systematic studies null mutants show reduced competitive fitness, weak sensitivity to caffeine, reduced growth on galactose

description: Putative transporter; member of the sugar porter family
Putative transporter; member of the sugar porter family; non-essential gene; overexpression results in elevated colony sectoring, an indicator of chromosomal instability
Putative transporter; member of the sugar porter family; YFL040W is not an essential gene; may have a role in intracellular sterol transport

briefDescription: Putative transporter in the major facilitator superfamily
description: Putative transporter in the major facilitator superfamily; member of the 12-spanner drug:H(+) antiporter DHA1 family; mutations in membrane-spanning domains permit cation and histidinol uptake

briefDescription: Putative transporter, member of the sugar porter family
description: Putative transporter, member of the sugar porter family; green fluorescent protein (GFP)-fusion protein localizes to the vacuolar membrane; YBR241C is not an essential gene; YBR241C has a paralog, VPS73, that arose from the whole genome duplication

briefDescription: Putative transporter of the ATP-binding cassette (ABC) family
description: Putative transporter of the ATP-binding cassette (ABC) family; role in plasma membrane sterol incorporation; implicated in pleiotropic drug resistance; provides resistance to ethanol stress and contributes to a decreased intracellular accumulation of ethanol; the authentic, non-tagged protein is detected in highly purified mitochondria in high-throughput studies
functionSummary: Protein involved in sterol homeostasis and response to drugs; putative plasma membrane localization, localized to mitochondrion and cytosol in large scale studies

briefDescription: Putative transporter of the MRP subfamily
description: Putative transporter of the MRP subfamily; adjacent ORFs YKR103W and YKR104W are merged in different strain backgrounds; MRP stands for multidrug resistance-associated protein

briefDescription: Putative transporter of the MRP subfamily
description: Putative transporter of the MRP subfamily; contains a stop codon in S288C; adjacent ORFs YKR103W and YKR104W are merged in different strain backgrounds; MRP stands for multidrug resistance-associated protein
functionSummary: Putative membrane-localized xenobiotic ABC transporter

description: Putative tRNA acetyltransferase; RNA-binding protein required for the formation of the modified nucleoside N(4)-acetylcytidine in serine and leucine tRNAs but not required for the same modification in 18S rRNA; protein abundance increases in response to DNA replication stress

briefDescription: Putative tubulin tyrosine ligase associated with P-bodies
description: Putative tubulin tyrosine ligase associated with P-bodies; may have a role in mRNA metabolism; yeast knockout collection strain identified as a pby1 null mutant is actually wild-type for PBY1 and deleted for mms4
functionSummary: Component of the cytoplasmic mRNA processing body (P body);   but not involved in mRNA catabolic process

briefDescription: Putative type-1 protein phosphatase targeting subunit
description: Putative type-1 protein phosphatase targeting subunit; tethers Glc7p type-1 protein phosphatase to Gsy2p glycogen synthase; PIG2 has a paralog, GIP2, that arose from the whole genome duplication
Putative ubiquitin-specific protease; concentrates at the bud neck; UBP5 has a paralog, DOA4, that arose from the whole genome duplication
Putative UTP glucose-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase; YHL012W has a paralog, UGP1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Protein whose biological role and cellular location are unknown

briefDescription: Putative vacuolar membrane transporter for cationic amino acids
description: Putative vacuolar membrane transporter for cationic amino acids; likely contributes to amino acid homeostasis by exporting cationic amino acids from the vacuole; member of the PQ-loop family, with seven transmembrane domains; mutant phenotype is functionally complemented by rat PQLC2 vacuolar transporter

briefDescription: Putative vacuolar membrane transporter for cationic amino acids
description: Putative vacuolar membrane transporter for cationic amino acids; likely contributes to amino acid homeostasis by exporting cationic amino acids from the vacuole; member of the PQ-loop family, with seven transmembrane domains; similar to mammalian PQLC2 vacuolar transporter; YPQ1 has a paralog, RTC2, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: A basic amino acid transmembrane transporter protein involved in basic amino acid transmembrane export from the vacuole that is an integral component of fungal-type vacuolar membrane

briefDescription: Putative vacuolar membrane transporter for cationic amino acids
description: Putative vacuolar membrane transporter for cationic amino acids; likely contributes to amino acid homeostasis by exporting cationic amino acids from the vacuole; positive regulation by Lys14p suggests that lysine may be the primary substrate; member of the PQ-loop family, with seven transmembrane domains; similar to mammalian PQLC2 vacuolar transporter; RTC2 has a paralog, YPQ1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
Putative X-Pro aminopeptidase; green fluorescent protein (GFP)-fusion protein localizes to the cytoplasm; YFR006W is not an essential gene
functionSummary: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the cytoplasm in a large-scale study

description: Putative Y' element ATP-dependent helicase
Putative Y' element ATP-dependent helicase
Putative Y' element ATP-dependent helicase
Putative Y' element ATP-dependent helicase; the authentic, non-tagged protein is detected in highly purified mitochondria in high-throughput studies; YML133C contains an intron
Putative Y' element ATP-dependent helicase; YLL066C is not an essential gene

briefDescription: Putative zinc cluster protein of unknown function
description: Putative zinc cluster protein of unknown function; proposed to be involved in the regulation of energy metabolism, based on patterns of expression and sequence analysis
functionSummary: Sequence-specific DNA binding transcription factor implicated in oxidative phosphorylation

briefDescription: Putative zinc-cluster protein of unknown function
description: Putative zinc-cluster protein of unknown function

briefDescription: Putative zinc cluster protein, predicted to be a transcription factor
description: Putative zinc cluster protein, predicted to be a transcription factor; not an essential gene; EDS1 has a paralog, RGT1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
Putative zinc cluster transcription factor; involved in conferring resistance to cycloheximide

briefDescription: Putative zinc finger DNA binding transcription factor
description: Putative zinc finger DNA binding transcription factor; contains two N-terminal C2H2 zinc fingers and C-terminal proline rich domain; overproduction impairs cell growth and induces expression of genes involved in monosaccharide catabolism and aldehyde metabolism; regulates expression of of Y' telomeric elements and subtelomeric COS genes; relocalizes to the cytosol in response to hypoxia; RGM1 has a paralog, USV1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
Putative zinc finger protein; YPR013C is not an essential gene
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; in competitive growth studies null mutant shows increased fitness, reduced starvation resistance and decreased chronological lifespan; in systematic studies mutants are weakly sensitive to rapamycin and have increased percentage of G1 cells

description: Putative zinc finger transcription factor; binds DNA in sequence-specific manner; overexpression causes a cell cycle delay or arrest
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene in S288C, essential gene in Sigma1278b; null mutants are impaired in anaerobic growth, heterozygous diploid nulls are haploinsufficient; overexpression causes decreased growth, abnormal cell cycle progression and chromosome segregation, abnormal morphology of nuclei and buds, and decreased resistance to the microtubule-destabilizing agent nocodazole

briefDescription: Putative Zn(II)2Cys6 motif containing transcription factor
description: Putative Zn(II)2Cys6 motif containing transcription factor; non-essential gene identified in a screen for mutants with increased levels of rDNA transcription; similar to S. kluyveri Urc2p involved in uracil catabolism

Pyridoxal-5’-phosphate synthase; involved in thiamine and pyridoxine biosynthesis; member of a stationary phase-induced gene family where transcriptional induction precedes the diauxic shift; induced in the absence of thiamine in a Thi2/3p-dependent manner and repressed in its presence; forms a co-regulated gene pair with SNO3; paralog of SNZ1 and SNZ2
Pyridoxine (pyridoxamine) phosphate oxidase; has homologs in E. coli and Myxococcus xanthus; transcription is under the general control of nitrogen metabolism

Pyrimidine nucleotidase; responsible for production of nicotinamide riboside and nicotinic acid riboside; overexpression suppresses the 6-AU sensitivity of transcription elongation factor S-II, as well as resistance to other pyrimidine derivatives; SDT1 has a paralog, PHM8, that arose from the whole genome duplication

Pyruvate carboxylase isoform; cytoplasmic enzyme that converts pyruvate to oxaloacetate; differentially regulated than isoform Pyc1p; mutations in the human homolog are associated with lactic acidosis; PYC2 has a paralog, PYC1, that arose from the whole genome duplication

Pyruvate carboxylase isoform; cytoplasmic enzyme that converts pyruvate to oxaloacetate; differentially regulated than isoform Pyc2p; mutations in the human homolog are associated with lactic acidosis; PYC1 has a paralog, PYC2, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Pyruvate carboxylase that catalyzes the carboxylation of pyruvate to form oxaloacetate; involved in gluconeogenesis; localizes to the cytosol

description: Pyruvate kinase; appears to be modulated by phosphorylation; transcription repressed by glucose, and Pyk2p may be active under low glycolytic flux; PYK2 has a paralog, CDC19, that arose from the whole genome duplication

Pyruvate kinase; functions as a homotetramer in glycolysis to convert phosphoenolpyruvate to pyruvate, the input for aerobic (TCA cycle) or anaerobic (glucose fermentation) respiration; regulated via allosteric activation by fructose bisphosphate; CDC19 has a paralog, PYK2, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Pyruvate kinase that catalyzes the final step in glycolysis, the conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate to pyruvate, which is then utilized in anaerobic or aerobic respiration; localized to the cytoplasm
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; heterozygous null mutant displays decreased fitness; conditional mutant is heat-sensitive and arrests in an unbudded state; overexpression confers chromosome instability

description: Quinolinate phosphoribosyl transferase; required for the de novo biosynthesis of NAD from tryptophan via kynurenine; expression regulated by Hst1p
functionSummary: Quinolinate phosphoribosyl transferase involved in de novo NAD biosynthesis from tryptophan; localizes to both the cytoplasm and nucleus
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant is auxotrophic for nicotinic acid, shows elevated sensitivity to oxidative stress and defective respiratory metabolism; in systematic studies null mutants show reduced competitive fitness

description: Rab escort protein; forms a complex with the Ras-like small GTPase Ypt1p that is required for the prenylation of Ypt1p by protein geranylgeranyltransferase type II (Bet2p-Bet4p); sequence similarity to mammalian choroideraemia gene; relative distribution to the nucleus increases upon DNA replication stress

Rab family GTPase; essential for vesicle-mediated exocytic secretion and autophagy; associates with the exocyst component Sec15p and may regulate polarized delivery of transport vesicles to the exocyst at the plasma membrane
functionSummary: GTPase involved in Golgi to plasma membrane transport, vesicle fusion, and exocytosis; also involved in membrane addition at the site of cytokinesis, autophagy, and ascospore-type prospore assembly; localizes to the incipient bud site, mating projection tip, and transport vesicle
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; conditional mutations cause defects in protein secretion, abnormal secretory vesicles and vacuolar morphology, decreased autophagy, abnormal budding and sporulation; overexpression results in slow growth

description: Rab family GTPase; GTP-binding protein of the rab family; required for homotypic fusion event in vacuole inheritance, for endosome-endosome fusion; localizes to sites of contact between the vacuole and mitochondria (vCLAMPs); interacts with the cargo selection/retromer complex for retrograde sorting; similar to mammalian Rab7
functionSummary: GTPase involved in vacuole inheritance, regulation of non-autophagic vacuole fusion, retrograde (endosome to Golgi) transport, endocytosis, and the CVT pathway; also involved in macroautophagy and piecemeal microautophagy of the nucleus; colocalizes with the cargo-selective retromer subcomplex and localizes to the vacuole, vacuole membrane, and vacuole-mitochondrion membrane contact site
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits decreased fitness, abnormal vacuolar morphology, impaired utilization of various nitrogen sources, short telomeres, decreased lifespan, and decreased resistance to ethanol, caffeine, metals, and TOR inhibitor rapamycin; null mutant also fails to undergo autophagy; homozygous diploid null is thermotolerant, defective in sporulation, and sensitive to UV irradiation and a wide variety of antibiotics

description: Rab family GTPase; involved in the ER-to-Golgi step of the secretory pathway; complex formation with the Rab escort protein Mrs6p is required for prenylation of Ypt1p by type II protein geranylgeranyltransferase (Bet2p-Bet4p); binds to unspliced HAC1 mRNA; regulates the unfolded protein response (UPR) by promoting the decay of HAC1 RNA; localizes to the early Golgi, the transitional Golgi and ER membranes, pre-autophagosomal structures, and cytoplasmic vesicles
functionSummary: SNARE-binding GTPase involved in vesicle budding and docking, vesicle-mediated transport, endocytic recycling, macroautophagy, SNARE complex disassembly, and pre-mRNA catabolism; localizes to Golgi and ER membranes, pre-autophagosomal structures, and cytoplasmic vesicles
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; conditional mutants are slow-growing, sensitive to both heat and cold, have fragmented DNA, abnormal ER morphology and aberrant microtubules, undergo cell cycle arrest, do not undergo autophagy, and are sensitive to nitrogen starvation, antibiotics and dopaminergic antagonists; reduction-of-function mutants display chromosome instability and decreased fitness; homozygous diploid conditional mutants fail to sporulate

description: Rab family GTPase; involved in the exocytic pathway; mediates intra-Golgi traffic or the budding of post-Golgi vesicles from the trans-Golgi; YPT31 has a paralog, YPT32, that arose from the whole genome duplication; localizes to the transitional and late Golgi
functionSummary: GTPase involved in vesicle-mediated transport, early endosome to Golgi transport, and exocytosis; localizes to Golgi apparatus, trans-Golgi network, endosomes, and mitochondrial outer membrane

description: Rab family GTPase; required for endosome-to-Golgi, intra-Golgi retrograde, and retrograde Golgi-to-ER transport; temporarily at the Golgi, dissociating into the cytosol on arrival of the late Golgi GTPase Ypt32p; Golgi-localized form is GTP bound, while cytosolic form is GDP-bound; required for delivery of Atg9p to the phagophore assembly site during autophagy under heat stress, with Ypt6p for starvation induced autophagy and for the CVT pathway; homolog of mammalian Rab6
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits decreased fitness, slow growth, increased lifespan, abnormal vacuolar morphology, impaired utilization of various nitrogen sources, impaired endocytosis, and decreased resistance to heat, metals, and TOR inhibitor rapamycin; homozygous diploid null is auxotrophic for myo-inositol, and is sensitive to caffeine and a variety of antibiotics; heterozygous diploid null mutant is haploinsufficient

briefDescription: Rab family GTPase involved in the exocytic pathway
description: Rab family GTPase involved in the exocytic pathway; mediates intra-Golgi traffic or the budding of post-Golgi vesicles from the trans-Golgi; protein abundance increases in response to DNA replication stress; YPT32 has a paralog, YPT31, that arose from the whole genome duplication

Rab family GTP-binding protein; contains the PEST signal sequence specific for proteolytic enzymes; may be involved in vesicular transport; overexpression leads to accumulation of Golgi-like cisternae with budding vesicles
functionSummary: Guanyl nucleotide-binding protein and putative GTPase involved in Golgi organization; localizes to cytoplasm and vacuole membrane

description: Rab GTPase; Myo2p-binding protein implicated in mother-to-bud transport of cortical endoplasmic reticulum (ER), late Golgi, and mitochondria during cell division; function is regulated at multiple levels; abundance of active Ypt11p forms is controlled by phosphorylation status and degradation; normally a low-abundance protein whose ER localization is only detected when protein is highly over expressed

Rab GTPase-activating protein; regulates endocytosis via inactivation of Vps21p at endosomes and vacuole fusion via inactivation of Ypt7p at vacuoles; also acts on Ypt52p and Sec4p; localizes to plasma membrane, sites of polarized growth; relocalizes from bud neck to cytoplasm upon DNA replication stress; similar to TBC-domain Tre2 oncogene; MSB3 has a paralog, MSB4, that arose from the whole genome duplication; human homolog USP6NL can complement yeast msb3 msb4 double null
functionSummary: GTPase activator involved in both exocytic and endocytic pathways; has role in formin-nucleated actin cable assembly and the regulation of protein localization; localizes to plasma membrane and cytosol
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant mislocalizes endosomal proteins to the vacuole; overexpression leads to abnormal vacuole morphology

description: Ran GTPase; GTP binding protein (mammalian Ranp homolog) involved in the maintenance of nuclear organization, RNA processing and transport; regulated by Srm1p, Rna1p, Yrb1p, Yrb2p, Yrp4p, Yrb30p, Cse1p and Kap95p; GSP1 has a paralog, GSP2, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Ran-like GTPase that regulates nucleocytoplasmic transport, rRNA processing, maintenance of nuclear organization and transcriptional silencing at telomeres; localizes predominantly to the nucleus

description: Ran GTPase binding protein; involved in nuclear protein import and RNA export, ubiquitin-mediated protein degradation during the cell cycle; shuttles between the nucleus and cytoplasm; is essential; homolog of human RanBP1
RanGTP-binding protein; inhibits RanGAP1 (Rna1p)-mediated GTP hydrolysis of RanGTP (Gsp1p); shares similarity to proteins in other fungi but not in higher eukaryotes
functionSummary: GTPase regulator that localizes to both the nucleus and cytoplasm

description: Receptor for a factor pheromone; couples to MAP kinase cascade to mediate pheromone response; transcribed in alpha cells and required for mating by alpha cells, ligand bound receptors endocytosed and recycled to the plasma membrane; GPCR
functionSummary: A-factor pheromone receptor; involved in pheromone-dependent signal transduction, cellular conjugation, and cell fusion; localizes to the plasma membrane

description: Receptor for alpha-factor pheromone; seven transmembrane-domain GPCR that interacts with both pheromone and a heterotrimeric G protein to initiate the signaling response that leads to mating between haploid a and alpha cells
functionSummary: Alpha-factor pheromone receptor; role in pheromone-dependent signal transduction involved in cellular conjugation, mating projection assembly, and in cell fusion; localizes to the plasma membrane
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; conditional and reduction-of-function mutants display a decrease in cell cycle arrest in response to pheromone addition, are unable to form shmoos, and have MatA cell specific sterility; reduction of function mutant has a unilateral cell fusion defect and produces elevated levels of Mfa1p/Mfa2p; null mutant has a reduced mating response to alpha factor; heterozygous null mutant has decreased starvation resistance

briefDescription: Receptor protein for the cytoplasm-to-vacuole targeting (Cvt) pathway
description: Receptor protein for the cytoplasm-to-vacuole targeting (Cvt) pathway; delivers cargo proteins aminopeptidase I (Ape1p) and alpha-mannosidase (Ams1p) to the phagophore assembly site for packaging into Cvt vesicles; interaction with Atg19p during the Cvt pathway requires phosphorylation by Hrr25p
functionSummary: Protein involved in the cytoplasm-to-vacuole targeting (CVT) pathway, ER-associated ubiquitin-dependent protein catabolic process, protein complex localization, protein processing and vesicle organization; localizes to the pre-autophagosomal structure (PAS)
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows normal autophagy and pexophagy; overexpression leads to decreased filamentous growth

briefDescription: Receptor protein involved in selective autophagy during starvation
description: Receptor protein involved in selective autophagy during starvation; specifically involved in the transport of cargo protein alpha-mannosidase (Ams1p); Atg19p paralog
functionSummary: Component of the cytoplasm-to-vacuole targeting, CVT complex; involved in transport of alpha-mannosidase (Ams1p) to the vacuole during autophagy
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a decreased growth rate; null mutant has a reduced ability to use glutamine as nitrogen source; null mutant has a severe respiratory growth defect; null mutant has increased competitive fitness on minimal medium; null displays altered accumulation of polyphosphate; null mutant has both decreased resistance to zinc treatment and ethanol

description: RecQ family nucleolar DNA helicase; role in genome integrity maintenance, chromosome synapsis, meiotic joint molecule/crossover formation; stimulates activity of Top3p; rapidly lost in response to rapamycin in Rrd1p-dependent manner; forms nuclear foci upon DNA replication stress; yeast SGS1 complements mutations in human homolog BLM implicated in Bloom syndrome; also similar to human WRN implicated in Werner syndrome; human BLM and WRN can each complement yeast null mutant
functionSummary: Nucleolar ATP-dependent DNA helicase that is a subunit of the RecQ helicase-Topoisomerase III complex; melts and unwinds double-stranded DNA; involved in the formation of telomeric 3' overhangs, maintenance of telomeres by recombination, processing of DNA double-strand breaks, segregation of chromatids during mitosis, and segregation of chromosomes during meiosis; has a role in gene conversion at the mating-type loci, and also regulates meiotic recombination and the conversion of paired broken DNA and homologous duplex DNA into four-stranded branched intermediate joint molecules
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant has an elevated rate of mutations and rate of gross chromosomal rearrangements, increased chromosome instability, and increased sensitivity to DNA damaging agents and UV light; null mutant has a decreased replicative lifespan but elevated caloric-restriction induced lifespan extension, and elevated chronological lifespan; null mutant has abnormal nuclear and nucleolar morphology, poor spore viability and decreased post-germination growth

description: Redundant rho-like GTPase Cdc42p effector; involved in initiation of budding and cellular polarization; interacts with Cdc42p via the Cdc42/Rac-interactive binding (CRIB) domain and with PI(4,5)P2 via a polybasic region; GIC2 has a paralog, GIC1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Phosphatidylinositol-4,5-bisphosphate binding GTPase activator involved in actin cable assembly, establishment of cell polarity, septin ring organization, and regulation of exit from mitosis; localizes to plasma membrane, incipient cellular bud site, bud tip, and mating projection tip

briefDescription: Regulates transcription of ribosomal protein and biogenesis genes
description: Regulates transcription of ribosomal protein and biogenesis genes; regulates response to nutrients and stress, G2/M transitions during mitotic cell cycle and DNA-damage response, and modulates cell size; regulated by TORC1 and Mrs6p; sequence of zinc finger, ChIP localization data, and protein-binding microarray (PBM) data, and computational analyses suggest it binds DNA directly at highly active RP genes and indirectly through Rap1p at others; can form the [ISP+] prion
functionSummary: Predicted RNA polymerase II transcription factor involved in the activation of transcription of ribosomal protein genes and in the regulation of cell size; localizes to both the nucleus and cytoplasm
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutants grow slowly, have abnormal vacuolar morphology, decreased ethanol tolerance, small cells and nuclei, slow G1 phase progression, abnormal budding, and are sensitive to DNA-damaging agents, caffeine, heat, and various drugs; homozygous diploid nulls tolerate zinc deficiency, cannot sporulate; overexpression slows growth, interferes with silencing, and can be lethal in S288C; overexpression enhances pseudohyphal growth in Sigma1278b

description: Regulator of filamentous growth; interacts with FLO11 promoter and regulates FLO11 expression; binds to transcription factors Flo8p and Mss11p; green fluorescent protein (GFP)-fusion protein localizes to the nucleus; YDL233W is not an essential gene
functionSummary: Protein whose biological role is unknown; localizes to the nucleus and cytoplasm in a large-scale study

description: Regulator of ornithine decarboxylase Spe1p; antizyme that binds to Spe1p to stimulate ubiquitin-independent degradation by the proteasome; binding of polyamines to nascent Oaz1p during translation stimulates +1 ribosomal frameshifting, allowing translation of full-length Oaz1p

Regulator of phospholipase D (Spo14p); interacts with Spo14p and regulates its catalytic activity; capable of buffering the toxicity of C16:0 platelet activating factor, a lipid that accumulates intraneuronally in Alzheimer's patients

briefDescription: Regulator of Rho1p signaling, cofactor of Tus1p
description: Regulator of Rho1p signaling, cofactor of Tus1p; required for the localization of Tus1p during all phases of cytokinesis; green fluorescent protein (GFP)-fusion protein localizes to the bud neck and cytoplasm; null mutant is viable and exhibits growth defect on a non-fermentable (respiratory) carbon source

Regulator of ribosomal protein (RP) transcription; has forkhead associated domain that binds phosphorylated proteins; recruits coactivator Ifh1p or corepressor Crf1p to RP gene promoters; also has forkhead DNA-binding domain though in vitro DNA binding assays give inconsistent results; computational analyses suggest it binds DNA directly at highly active RP genes and indirectly through Rap1p motifs at others; suppresses RNA pol III and splicing factor prp4 mutants
functionSummary: Transcription regulator-binding protein involved in the regulation of ribosomal protein gene transcription

description: Regulator of septin dynamics; involved in the regulation of septin dynamics at bud neck after mitotic entry, likely by stabilizing septin structure; regulated at post-translational level by cell cycle dependent phosphorylation; likely phosphorylated by Cdc28p and dephosphorylated by Cdc14p before cytokinesis; high-copy suppressor of synthetic lethality of sis2 sit4 double mutant; VHS2 has a paralog, MLF3, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Protein involved in the organization of the septin ring, and in polarized actin organization at elevated temperature; localizes to the cytoplasm

briefDescription: Regulator of the Fps1p glycerol channel
description: Regulator of the Fps1p glycerol channel; under nonstress conditions, binds to Fps1p to positively regulate glycerol transport; under osmotic stress, multiple phosphorylation by Hog1p causes Ask10p to dissociate from Fps1p; forms homodimers and heterodimerizes with paralog Rgc1p; phosphorylated in response to oxidative stress; has a role in destruction of Ssn8p; associates with RNA polymerase II holoenzyme
functionSummary: Regulator of the Fps1p glycerol channel; involved in oxidative stress response, protein catabolism, and regulation of glycerol transport; localizes to the cytoplasm
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant is resistant to arsenite; in systematic studies null mutants are sensitive to hyperosmotic stress and to many chemicals, including benomyl, camptothecin, cycloheximide, fluconazole, hydroxyurea, MMS, tunicamycin

briefDescription: Regulatory light chain for the type II myosin Myo1p
description: Regulatory light chain for the type II myosin Myo1p; binds to an IQ motif of Myo1p, localization to the bud neck depends on Myo1p; involved in the disassembly of the Myo1p ring

briefDescription: Regulatory protein that binds Pdc2p and Thi2p transcription factors
description: Regulatory protein that binds Pdc2p and Thi2p transcription factors; activates thiamine biosynthesis transcription factors Pdc2p and Thi2p by binding to them, but releases and de-activates them upon binding to thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), the end product of the pathway; has similarity to decarboxylases but enzymatic activity is not detected

briefDescription: Regulatory subunit A of the heterotrimeric PP2A complex
description: Regulatory subunit A of the heterotrimeric PP2A complex; the heterotrimeric protein phosphatase 2A (PP2A) complex also contains regulatory subunit Cdc55p and either catalytic subunit Pph21p or Pph22p; required for cell morphogenesis and transcription by RNA polymerase III
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant has low proportion of S-phase cells and G1 cells in heterozygous diploid; null mutant shows secreation defect

briefDescription: Regulatory subunit B of protein phosphatase 2A (PP2A)
description: Regulatory subunit B of protein phosphatase 2A (PP2A); Zds1p/2p-dependent localization to cytoplasm promotes mitotic entry; localization to nucleus prevents mitotic exit; required for correct nuclear division, chromosome segregation during achiasmate meiosis; maintains nucleolar sequestration of Cdc14p during early meiosis; limits formation of PP2A-Rts1p holocomplexes to ensure timely dissolution of sister chromosome cohesion; homolog of mammalian B55
functionSummary: Type 2A protein phosphatase regulatory subunit; positively regulates mitotic entry at the G2/M phase transition and negatively regulates mitotic exit; regulator of the mitotic spindle assembly and the morphogenesis checkpoint; stimulates transcription in response to hyperosmotic stress by regulating the nuclear localization of Msn2p and Msn4p, as well as the activation of Msn2p; localizes to the nucleus, cytoplasm, bud neck, bud tip, vacuolar membrane and shmoo tip
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays abnormally elongated buds, decreased growth rate and increased sensitivity to cold, benomyl, hydroxyurea, nocodazole; homozygous diploid is unable to complete meiosis

briefDescription: Regulatory subunit for Glc7p type-1 protein phosphatase (PP1)
description: Regulatory subunit for Glc7p type-1 protein phosphatase (PP1); tethers Glc7p to Gsy2p glycogen synthase, binds Hsf1p heat shock transcription factor, required for induction of some HSF-regulated genes under heat shock; GAC1 has a paralog, PIG1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Regulatory subunit of the Glc7p protein phosphatase type 1 complex; involved in glycogen metabolic process, mitotic spindle assembly checkpoint, meiotic nuclear division and response to heat

briefDescription: Regulatory subunit for the plasma membrane H(+)-ATPase Pma1p
description: Regulatory subunit for the plasma membrane H(+)-ATPase Pma1p; small single-membrane span proteolipid; forms unique helix and positively charged cytoplasmic domain that is able to specifically segregate phosphatidylserines; PMP1 has a paralog, PMP2, that arose from the whole genome duplication

Regulatory subunit of acetolactate synthase; acetolactate synthase catalyzes the first step of branched-chain amino acid biosynthesis; enhances activity of the Ilv2p catalytic subunit, localizes to mitochondria

briefDescription: Regulatory subunit of Cdc7p-Dbf4p kinase complex
description: Regulatory subunit of Cdc7p-Dbf4p kinase complex; required for Cdc7p kinase activity and initiation of DNA replication; phosphorylates the Mcm2-7 family of proteins; cell cycle regulated; relative distribution to the nucleus increases upon DNA replication stress; co-expression of human CDC7 and DBF4 complements single cdc7 or dbf4 null mutations or the cdc7 dbf4 double null mutation
functionSummary: Positive regulatory subunit of the Dbf4-dependent protein kinase (DDK) complex; essential for Cdc7p kinase activity; positively regulates the initiation of DNA replication and negatively regulates mitotic exit; positive regulator of pre-meiotic DNA replication and meiosis I; interacts with replication origins
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; conditional mutant exhibits heat sensitivity and a large-budded terminal phenotype with nuclei at the bud neck; in large-scale studies, conditional mutants exhibit chromosome instability and an S-phase cell cycle delay

description: Regulatory subunit of protein phosphatase 1 (Glc7p); involved in glycogen metabolism and chromosome segregation; proposed to regulate Glc7p activity via conformational alteration; ortholog of the mammalian protein phosphatase inhibitor 2; protein abundance increases in response to DNA replication stress

briefDescription: Regulatory subunit of protein phosphatase PP4
description: Regulatory subunit of protein phosphatase PP4; presence of Psy4p in the PP4 complex (along with catalytic subunit Pph3p and Psy2p) is required for dephosphorylation of the histone variant H2AX, but not for dephosphorylation of Rad53p, during recovery from the DNA damage checkpoint; localization is cell-cycle dependent and regulated by Cdc28p phosphorylation; required for cisplatin resistance; homolog of mammalian R2

briefDescription: Regulatory subunit of the Atg1p signaling complex
description: Regulatory subunit of the Atg1p signaling complex; stimulates Atg1p kinase activity; required for vesicle formation during autophagy and the cytoplasm-to-vacuole targeting (Cvt) pathway; contains a HORMA domain required for autophagy and for recruitment of the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase complex subunit Atg14p to the pre-autophagosomal structure
functionSummary: Protein kinase regulator subunit of the Atg1 signaling complex; involved in  protein localization to pre-autophagosomal structure (PAS), late nucleophagy, mitochondrion degradation, piecemeal microautophagy of nucleusmacroautophagy and cytoplasm-to-vacuole targeting (CVT) pathway
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows decreased autophagy and mitophagy, increased sensitivity to nitrogen starvation, abnormal nuclear morphology, and is unable to sporulate

briefDescription: Regulatory subunit of the cyclic AMP-dependent protein kinase (PKA)
description: Regulatory subunit of the cyclic AMP-dependent protein kinase (PKA); PKA is a component of a signaling pathway that controls a variety of cellular processes, including metabolism, cell cycle, stress response, stationary phase, and sporulation
functionSummary: cAMP-dependent protein kinase inhibitor involved in the regulation of signaling; localizes to the nucleus, cytoplasm and plasma membrane
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant is temperature sensitive, is unable to utilize various fermentable carbon sources, has respiratory growth defects, is nitrogen starvation intolerant, has decreased spore viability, an inability to accumulate glycogen and reduced thermotoleance; null mutants are also sensitive to desiccation and have a decreased replicative lifespan; heterozygous diploid null has decreased resistance to osmotic and oxidative stress

briefDescription: Regulatory subunit of the Glc7p type-1 protein phosphatase
description: Regulatory subunit of the Glc7p type-1 protein phosphatase; involved with Reg1p, Glc7p, and Snf1p in regulation of glucose-repressible genes, also involved in glucose-induced proteolysis of maltose permease; REG2 has a paralog, REG1, that arose from the whole genome duplication

briefDescription: Regulatory subunit of the type 1 protein phosphatase (PP1) Glc7p
description: Regulatory subunit of the type 1 protein phosphatase (PP1) Glc7p; whether it functions as a positive or negative regulator of Glc7p is controversial; involved in the regulation of Glc7p nuclear localization and function
functionSummary: Protein serine/threonine phosphatase inhibitor and protein phosphatase activator; contributes to maintenance of protein location in nucleus and chromosome segregation; localizes to nucleus and protein phosphatase type 1 complex, to cytoplasm in high-throughput studies
phenotypeSummary: Essential gene; sds22-77 frameshift mutation causes heat- and cold-sensitivity and sensitivity to CsCl, formamide, and rapamycin at the restrictive temperature; in large-scale studies, repression confers reduced competitive fitness; sds22-5 mutant displays chromosome instability at the semi-permissive temperature; diploid heterozygous null mutant is haploproficient but sensitive to starvation and to human cationic antimicrobial peptide derivatives

briefDescription: Regulatory subunit of the type I protein phosphatase (PP1) Glc7p
description: Regulatory subunit of the type I protein phosphatase (PP1) Glc7p; Glc7p participates in the regulation of a variety of metabolic processes including mitosis and glycogen metabolism; in vitro evidence suggests Ypi1p is an inhibitor of Glc7p while in vivo evidence suggests it is an activator; overproduction causes decreased cellular content of glycogen; partial depletion causes lithium sensitivity, while overproduction confers lithium-tolerance

briefDescription: Regulatory subunit of the vacuolar transporter chaperone (VTC) complex
description: Regulatory subunit of the vacuolar transporter chaperone (VTC) complex; involved in membrane trafficking, vacuolar polyphosphate accumulation, microautophagy and non-autophagic vacuolar fusion; VTC2 has a paralog, VTC3, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Calmodulin-binding regulatory subunit of the vacuolar transporter chaperone (VTC) complex; involved in vacuole fusion, vacuolar transport, microautophagy and polyphosphate metabolism; localizes to endoplasmic reticulum and vacuole membranes

briefDescription: Regulatory subunit of the vacuolar transporter chaperone (VTC) complex
description: Regulatory subunit of the vacuolar transporter chaperone (VTC) complex; involved in membrane trafficking, vacuolar polyphosphate accumulation, microautophagy and non-autophagic vacuolar fusion; VTC3 has a paralog, VTC2, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Calmodulin-binding regulatory subunit of the vacuolar transporter chaperone (VTC) complex; involved in vacuole fusion, vacuolar transport, microautophagy and polyphosphate metabolism; localizes to endoplasmic reticulum and vacuole membranes

briefDescription: Regulatory subunit of the vacuolar transporter chaperone (VTC) complex
description: Regulatory subunit of the vacuolar transporter chaperone (VTC) complex; VTC complex is involved in membrane trafficking, vacuolar polyphosphate accumulation, microautophagy and non-autophagic vacuolar fusion; also has mRNA binding activity; protein abundance increases in response to DNA replication stress

Regulatory subunit of trehalose-6-phosphate synthase/phosphatase; involved in synthesis of storage carbohydrate trehalose; expression is induced by stress conditions and repressed by the Ras-cAMP pathway; TPS3 has a paralog, TSL1, that arose from the whole genome duplication
functionSummary: Subunit of alpha,alpha-trehalose phosphate synthase complex that contributes to trehalose-synthase and trehalose-phosphate activities; involved in trehalose biosynthesis

briefDescription: Regulatory subunit of type 1 protein phosphatase Glc7p
description: Regulatory subunit of type 1 protein phosphatase Glc7p; involved in negative regulation of glucose-repressible genes; involved in regulation of the nucleocytoplasmic shuttling of Hxk2p; REG1 has a paralog, REG2, that arose from the whole genome duplication
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant shows decreased rate of fermentative growth, sensitivity to starvation and elevated glycogen accumulation; null mutation decreases utilization of galactose, maltose, sucrose as carbon sources, also increases resistance to a toxic glucose analog 2-deoxy-D-glucose and causes sensitivity to L-canavanine; null mutants have large cell size

description: Replication fork associated factor; required for stable replication fork pausing; component of the DNA replication checkpoint pathway; required for accurate chromosome segregation during meiosis; forms nuclear foci upon DNA replication stress
functionSummary: Subunit of the replication fork protection complex that stabilizes stalled replication forks during DNA replication; required for sister chromatid cohesion and chromosome segregation during meiosis; localized to the nucleus
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant displays high rate of chromosome instability, increased sensitivity to benomyl, hydroxyurea, camptothecin and selenomethionine; null mutant is also sensitive to UV; in systematic studies mutants are resistant to caffeine, cycloheximide and fluconazole

description: Repressible acid phosphatase; 1 of 3 repressible acid phosphatases that also mediates extracellular nucleotide-derived phosphate hydrolysis; secretory pathway derived cell surface glycoprotein; induced by phosphate starvation and coordinately regulated by PHO4 and PHO2
functionSummary: Acid phosphatase involved in the cellular response to phosphate starvation and the metabolism of phosphate-containing compounds; also has nucleoside-triphosphatase and nucleoside-triphosphate pyrophosphatase activities; localized to the cell wall
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant exhibits reduced acid phosphatase activity in low-inorganic phosphate medium; in large-scale studies, null mutant displays small cell size and elongated buds, reduced or increased competitive fitness in different media, increased chitin deposition, and MMS sensitivity

description: Repressible vacuolar alkaline phosphatase; regulated by levels of Pi and by Pho4p, Pho9p, Pho80p, Pho81p and Pho85p; dephosphorylates phosphotyrosyl peptides; contributes to NAD+ metabolism by producing nicotinamide riboside from NMN
functionSummary: Alkaline phosphatase involved in protein dephosphorylation and nicotinamide nucleotide metabolism; localizes to the vacuole membrane
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant accumulates reduced levels of N-ribosylnicotinamide; in large-scale studies, null mutant displays reductions in competitive fitness and starvation resistance, and is sensitive to sodium selenide

description: Repressor of G1 transcription; binds to SCB binding factor (SBF) at SCB target promoters in early G1; dilution of Whi5p concentration during cell growth determines cell size; phosphorylation of Whi5p by the CDK, Cln3p/Cdc28p relieves repression and promoter binding by Whi5, and contributes to both the determination of critical cell size at START and cell fate; periodically expressed in G1
functionSummary: Transcription cofactor that represses transcription during the G1/S mitotic transition; component of the SBF transcription complex; localizes to both the cytoplasm and nucleus
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant has small nuclei, small cell size, extended lifespan, is sensitive to caffeine; ability of homozygous diploid null to sporulate is dependent on strain background; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient

description: Repressor of translation initiation; binds eIF4G through its RGG domain and inhibits recruitment of the preinitiation complex; also contains an Lsm domain; may have a role in RNA processing; overproduction suppresses null mutation in clathrin heavy chain gene CHC1; forms cytoplasmic foci upon DNA replication stress

briefDescription: Required for 25S rRNA maturation and 60S ribosomal subunit assembly
description: Required for 25S rRNA maturation and 60S ribosomal subunit assembly; localizes to the nucleolus and in foci along nuclear periphery; constituent of 66S pre-ribosomal particles; cooperates with Rrs1p and Mps3p to mediate telomere clustering by binding Sir4p, but is not involved in telomere tethering

briefDescription: Required for splicing of the group I intron bI5 of the COB pre-mRNA
description: Required for splicing of the group I intron bI5 of the COB pre-mRNA; nuclear-encoded mitochondrial protein that binds to the RNA to promote splicing; also involved in but not essential for splicing of the COB bI2 intron and the intron in the 21S rRNA gene
functionSummary: Mitochondrial RNA binding protein involved in mitochondrial mRNA processing via Group I intron splicing
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant diploid shows reduced rate of respiratory growth on non-fermentable carbon sources; in systematic studies null mutants show decreased chronological lifespan and competitive fitness

description: Reticulon-interacting protein; ER integral membrane protein involved in the generation of tubular ER morphology; promotes membrane curvature; forms tubules in vitro; regulates the ER asymmetry-induced inheritance block during ER stress; role in ER-derived peroxisomal biogenesis; interacts with Yip1p to mediate membrane traffic and with Sey1p to maintain ER morphology; facilitates lipid exchange between the ER and mitochondria; forms ER foci upon DNA replication stress
phenotypeSummary: Non-essential gene; null mutant has a reduced ability to utilize glutamine or glutamate as nitrogen source; null mutant displays increased autophagy during nitrogen starvation; overexpression results in increased filamentous growth in sigma1278b; overexpression in another strain background results in lethality, with huge swollen cells that accumulate internal membranes, and have a block in membrane traffic; heterozygous diploid null is haploinsufficient

description: Reticulon protein; involved in nuclear pore assembly and maintenance of tubular ER morphology; promotes membrane curvature; regulates the ER asymmetry-induced inheritance block during ER stress; role in ER-derived peroxisomal biogenesis; increases tubular ER when overexpressed; mutants have reduced phosphatidylserine transfer between the ER and mitochondria; interacts with exocyst subunit Sec6p, Yip3p, and Sbh1p; member of the RTNLA subfamily

Reticulon protein; involved in nuclear pore assembly and maintenance of tubular ER morphology; promotes membrane curvature; regulates the ER asymmetry-induced inheritance block during ER stress; role in ER-derived peroxisomal biogenesis; interacts with Sec6p, Yip3p, and Sbh1p; less abundant than RTN1; member of RTNLA (reticulon-like A) subfamily; protein increases in abundance and relocalizes to plasma membrane upon DNA replication stress

briefDescription: Retrotransposon TYA Gag and TYB Pol genes
description: Retrotransposon TYA Gag and TYB Pol genes; Gag processing produces capsid proteins, Pol is cleaved to produce protease, reverse transcriptase and integrase activities; in YARCTy1-1 TYB is mutant and probably non-functional; protein product forms cytoplasmic foci upon DNA replication stress

briefDescription: Retrotransposon TYA Gag and TYB Pol genes
description: Retrotransposon TYA Gag and TYB Pol genes; Gag processing produces capsid proteins, Pol is cleaved to produce protease, reverse transcriptase and integrase activities; in YDRCTy1-3 TYB is mutant and probably non-functional

briefDescription: Retrotransposon TYA Gag and TYB Pol genes
description: Retrotransposon TYA Gag and TYB Pol genes; polyprotein is processed to make a nucleocapsid-like protein (Gag), reverse transcriptase (RT), protease (PR), and integrase (IN); YLR035C-A is part of a mutant retrotransposon

briefDescription: Retrotransposon TYA Gag and TYB Pol genes
description: Retrotransposon TYA Gag and TYB Pol genes; transcribed/translated as one unit; polyprotein is processed to make a nucleocapsid-like protein (Gag), reverse transcriptase (RT), protease (PR), and integrase (IN); similar to retroviral genes

briefDescription: Retrotransposon TYA Gag and TYB Pol genes
description: Retrotransposon TYA Gag and TYB Pol genes; transcribed/translated as one unit; polyprotein is processed to make a nucleocapsid-like protein (Gag), reverse transcriptase (RT), protease (PR), and integrase (IN); similar to retroviral genes

briefDescription: Retrotransposon TYA Gag and TYB Pol genes
description: Retrotransposon TYA Gag and TYB Pol genes; transcribed/translated as one unit; polyprotein is processed to make a nucleocapsid-like protein (Gag), reverse transcriptase (RT), protease (PR), and integrase (IN); similar to retroviral genes

briefDescription: Retrotransposon TYA Gag and TYB Pol genes
description: Retrotransposon TYA Gag and TYB Pol genes; transcribed/translated as one unit; polyprotein is processed to make a nucleocapsid-like protein (Gag), reverse transcriptase (RT), protease (PR), and integrase (IN); similar to retroviral genes

briefDescription: Retrotransposon TYA Gag and TYB Pol genes
description: Retrotransposon TYA Gag and TYB Pol genes; transcribed/translated as one unit; polyprotein is processed to make a nucleocapsid-like protein (Gag), reverse transcriptase (RT), protease (PR), and integrase (IN); similar to retroviral genes; YHR214C-B has a paralog, YAR070C, that arose from a segmental duplication

Retrotransposon TYA Gag gene; Gag is a nucleocapsid protein that is the structural constituent of virus-like particles (VLPs); similar to retroviral Gag; YDR170W-A is part of a mutant retrotransposon; distribution in the cytoplasm becomes irregular rather than punctate upon DNA replication stress

briefDescription: Retrotransposon TYA Gag gene co-transcribed with TYB Pol
description: Retrotransposon TYA Gag gene co-transcribed with TYB Pol; Gag processing produces capsid proteins; in YARCTy1-1 TYB is mutant and probably non-functional

briefDescription: Retrotransposon TYA Gag gene co-transcribed with TYB Pol
description: Retrotransposon TYA Gag gene co-transcribed with TYB Pol; Gag processing produces capsid proteins; in YDRCTy1-3 TYB is mutant and probably non-functional

briefDescription: Retrotransposon TYA Gag gene co-transcribed with TYB Pol
description: Retrotransposon TYA Gag gene co-transcribed with TYB Pol; translated as TYA or TYA-TYB polyprotein; Gag is a nucleocapsid protein that is the structural constituent of virus-like particles (VLPs); similar to retroviral Gag
